Â Â THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court


  
    
      
        Diana Ardis and
          William David Ardis, Respondents,
        v.
        Edward L.
          Sessions, D.C., Petitioner.
      
    
  


ON WRIT OF CERTIORARI TO THE COURT OF APPEALS

Appeal From Charleston County
Â  Deadra L. Jefferson, Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No.Â  26695
  Heard February 3, 2009 - Filed August 3,
2009 

REVERSED


  
    
      
        Charles
          E. Hill, and R. Hawthorne Barrett, both of Turner, Padget, Graham & Laney, of
          Columbia, for Petitioner.
        Ellis I.
          Kahn, and Justin S. Kahn, both of Kahn Law Firm, of Charleston, for Respondents.
      
    
  


JUSTICE KITTREDGE: In this chiropractic malpractice action, the court of
  appeals reversed a defense jury verdict based on an erroneous jury
  instruction.Â  Â Ardis v. Sessions, 370 S.C. 229, 633 S.E.2d 905 (Ct. App. 2006).Â  We granted a writ of certiorari to review the decision of the court of
  appeals.Â  We reverse and reinstate the defense verdict, for we hold Respondents
  were not prejudiced by the jury charge.
I.
Diana
  Ardis suffered a herniated disk which
  resulted in surgery on February 29, 1996.Â  Ardis sued Dr. Edward L. Sessions in
  negligence for chiropractic malpractice, claiming Sessions caused the herniated
  disk when he performed a spinal manipulation on February 19, 1996.[1]Â 
  Sessions denied he performed a manipulation on February 19, and the trial
  centered on who was telling the truth about the February 19 office visit.
Ardis
  reported on February 19 to Sessions (and separately to his office assistant)
  â€œthat she had slipped off of a ladder hurting her left low back and leg.â€Â 
  Ardis admitted she made the statements about falling off a ladder, but
  purportedly only in jest.Â  â€œAt trial, Sessions testified that instead of a
  manipulation that day, he used a less invasive treatment, which would have been
  insufficient to herniate [Ardisâ€™] disk.â€[2]Â  Ardis, 370 S.C. at 231, 633 S.E.2d at 906.
The
  jury returned a defense verdict.Â  Ardis appealed, challenging the â€œgood faithâ€
  portion of the jury charge, the refusal to charge the jury as requested, and
  certain evidentiary rulings.Â  A panel majority of the court of appeals reversed
  and remanded based on its view that the â€œgood faithâ€ jury charge was erroneous
  and prejudicial.Â  One member of the appellate panel dissented, noting that
  â€œ[w]hen reviewing a jury instruction for alleged error, the appellate court
  must consider the charge as a whole in light of the evidence and issues
  presented at trial.â€ Â Ardis, 370 S.C. at 234, 633 S.E.2d at 907 (Beatty,
  J. dissenting).Â  
II.
A.
The challenged jury charge is as follows:

  I . . . charge you that a mistake in diagnosis of
    itself will not support a verdict in a malpractice suit.Â  I charge you that a
    physician is not ordinarily liable for making an incorrect diagnosis where it
    is made in good faith and there is reasonable doubt as to the nature of the
    physical conditions involved or as to what should be done in accordance with
    recognized authority in good current practice or where it is made in good faith
    on observation of the patient and based upon physical evidences and symptoms
    which would warrant such diagnosis by a reasonably prudent and informed
    physician.[3]

The court of
  appeals agreed with Ardis and found the jury instruction erroneous and
  prejudicial.
We agree with the court of appeals majority that a â€œgood
  faithâ€ jury charge in a professional malpractice case is improper due to the
  implication that â€œan error in judgment is actionable only if made in bad
  faith.â€Â  McCourt ex rel. McCourt v. Abernathy, 318 S.C. 301, 306, 457 S.E.2d
  603, 606 (1995).Â  The â€œgood faithâ€ instruction requires a plaintiff in a
  malpractice action to demonstrate not only a departure from the standard of
  care, but additionally that such error was made in bad faith.Â  The â€œgood faithâ€
  instruction impermissibly adds a subjective component contrary to our objective
  professional negligence law. 
B.
The
  â€œgood faithâ€ instruction, while erroneous, did not prejudice Ardis.
When an appellate court reviews an alleged error in a jury charge,
  it â€œmust consider the courtâ€™s jury charge as a whole in light of the evidence
  and issues presented at trial.Â  If, as a whole, the charges are reasonably free
  from error, isolated portions which might be misleading do not constitute
  reversible error.â€Â  Keaton ex rel.
    Foster v. Greenville Hosp. Sys., 334
  S.C. 488, 497, 514 S.E.2d 570, 575 (1999) (citations omitted).Â  This holistic
  approach to jury instructions is linked to the principle of appellate procedure that â€œ[a]n error not shown to be
  prejudicial does not constitute grounds for reversal.â€  Brown v.
    Pearson, 326 S.C. 409, 417, 483 S.E.2d 477, 481 (Ct. App. 1997); see
      also Cole v. Raut, 378 S.C. 398, 405, 663 S.E.2d 30, 33 (2008)
  (reciting the rule that a charge must be erroneous and prejudicial to warrant
  reversal);Â  Ellison v. Simmons, 238 S.C. 364, 372, 120 S.E.2d 209, 213
  (1961) (noting that a jury â€œcharge, even if erroneous, on a matter not in
  issue, is not always considered prejudicialâ€).Â  
The â€œgood
  faithâ€ jury instruction was limited to liability associated with â€œan incorrect
  diagnosis.â€Â  Ardis, 370 S.C. at 232, 633 S.E.2d at 906.Â  At best, the
  malpractice claim of Ardis only tangentially concerned an incorrect diagnosis.Â 
  Because the outcome of the malpractice claim turned on who was telling the
  truth about the February 19 office visit, the trial focused on the conflicting
  testimony and the records of the February 19 visit.
As
  counsel for Sessions argued to the jury, â€œwe come back to this piece of paper
  [concerning the February 19 office visit] because the case turns on the
  accuracy of this document.â€Â  Sessionsâ€™ counsel further argued in closing that
  â€œthe bottom line issue is[,] did she get a chiropractic adjustment on February
  the 19th, 1996?Â  Because if she didnâ€™t, her whole case is gone.â€[4]Â  
Most
  professional negligence actions involve scrutiny of the professionalâ€™s exercise
  of judgment.Â  This case, however, presents an exception to the typical
  professional malpractice claim in that the outcome of this malpractice claim
  turned on who was telling the truth about the February 19 office visit.Â  Accordingly,
  when the challenged jury charge is viewed
  â€œin light of the evidence and issues presented at trial[,]â€ it becomes apparent that the challenged â€œgood faithâ€ jury
  charge resulted in no prejudice to Ardis.Â  Keaton, 334 S.C. at 497, 514
  S.E.2d at 575. 
C.
Because
  the court of appeals reversed the defense verdict based on the â€œgood faithâ€
  jury charge, the court of appeals did not reach Ardisâ€™ other appellate issues.Â 
  We have reviewed the record and find no prejudicial errors in the exclusion of
  evidence or the trial courtâ€™s refusal to give a requested instruction.Â  We
  affirm the trial court pursuant to Rule 220(b)(1), SCACR, and the following
  authorities: Issues II, III, and V:Â  Gamble v. Intâ€™l Paper Realty Corp. of
    S.C., 323 S.C. 367, 373, 474 S.E.2d 438, 441 (1996) (â€œThe admission or
  exclusion of evidence is a matter within the sound discretion of the trial
  court and absent clear abuse, will not be disturbed on appeal.â€); and Â Â Issue
  IV:Â  Daves v. Cleary, 355 S.C. 216, 224, 584 S.E.2d 423, 427 (Ct. App. 2003) (noting that an appellate court must review a challenged jury instruction as
  a whole, and that a trial courtâ€™s failure to charge a â€œproperly requested
  charge is reversible error only where the requesting party can demonstrate
  prejudice from the refusalâ€).Â  
III.
In a
  professional negligence action, a â€œgood faithâ€ jury instruction that imposes on
  a plaintiff the additional burden of showing bad faith improperly introduces a
  subjective element to our objective test of liability.Â  Here, the â€œgood faithâ€
  charge was erroneous, but not prejudicial.Â  Nothing in the charge casts doubt
  on the juryâ€™s ability to objectively and fairly determine the truth concerning
  the February 19, 1996 office visit.Â  When
  the â€œgood faithâ€ charge is viewed â€œin light of the evidence and issues
  presented at trial[,]â€ it is apparent
  that the jury charge resulted in no prejudice to Ardis.Â  Keaton, 334
  S.C. at 497, 514 S.E.2d at 575.Â  We therefore reverse the decision of the court
  of appeals and reinstate the defense verdict.
REVERSED.
TOAL, C.J. and
  Acting Justice BURNETT, concur. PLEICONES, J., dissenting in a separate opinion
  in which WALLER, J., concurs.

JUSTICE PLEICONES:Â  I respectfully dissent.Â  While I agree with the
  majority that the â€œgood faithâ€ jury instruction was erroneous, I also find that
  the charge was prejudicial and would affirm the Court of Appeals.
If the jury believed Ardisâ€™s
  assertion that Sessions performed a manipulation under the circumstances she
  described, the jury must still have found that her version of the facts
  demonstrated negligence on the part of Sessions, in order for Ardis to prevail. See Hurd v. Williamsburg Co., 353 S.C. 596, 615, 579 S.E.2d 136,
  146 (Ct. App. 2003), affâ€™d, 363 S.C. 421, 611 S.E.2d 488 (The burden of
  proof in a negligence action is on the plaintiff to establish the negligence of
  the defendant).Â  At trial, Ardis presented evidence to show not only that
  Sessions performed the manipulation, but also that in doing so he breached the
  standard of care.Â  The trial courtâ€™s â€œgood faithâ€ instruction directly
  addresses this aspect of the case and, therefore, prejudiced Ardis.
I disagree with the
  majorityâ€™s reading of Sessionsâ€™s testimony as acknowledging that it would have
  been malpractice to perform a manipulation on February 19 in light of Ardisâ€™s
  reported injury that day.Â  Contrary to the majorityâ€™s reading, the record
  indicates that Sessions believed the issue whether the actions alleged by Ardis
  constituted negligence to be very much in dispute.Â  At the conclusion of his
  case, Sessions moved for a directed verdict, arguing that, even assuming that
  Sessions performed an adjustment, as Ardis claimed:

  [t]here has been
    absolutely no testimony in this case from [Ardisâ€™s expert] or anyone else that
    if Ms. Ardis presented to Doctor Sessions on February the 19th in the condition
    that she says that she was in, that there was any contraindication for Doctor
    Sessions to give her an ordinary chiropractic adjustment on that day.Â  There is
    absolutely no testimony that there was a deviation from the standard of care by
    Doctor Sessions on February 19 in giving this lady an adjustment.

We simply do not know whether
  the jury, in rendering a defense verdict, believed Sessionsâ€™s testimony that no
  manipulation was performed on the day in question or believed Ardisâ€™s testimony
  that a manipulation was performed, but found that to perform a manipulation
  under the circumstances did not constitute malpractice.Â  In my opinion, the use
  of the subjective â€œgood faithâ€ element in the jury instruction imposed an
  unrealistic burden on Ardis in her effort to prove negligence, and the jury may
  have found against Ardis due to her failure to meet such a standard.Â  See McCourt by and through McCourt v. Abernathy, 318 S.C. 301, 457 S.E.2d
  603 (1995).Â  I would therefore affirm the Court of Appeals.[5]
WALLER,
  J., concurs.


[1] Ardisâ€™ husband, William David Ardis, filed a loss of consortium claim.
[2] Specifically, Sessions testified that on February 19 Ardis had
  â€œparaspinal spasms.Â  We did some posterior pressure on the sacrum.Â  I diagnosed
  it with a sprain strain and told her to rest and use some ice.â€Â  When Sessions
  was asked if he had adjusted Ardis on February 19 or â€œdo[ne] anything that
  would aggravate her if she had a ruptured disk[,]â€ he answered no.Â  Sessions
  was additionally asked why he did not perform a manipulation of the â€œfull spine
  or the cervical thoracicâ€ on February 19, as he had routinely done on prior
  appointments.Â  Sessions replied, â€œher signs and symptoms did not indicate that
  I should adjust her.â€Â  Those â€œsigns and symptomsâ€ included Ardisâ€™ being â€œbent
  to the right sideâ€ and her claim of falling off a ladder.Â  In light of Ardisâ€™
  reported injury on February 19, we view Sessionsâ€™ testimony as an implicit
  acknowledgement that it would have been inappropriate to perform a full
  manipulation on that day. 
[3] The trial court frequently used the term â€œphysician,â€ although this case
  dealt with a claim of chiropractic malpractice.Â  There is no suggestion of
  error in this regard, for legal principles concerning professional malpractice
  claims generally remain constant from one profession to another.
[4] The closing argument by Ardisâ€™ counsel is not in the record on appeal.Â 
  The record, nevertheless, leaves no doubt that the case turned on whether
  Sessions performed a manipulation on Ardis on February 19.
[5] In briefs and in oral arguments, both parties also addressed various
  evidentiary issues from the trial court.Â  Because evidentiary holdings of the
  initial trial are not binding on remand, I would find it unnecessary to address
  these points. See Hosford v. Wynn, 26 S.C. 130, 1 S.E. 497, 499
  (1887) (new trial opens anew all questions in the case).

The Supreme Court of South Carolina
In the Matter of Elizabeth Mason Smith, Respondent.


ORDER

 Respondent, the Beaufort County Clerk of Court, was indicted for misconduct in office and embezzlement of public funds.  The Office of Disciplinary Counsel has filed a petition asking the Court to place respondent on interim suspension pursuant to Rule 17(b), RLDE, Rule 413, SCACR, because she poses a substantial threat of serious harm to the public or the administration of justice. 
 IT IS ORDERED that the petition is granted and respondent is suspended, pursuant to Rule 17(b), RLDE, Rule 413, SCACR, from the practice of law in this State until further order of this Court.


  
     
    s/ Costa M. Pleicones J.
      FOR THE COURT
  

Columbia, South Carolina
July 31, 2009

The Supreme Court of South Carolina
In the Matter of Clyde A. Eltzroth, Jr., Respondent.


ORDER

Respondent was suspended on April 27, 2009, for a period of ninety  (90) days.  He has now filed an affidavit  requesting reinstatement pursuant to Rule 32, of the Rules for Lawyer  Disciplinary Enforcement contained in Rule 413, SCACR. 
  The request is granted and he is hereby reinstated to the  practice of law in this state.

  
     
    JEAN H. TOAL, CHIEF JUSTICE
      s/Daniel E. Shearouse      
        Clerk
  

Columbia, South Carolina
August 3, 2009

title: K&A Acquisition Group v. Island Pointe
description: In this declaratory judgment action, Appellant appeals the master-in-equity's order finding that a .42 acre parcel of coastal property was "abandoned" by the South Carolina Department of Transportation and properly conveyed by quitclaim deed to private landowners.  We affirm as modified.

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court

	
		
			
				K&A
      Acquisition Group, LLC, Appellant,
				v.
				Island Pointe,
      LLC; South Carolina Department of Transportation, Elizabeth S. Mabry, in her
      Official Capacity as Executive Director of the South Carolina Department of
      Transportation; and City of Folly Beach, South Carolina, Respondents.
			
		
	


Appeal From Charleston County
Mikell R. Scarborough, Master-in-Equity
Opinion No.Â  26696
Heard April 21, 2009 - Filed August 10,
  2009Â  
AFFIRMED AS MODIFIED


	
		
			
				C.
  Mitchell Brown, of Nelson, Mullins, Riley & Scarborough, of Columbia,
  Robert H. Brunson and Erin E. Richardson, both of Nelson, Mullins, Riley &
  Scarborough, of Charleston, for Appellant.
				Beacham
  O. Brooker, Jr., of Columbia, Ellison D. Smith, IV, of Smith, Bundy, Bybee
  & Barnett, of Mt. Pleasant, James B. Richardson, Jr., of Columbia, Michael
  R. Daniel, of Elloree, Otis B. Peeples, Jr., of Charleston, for Respondents.
			
		
	

JUSTICE BEATTY:Â  In this declaratory judgment action, K&A Acquisition Group, LLC
  (K&A), appeals the master-in-equityâ€™s order finding that a .42 acre parcel
  of coastal property, which was part of a former Folly Beach toll road, was
  â€œabandonedâ€ by the South Carolina Department of Transportation (SCDOT) and
  properly conveyed by a quitclaim deed to private landowners.Â  Pursuant to Rule
  204(b), SCACR, this Court certified this appeal from the Court of Appeals.Â  We
  affirm as modified.
FACTUAL/PROCEDURAL HISTORY
In
  March 2005, K&A purchased Long Island located to the east of Peas Island across from Folly Creek. Â Long Island is annexed into the City of Folly Beach. Â K&A
  purchased this property with the expectation that it would construct a
  residential development on Long Island with approximately fifty to sixty home sites. 
Because
  there is no means of vehicular access to Long Island across Folly Creek,
  K&A sought to purchase a .42 acre parcel of property on neighboring Peas Island from Henry and Linda Walker (â€œthe Walker tractâ€). Â This parcel constituted a
  portion of the â€œoldâ€ Folly Beach toll road which originated in 1923 and has a
  lengthy procedural history.Â  
Prior
  to 1923, the Folly Beach Corporation, which owned and developed a significant
  portion of Folly Island, built a private road which:Â  started on James Island,
  crossed Peas Island, bridged Folly Creek to Long Island, crossed Long Island,
  extended from Long Island to Big Oak Island and Little Oak Island, and
  ultimately crossed Folly River and ended on Folly Island. 
On
  March 16, 1923, the General Assembly created the Folly Roadway Company â€œfor the
  purpose of constructing, maintaining, and operating a toll and turnpike road
  from a point on Jamesâ€™ Island, in the County of Charleston, to Folly Island in
  the said county, over the route of the existing road, causeways and bridges now
  connecting said islands, with the right to charge tolls on said route as fixed
  by law, and to erect one or more gates on said route for the collection of the
  same.â€ (â€œ1923 Legislative Actâ€).Â  Act No. 288, 1923 S.C. Acts 557.Â  
Subsequently,
  the Folly Beach Corporation conveyed the existing road to the Folly Roadway
  Company by deed recorded on April 13, 1923. 
After
  two years of operation, the Folly Roadway Company decided to rebuild the road
  and bridges and straighten the route of the toll road by extending the
  causeway, which connected James Island and Peas Island, all the way to Folly Beach. Â The construction of this new route would eliminate a portion of the original
  toll road which crossed Peas Island, Long Island, and two other marsh islands.
By
  legislative act, the General Assembly authorized the Folly Roadway Company to
  implement its plan to relocate the toll road.Â  Â Act No. 34, 1926 S.C. Acts
  1441.Â  In order to finance the construction of the â€œnewâ€ Folly Beach Road, the
  Folly Roadway Company issued $380,000 in bonds secured by mortgage of its
  properties, including the property underlying the â€œoldâ€ toll road route, to
  Citizens and Southern Bank of Savannah, Georgia. Â According to the Folly
  Roadway Company, the project resulted in â€œpractically a new road with its
  necessary bridges, causeways . . . connecting said Folly Island with James
  Island, S.C.â€ 
On
  November 28, 1939, Charleston County offered to purchase the toll road.Â  The
  Folly Roadway Company rejected the offer on the ground it refused to sell the
  roadway for less than the amount due on its outstanding bonds.Â  Subsequently, the
  bank securing the bonded indebtedness foreclosed on the Folly Roadway Companyâ€™s
  property.Â  At the foreclosure sale, Charleston County purchased all of the property
  owned by the Folly Roadway Company.Â  
On April 3, 1943,
  the General Assembly authorized and directed the State Highway Commission
  (n/k/a â€œSCDOTâ€) to purchase from Charleston County the â€œFolly Beach Road in Charleston County, to Free the Said Road of Toll Charges and to Authorize Charleston County to Sell Said Road to the Said Commission.â€Â  Act No. 64, 1943 S.C. Acts 85. 
According to the SCDOTâ€™s
  records, there was no maintenance performed on the remnants of the â€œoldâ€ route
  to Folly Beach which remained on Peas Island, Long Island, Big Oak Island, and then ran into private property.Â  These records also reflect that no portion
  of the â€œoldâ€ route was ever assigned a number as part of the State Highway System.Â  
Not
  until 2002, did the SCDOT realize that it owned the property at issue.Â  At that
  time, an attorney for the Walkers requested a quitclaim deed from the SCDOT to
  remove a cloud on the title to their property.Â Â  The Walkers, while attempting
  to sell their property, discovered that their house on Peas Island was located on top of a portion of the â€œoldâ€ Folly Beach Road toll route.Â  
By quitclaim deed
  dated April 3, 2002, the SCDOT conveyed to the Walkers the .42 acre tract of
  land on Peas Island for consideration in the amount of $1.00. 
Because
  K&A believed the â€œchief and most available means of access from Long Island
  to Folly Roadâ€ was a portion of property located across neighboring Peas Island, it sought to purchase the Walker tract and to obtain regulatory approval for a
  bridge connecting Long Island to Peas Island.Â  K&A claimed the purchase of
  the parcel was necessary to ensure a right of way from the residential
  development on Long Island to the mainland.
Shortly after
  K&A purchased Long Island, Island Pointe, LLC (â€œIsland Pointeâ€) purchased Peas Island and obtained title insurance on the entire tract which included the Walker tract.[1]Â 
  After the City of Folly Beach approved the residential development of Peas Island, Island Pointe proceeded with its development plan. 
K&A filed this
  declaratory judgment action against Island Pointe, the SCDOT, and the City of
  Folly Beach. Â In terms of relief, K&A essentially sought for the trial
  court to declare that the Walker tract remained a public right of way.Â  In
  support of this request for relief, K&A claimed the SCDOT did not abandon
  the property and did not properly convey it to the Walkers.
After a hearing,
  the master-in-equity ruled against K&A, finding: Â (1) the right of way
  dedicated to the public on the â€œoldâ€ Folly Beach toll road was transferred to
  the â€œnewâ€ Folly Beach toll road, (2) the SCDOT properly abandoned the portion
  of its property that once comprised the â€œoldâ€ Folly Beach toll road, (3) the
  SCDOT properly disposed of a portion of the property by means of a quitclaim
  deed to the Walkers, and (4) it did not have jurisdiction to declare that a
  public right of way still existed over the â€œoldâ€ route in question given such a
  decision would deprive landowners along this route, who were not joined as
  parties, an opportunity to protect their property interests.Â  The master-in-equity
  denied K&Aâ€™s motion for reconsideration.Â  
K&A appealed
  the master-in-equityâ€™s decision to the Court of Appeals.Â  Pursuant to Rule
  204(b), SCACR, this Court certified this appeal from the Court of Appeals.
ISSUES
I.  Should the court
  enforce a deed that purports to convey a fee simple interest from the State to
  a private party if the State did not â€œvigorously attempt to sell the property
  by advertising for competitive bids in local newspapers or by direct
  negotiationsâ€ as required by South Carolina Code Ann. Â§ 57-5-340?
II.  If a deed states
  that it is â€œsubject to any and all existing reservations, easements, rights of
  way, [and] control of access,â€ does the deed transfer the public right of way
  existing on the property conveyed in the deed to the grantee?
III.  Is a dedicated
  public right of way on the path of a former toll road â€œabandonedâ€ when the
  route of the toll road is moved but there was no â€œunequivocal act showing a
  clear intent to abandonâ€ the right of way and undisputed evidence supports
  continued public use of the road after the supposed â€œabandonment in fact?â€
IV.  Are current owners of
  property potentially subject to a public right of way â€œindispensable partiesâ€
  to litigation in which a non-adjoining property owner is challenging a deed
  potentially subject to a similar public right of way? 
STANDARD OF REVIEW
â€œA suit for declaratory judgment is
  neither legal nor equitable, but is determined by the nature of the underlying
  issue.â€Â  Felts v. Richland County, 303 S.C. 354, 356, 400 S.E.2d 781,
  782 (1991).
The determination of whether property has been dedicated to the
  public is an action in equity.Â  State v. Beach Co., 271 S.C. 425, 248
  S.E.2d 115 (1978); Mack v. Edens, 320 S.C. 236, 464 S.E.2d 124 (Ct. App.
  1995). Â â€œIf the action is viewed as interpreting a deed, it is an equitable
  matter and the appellate court may review the evidence to determine
  the facts in accordance with the courtâ€™s view of the preponderance of the evidence.â€Â  Slear v. Hanna, 329 S.C. 407, 410, 496 S.E.2d 633, 635 (1998).
Because this is an action in equity referred to a master-in-equity
  for final judgment, we may find facts in accordance with our own view of the
  preponderance of the evidence. Â Thomas v. Mitchell, 287 S.C. 35, 336
  S.E.2d 154 (Ct. App. 1985).Â  We, however, are not required to ignore the
  findings of the trial judge, who heard and saw the witnesses. Â Id. at 38, 336 S.E.2d at 155. 
DISCUSSION
Although
  K&A argues its issues in the above-listed sequence, we believe that in the
  interest of clarity and logical progression the issues should be addressed out
  of the â€œbriefedâ€ order.Â  
We find this appeal
  essentially presents four questions:Â  (1) was the â€œoldâ€ Folly Beach toll road
  dedicated to the public; (2) if so, did the construction or relocation of the
  â€œnewâ€ Folly Beach toll road effectively abolish the public easement on the
  â€œoldâ€ Folly Beach Road; (3) if the public easement on the â€œoldâ€ Folly Beach
  toll road remained intact after the relocation, was it abandoned by the SCDOT;
  and (4) if abandoned, did the SCDOT properly convey a portion of this property?[2]
In
  short answer, we find the â€œoldâ€ Folly Beach Road was dedicated to the public
  and this public easement remained intact after the new road was created and
  until the SCDOT affirmatively abandoned the route of the former toll road.Â  Additionally,
  we hold the SCDOT properly conveyed by quitclaim deed a portion of this
  abandoned property to the Walkers.Â Â Â Â  
I.
Although
  K&A agrees with the master-in-equityâ€™s finding that the â€œoldâ€ Folly Beach
  toll road was dedicated to the public, it contends the master-in-equity erred
  in finding this was a â€œqualified public easementâ€ that ran with the toll road.Â 
  Because the right of way in the â€œoldâ€ Folly Beach toll road was properly
  dedicated to the public, K&A claims it remained dedicated to the public
  even after the Folly Roadway Company relocated the road and ceased operation of
  the original toll road.Â  
We
  agree with K&Aâ€™s contention.Â  For reasons that will be discussed, we find
  the relocation of the â€œnewâ€ Folly Beach toll road did not abolish the public
  right of way that was properly created in the â€œoldâ€ Folly Beach toll road.
â€œThe essence of dedication is that it shall be for the use of the
  public at large.â€ Â Safety Bldg. & Loan Co. v. Lyles, 131 S.C. 542, 544,
  128 S.E. 724, 724 (1925).Â  A dedication â€œmust be made to the use of the public
  exclusively, and not merely to the use of the public in connection with a user
  by the owners in such measure as they may desire.â€ Â Id. at 545, 128 S.E.
  at 724.Â  
Applying
  these principles to the instant case, we find the â€œoldâ€ Folly Beach toll road was unequivocally dedicated to the public.Â  Pursuant to the 1923 Legislative
  Act, the General Assembly incorporated the Folly Roadway Company and authorized
  it to operate the â€œoldâ€ Folly Beach Road as a toll road.Â  Upon receiving this
  charter, the Folly Beach Corporation conveyed the â€œoldâ€ Folly Beach Road to the
  Folly Roadway Company.Â  In turn, the Folly Roadway Company began operating the existing
  route as a toll road and effectively dedicated the road to the public.Â  
Two years later, this Court explicitly recognized the Folly
  Roadway Companyâ€™s dedication of the â€œoldâ€ Folly Beach Road to the public.Â  In State
    v. Olasov, 133 S.C. 139, 130 S.E. 514 (1925), this Court affirmed the
  conviction of Olasov for trespass on the land of another which arose out of
  Olasovâ€™s refusal to pay the toll on the â€œoldâ€ Folly Beach Road.Â  Because Olasov
  had purchased several lots on Folly Beach from the Folly Beach Corporation,
  which included a â€œfree rightâ€ to use the â€œoldâ€ Folly Beach Road, Olasov claimed
  he did not have to pay the toll.Â  In affirming Olasovâ€™s conviction, this Court
  found Olasovâ€™s easement to use the â€œoldâ€ Folly Beach Road was terminated upon
  the sale of the road to the Folly Roadway Company.Â  Id. at 144, 130 S.E.
  515.Â  In a concurring opinion, one justice stated, â€œWhile unquestionably the
  turnpike company has dedicated the highway to the public and the easement is a
  public easement and not private property, the turnpike company still retains
  the fee-simple title to the land.Â  The public has an easement to use the road
  upon the payment of tolls provided for in the act incorporating the turnpike
  company; that is, the public has a qualified easement.â€Â  Id. at 146, 130
  S.E. 516 (Cothran, J., concurring).
Furthermore, there is evidence in the record that the Folly
  Roadway Company believed the toll road was dedicated to the public.Â  In its
  Complaint dated July 22, 1940, in which it challenged Charleston Countyâ€™s condemnation action, the Folly Roadway Company specifically stated that the â€œoldâ€ Folly Beach toll road had been dedicated to the public. 
II.
Because
  the â€œoldâ€ Folly Beach Road had been dedicated to the public, K&A asserts the
  master-in-equity erred in determining that the construction of the â€œnewâ€ Folly Beach toll road effectively â€œtransferredâ€ the original public dedication from the
  â€œoldâ€ road to the â€œnewâ€ road. Â 
We find the master-in-equity erred in concluding that
  the public dedication was â€œtransferred by the changing of the route of the
  road.â€ Â Given the â€œoldâ€ Folly Beach Road was established as a highway and
  dedicated to the public, the public right of way continued until it was affirmatively
  abandoned by the SCDOT. Â Â 
The
  mere act of relocating the toll road did not have the effect of abolishing the
  public easement created in the original route.Â  Although the Folly Roadway
  Company may have vacated the â€œoldâ€ Folly Beach route, this action did not
  operate to eliminate the public right of way.Â  Thus, the â€œoldâ€ Folly Beach Road remained dedicated to the public despite the relocation.Â  See 39A
  C.J.S. Highways Â§ 128 (Supp. 2008) (â€œWhile the relocation of a highway
  by the public authority may be sufficient to show the abandonment of the old
  highway, such relocation does not automatically effect the abandonment of an
  old easement.â€);Â  39 Am. Jur. 2d Highways, Streets, & Bridges Â§ 148
  (2008) (â€œOnce established, a public highway does not lose its character as a
  public road unless it is either vacated by the authorities in the manner prescribed
  by statute or abandoned.â€); see also A.C. McI., Annotation, What
    Justifies Discontinuance of a Highway?, 68 A.L.R. 794 (1930 & Supp.
  2008) (noting that highways cannot be vacated unless they are useless,
  inconvenient or burdensome and concluding that whether a highway should be
  vacated, or discontinued, is determined primarily by considerations of its
  necessity or public utility).[3]
Moreover, this
  Court has specifically found that once a toll road is dedicated to the public
  the easement is not revoked upon cessation of the toll road operation.Â  Scheper
    v. Clark, 124 S.C. 302, 312, 117 S.E. 599, 602 Â (1923) (â€œâ€˜The weight of
  authority and sound reason concur in holding that, upon termination of the
  franchise, the road [a toll road] remains as before, a public highway, wholly
  freed from the burden of tolls.â€™â€ (quoting Allison v. R.C. Gravel-Road Co.,
  39 S.W. 910, 913 (Mo. 1897))).

III.
In
  view of our conclusion that the relocation of the original toll road did not
  operate to eliminate the public easement, the question becomes whether SCDOT
  properly abandoned the right of way.Â  See Hoogenboom v. City of
    Beaufort, 315 S.C. 306, 319 n.7, 433 S.E.2d 875, 884 n.7 (Ct. App. 1993)
  (â€œA right of way created by dedication may be lost by abandonment.â€). 
As we
  interpret the trial order, the master-in-equity equated the term
  â€œdiscontinuanceâ€ with â€œabandonment.â€ Â In his order, the master-in-equity states,
  â€œabandonment or discontinuance of the â€˜oldâ€™ route was effectively accomplished
  in 1926 upon completion of the â€˜newâ€™ road by the Folly Roadway Company pursuant
  to legislative action.â€Â  Based on this belief, the master-in-equity concluded
  â€œthis discontinuance operated as an affirmative abandonment in fact of the old
  roadway.â€ 
Although
  we agree with the master-in-equityâ€™s determination that the SCDOT abandoned the
  old route, we disagree that the â€œdiscontinuanceâ€ or relocation of the route was
  sufficient to constitute abandonment. Â The terms â€œdiscontinuanceâ€ and
  â€œabandonmentâ€ are not synonymous.Â  See Marrin v. Spearow, 646
  A.2d 254, 257 (Conn. App. Ct. 1994) (â€œâ€˜Discontinuanceâ€™ and â€˜abandonmentâ€™ are not synonymous terms as
  applied to highways. Â A highway may be extinguished by
  direct action through governmental agencies, in which case it is said to be
  discontinued; or by nonuser by the public for a long period of time with the
  intention to abandon, in which case it is said to be abandoned.â€ (citation
  omitted)); Ord v. Fugate, 152 S.E.2d 54, 59 (Va. 1967) (noting that discontinuance
  of public road should not carry the same effect as abandonment and stating
  â€œunder the present statutes the discontinuance of a secondary road means merely
  that it is removed from the state secondary road system. Â Discontinuance of a road
  is a determination only that it no longer serves public convenience warranting
  its maintenance at public expense. Â The effect of discontinuance upon a road is
  not to eliminate it as a public road or to render it unavailable for public
  useâ€); see also Wilson v. Greenville County, 110 S.C. 321,
  325, 96 S.E. 301, 302 (1918) (recognizing that discontinuance of a public
  highway and abandonment are two acts which are â€œseparate and distinct in fact
  and in lawâ€). 
The discontinuance of a
  highway may be evidence of abandonment.Â  However, mere discontinuance is not sufficient
  to prove abandonment.[4]Â 
  This conclusion is supported by our case law and our stateâ€™s statutory scheme
  governing the procedure required for abandonment.Â  
Under
  our stateâ€™s case law, for a party to prove abandonment it must present evidence
  beyond the mere relocation of a road.Â  See Wessinger v. Goza, 231
  S.C. 607, 611, 99 S.E.2d 395, 397 (1957) (â€œIt is axiomatic that a public
  highway is not abandoned simply because a new highway is built.â€).Â  Instead, a
  party must â€œshow the abandonment by clear and unequivocable evidence.â€Â  Carolina
    Land Co. v. Bland, 265 S.C. 98, 109, 217 S.E.2d 16, 21 (1975).Â  This Court
  has explained the principles of abandonment as follows:

	â€˜An abandonment occurs where the use for
  which the property is dedicated becomes impossible of execution, or where the
  object of the use for which the property is dedicated wholly fails. Â Any use
  which is not inconsistent with the declared purpose of a dedication will not
  support a charge of abandonment.â€™
	â€˜Acts of
  municipality. Â The rights of purchasers under a map and of the general public
  cannot be lost by the unauthorized acts of the governing or controlling
  officials of the municipality, or by their neglect, but only by legal abandonment
  by the public as well as the officials.â€™ 26 C.J.S. Dedication s 63 at
  page 552.
	â€˜An easement created by dedication may be abandoned by unequivocal
  acts showing a clear intent to abandon. Â To constitute abandonment, the use for
  which the property is dedicated must become impossible of execution, or the
  object of the use must wholly fail. Â Generally, a mere misuser or nonuser does
  not constitute abandonment of land dedicated to public use.â€™ 23 Am.Jur.(2d) 57,
  Dedication, Sec. 66.

City of Myrtle Beach v. Parker, 260 S.C. 475,
  486, 197 S.E.2d 290, 295-96 (1973).
Turning
  to the instant case, we find the SCDOT offered evidence of â€œunequivocal acts
  showing a clear intent to abandonâ€ the public easement.Â  
Although
  not dispositive, the Folly Roadway Company re-routed the â€œoldâ€ Folly Beach Road.Â  After this relocation, the use and maintenance of the old road
  significantly diminished because vehicular travel used the newly-created road.Â 
  Notably, after the relocation of the road in 1926, a one-hundred-foot private
  right of way over Big Oak Island was granted to property owners on Long Island
  as a means of access to Long Island from the â€œnewâ€ road.Â  That same year, the
  Folly Roadway Company deeded to H.T. and Alice Ebner a portion of the â€œoldâ€
  route from the end of Little Oak Island to Folly Island, which included the
  bridge over the Folly River.Â  In 1986, the SCDOT also issued by quitclaim deed
  to Harry L. Joye, Jr. and Cecelia Self a portion of the â€œoldâ€ route which
  crossed Big Oak Island.Â  Significantly, the Walkers built their home over a
  portion of the â€œoldâ€ route.Â  If the public right of way still remained on the
  â€œoldâ€ road, then the above easement would have been unnecessary, the SCDOT
  would not have deeded the property to the Ebners, and the Walkers would not have
  been able to construct their home in that particular location.
Based
  on the foregoing, we find the SCDOT properly abandoned the â€œoldâ€ Folly Beach Road, which included the Walker tract.Â  Cf. Williams v. Woodward,
  240 S.W.2d 94 (Ky. Ct. App. 1951) (holding that where the State Highway Department abandoned roadway and
  relocated new highway, abutting property owners built fences around roadway and
  otherwise obstructed it, and roadway had not been used to any substantial
  extent by public for some years, the actions of the State Highway Department,
  and of the abutting property owners and non-user by the public, constituted an
  abandonment of the roadway); Hart v.
    Town of Shafter, 810 N.E.2d 489, 491
  (Ill. App. Ct. 2004) (â€œ[A]n
  abandonment will be found only where the public has acquired the legal right to
  another road or where the necessity for another
  road has ceased to exist.â€); see J.E.M.,
  Annotation, Alteration or Relocation of Street or Highway as Abandonment or
    Vacation of Parts Not Included, 158 A.L.R. 543 (1945 & Supp. 2008) (analyzing
  cases and considering question of whether, or under what circumstances, a
  change in a public way will work an abandonment, vacation, or discontinuance of
  the former way to the extent of the change).
Furthermore,
  once the public easement on the â€œoldâ€ Folly Beach Road was abandoned, we find it
  could not be essentially â€œrededicated,â€ as contended by K&A, through
  nominal use by two or three Peas Island landowners or the placement of
  utilities during the 1970s or 1980s.Â  Â 

IV.
K&A argues the
  master-in-equity erred in enforcing the conveyance by quitclaim deed from the SCDOT to the Walkers on two grounds.Â  Initially, K&A claims the SCDOT
  failed to comply with the statutory requirements of section 57-5-340 of the
  South Carolina Code.Â  Even if the statutory requirements were satisfied,
  K&A asserts the language of the deed expressly subjected the transferred
  property to existing easements. 
A.
As stated in the
  deed, the SCDOT conveyed the property to the Walkers pursuant to the authority
  established in section 57-5-340 of the South Carolina Code.Â  This section
  provides in relevant part:Â  

	The department shall continuously inventory all of its real
  property. Â When, in the judgement [sic] of the department any real estate acquired
  as provided in this chapter is no longer necessary for the proper operation of
  the department or highway systems, the department shall vigorously attempt
    to sell the property by advertising for competitive bids in local newspapers 
	or by direct negotiations, but in every case of the sale or transfer of any real
    estate by the commission or the department, the sale or transfer shall be made
    public by publishing notice of it in the minutes of the next succeeding meeting
    of the commission. Â The commission and the department shall convey by deed,
  signed by the Secretary of the Department of Transportation and the Deputy
  Director of the Division of Finance and Administration, any real estate
  disposed of under this section. Â Any funds derived from the sale of surplus
  property by authority of this section shall be credited to the funding category
  from which funds were drawn to finance the departmentâ€™s acquisition of the
  property. 

S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 57-5-340 (2006
  & Supp. 2008) (emphasis added).Â  K&A asserts the deed should not be
  enforced because the SCDOT did not â€œvigorously attempt to sell the property by
  advertising for competitive bids in local newspapers or by direct
  negotiations.â€Â  
K&A
  is correct that the SCDOT did not advertise for competitive bids on the Walker property.Â  However, we find this was not necessary to be in compliance with section
  57-5-340.Â  As evidenced by the correspondence between the Walkersâ€™ attorney and
  the SCDOT, there were â€œdirect negotiationsâ€ between the parties.Â  Because the
  requirements for the SCDOT are written using the disjunctive â€œor,â€ we conclude
  the General Assembly has authorized the SCDOT to sell surplus property either
  through advertisement or direct negotiations. Â See Brewer v. Brewer,
  242 S.C. 9, 14, 129 S.E.2d 736, 738 (1963) (noting that the use of the word â€œorâ€ in a statute â€œis a disjunctive particle that marks an alternativeâ€); see
    also Hawkins v.
      Bruno Yacht Sales, Inc.,
  353 S.C. 31, 39, 577 S.E.2d 202, 207 (2003) (recognizing the cardinal rule of statutory construction is to ascertain and effectuate the intent of the
  legislature); Hitachi Data Sys. Corp. v. Leatherman, 309 S.C.
  174, 178, 420 S.E.2d 843, 846 (1992) (noting the words of the statute must be
  given their plain and ordinary meaning without resorting to subtle or forced
  construction to limit or expand the statuteâ€™s operation). Â Furthermore, as
  testified to at the hearing before the master-in-equity, the SCDOT published
  notice of the transfer â€œin the minutes of the next succeeding meeting of the
  commission.â€Â  Accordingly, we find the
  SCDOT sale of the Walker tract for consideration of $1.00 was sufficient to
  satisfy the requisite statutory procedure.[5]
B.
Even assuming the
  requirements of section 57-5-340 were satisfied by the means of conveyance,
  K&A contends a provision of the Walker deed identifies the existence of the
  public right of way on Peas Island.Â  The provision relied on by K&A states,
  â€œThis conveyance is being made subject to any and all existing public utility
  rights of user, reservations, easements, rights of way, control of access,
  zoning ordinances and restrictions or protective covenants that may appear on
  record or on the premises, other than those hereby released.â€ 
In construing a deed, â€œthe intention of the grantor must be
  ascertained and effectuated, unless that intention contravenes some well
  settled rule of law or public policy.â€Â  Wayburn v. Smith,
  270 S.C. 38, 41, 239 S.E.2d 890, 892 (1977).Â  â€œIn determining the grantorâ€™s
  intent, the deed must be construed as a whole and effect given to every part if
  it can be done consistently with the law.â€Â  Gardner v. Mozingo,
  293 S.C. 23, 25, 358 S.E.2d 390, 391-92 (1987). Â â€œThe intention of the grantor
  must be found within the four corners of the deed.â€ Id. at 25, 358
  S.E.2d at 392. Â â€œWhen intention is not expressed accurately in the deed
  evidence aliunde may be admitted to supply or explain it.â€Â  Id. Â â€œThe instrument is not thereby varied or contradicted but is explained or
  corrected.â€Â  Id. Â â€œâ€˜A
  grant of an easement is to be construed
  in accordance with the rules applied to deeds and other
  written instruments.â€™â€Â  Binkley v. Rabon Creek Watershed Conservation Dist.
    of Fountain Inn, 348 S.C. 58, 71, 558 S.E.2d 902, 909 (Ct. App. 2001)
  (quoting 28A C.J.S. Easements Â§ 57 (1996)). 
Applying these established rules of interpreting deeds, we find
  the property conveyed to the Walkers was not subject to a public easement.Â  As
  previously stated, any public easement on the â€œoldâ€ Folly Beach Road had been
  abandoned by the SCDOT well before the 2002 conveyance.Â  Significantly, the
  SCDOT did not even realize it had an interest in the property until the
  Walkersâ€™ attorney requested a quitclaim deed.Â  Moreover, given the Walkersâ€™
  home was built on top of the .42 acre parcel, it would have been nonsensical
  for the SCDOT to reserve a public right of way over this property.Â  Additionally,
  we believe the terms of the deed referencing a right of way constituted
  â€œboilerplateâ€ language which did not specifically identify any right of way.Â  Furthermore,
  we note the SCDOT issued a similar quitclaim deed to other Peas Island landowners in a 1986 conveyance, thus, indicating the absence of a public easement.Â  
V.
Finally,
  K&A argues the master-in-equity erred in concluding he was without
  jurisdiction to find that a public right of way existed over the â€œoldâ€ Folly Beach
  Road given the other potentially-affected landowners were not joined in the
  lawsuit.Â  K&A avers this ruling was erroneous because a ruling that the
  public right of way continues to exist would not disturb the property rights of
  landowners on Big Oak Island or Little Oak Island. 
In view of our
  conclusion that the SCDOT abandoned the public easement on the â€œoldâ€ Folly Beach Road, we need not address this issue.Â  See Hagood
    v. Sommerville, 362 S.C. 191, 199, 607 S.E.2d 707, 711 (2005) (stating the
  appellate court need not address additional issues when resolution of prior issue is
  dispositive).
In any event, we
  find the master-in-equityâ€™s conclusion was erroneous given the proper parties
  were joined in the lawsuit.Â  Because the evidence indisputably established that
  the public easement had been abandoned well before the 2002 conveyance to the
  Walkers, the necessary parties to the lawsuit were only those who had an
  interest in the specific .42 acre parcel.Â  Thus, Island Pointe, who purchased
  the Walker property, as well as the SCDOT and the City of Folly Beach were the
  only indispensable parties.Â  See S.C. Depâ€™t of Transp. v. Hinson
    Family Holdings, LLC, 361 S.C. 649, 655, 606 S.E.2d 781, 784-85 (2004)
  (stating â€œDOT and the local municipality are the indispensable parties that
  must be joined in an action to abandon a public roadâ€).Â  
CONCLUSION
We
  agree with the master-in-equityâ€™s ultimate decision to find the SCDOT abandoned
  the â€œoldâ€ Folly Beach Road and properly conveyed a portion of this property to
  the Walkers.Â  However, we modify the master-in-equityâ€™s order regarding the analysis
  of abandonment.Â  
We
  find the mere relocation or â€œdiscontinuanceâ€ of the â€œoldâ€ Folly Beach Road did
  not operate to abolish the previously established public right of way and to
  transfer it to the â€œnewâ€ Folly Beach Road.Â  Instead, we conclude the original
  public easement remained intact until the SCDOT affirmatively abandoned the
  property.Â  Additionally, we hold the SCDOT properly conveyed the .42 acre
  parcel at issue by complying with the statutory requirements of section
  57-5-340 and issuing a valid deed to the Walkers.Â  Accordingly, the decision of
  the master-in-equity is
AFFIRMED
  AS MODIFIED.
TOAL,
  C.J., WALLER, PLEICONES and KITTREDGE, JJ., concur.


[1]Â  The Walkers sold the .42 acre tract with an
  additional 1.5 acres on Peas Island to Island Pointe for $2,000,000. 
[2]Â  We note the Respondents question whether K&A has
  standing to challenge the SCDOTâ€™s conveyance of the Walker tract and, in turn, Island
  Pointeâ€™s ownership of the Walker tract.Â  Because this issue was neither raised
  to nor ruled upon by the master-in-equity, we find it is not preserved for this
  Courtâ€™s review. Â See Lucas v. Rawl Family Ltd. Pâ€™ship,
  359 S.C. 505, 511, 598 S.E.2d 712, 715 (2004) (stating an issue cannot be raised for
  the first time on appeal, but must have been raised to
  and ruled upon by the trial judge to be preserved for appellate  review). 
[3]Â  Although not expressly stated, section 57-5-120 of
  the South Carolina Code supports this conclusion in that the SCDOT may abandon
  a section of highway which is relocated.Â  This section implies that the SCDOT
  must take additional steps to abandon a road beyond mere relocation.Â  See S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 57-5-120 (2006) (â€œThe
  department may abandon as a part of the state highway system any section of
  highway which may be relocated, and every such section so abandoned as a part
  of the state highway system shall revert to the jurisdiction of the respective
  appropriate local authorities involved or be abandoned as a public way. Â But
  the department, in its discretion, may retain in the system any such relocated
  section when it serves as a needed connection to the new section or when it
  serves as a proper part of the state highway system.â€).Â  
[4]Â  We note the existence of an old case which appears
  to equate the term â€œdiscontinuanceâ€ with â€œabandonment.â€Â  However, we find the
  case is distinguishable and the statement constitutes dicta.Â  
In Keenan v.
  Broad River Power Co., 163 S.C. 133, 161 S.E. 330 (1931), a private
  landowner brought suit to recover damages resulting from the defendantsâ€™
  trespass.Â  Prior to the action, the defendants had acquired an easement over
  the landownerâ€™s property for the operation of their railroad.Â  Because the
  defendants ceased operation of the railway over this property, this Court found
  the â€œdiscontinuanceâ€ operated as an â€œabandonmentâ€ of the right of way which
  could not be revived.Â  Thus, the plaintiff was entitled to compensation for the
  damages incurred by the defendantsâ€™ re-entry upon the property.Â  
Keenan is
  distinguishable from the instant case in that it involved a private right of
  way.Â  Moreover, this Courtâ€™s statement regarding the two terms constituted
  dicta given the â€œDefendants practically admit[ted] that they had abandoned the
  right of wayâ€ even though they used the term discontinued.Â  Id. at 136,
  161 S.E. at 331.Â  Thus, it was unnecessary for this Court to define or analyze
  these two terms.
[5]Â Â  Our decision should in no way be construed as
  providing the SCDOT with â€œunbridledâ€ authority to convey public property to
  private landowners.Â  We believe the facts of this case are unique and will not
  recur on a frequent basis.Â  Moreover, the term â€œdirect negotiationsâ€
  necessarily requires a good faith effort on the part of the SCDOT to procure
  the best deal given the â€œfunds derived
  from the sale of surplus property by authority of this section shall be
  credited to the funding category from which funds were drawn to finance the
  departmentâ€™s acquisition of the property.â€ Â S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 57-5-340 (2006 & Supp. 2008).Â  In view of this
  statutory provision, it is in the best interest of the SCDOT to receive the
  most favorable financial return on its conveyance of surplus property.

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court

	
		
			
				James Stalk, Petitioner,
				v.
				State of South Carolina, Respondent.
			
		
	


ON WRIT OF CERTIORARI TO THE COURT OF
  APPEALS

Appeal from Lancaster County
Â Kenneth G. Goode, Circuit Court Judge
Opinion No.Â  26697
Submitted May 28, 2009 - Filed August 10,
  2009Â  
AFFIRMED AS MODIFIED


	
		
			
				Chief
  Appellate Defender Joseph L. Savitz, III, of South Carolina Commission on
  Indigent Defense, of Columbia, for Petitioner.
				Attorney
  General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney General John W. McIntosh, Assistant
  Deputy Attorney General Salley W. Elliott, and Assistant Attorney General David
  Spencer, all of Columbia, for Respondent.
			
		
	


JUSTICE
  PLEICONES:Â  We granted petitionerâ€™s (Stalkâ€™s) petition for a writ of
  certiorari to review a Court of Appeals decision which reversed a circuit court
  order granting Stalk post-conviction relief (PCR).Â  Stalk v. State, 375
  S.C. 289, 652 S.E.2d 402 (Ct. App. 2007).Â  WeÂ  affirm as modified.
FACTS/PROCEDURAL HISTORY
Stalk
  pleaded guilty to twelve charges[1] and received an aggregate sentence of fifty years.Â  He took no direct appeal,
  but filed a PCR application which was granted after an evidentiary hearing, the
  PCR judge finding Stalkâ€™s plea counsel rendered ineffective assistance.Â  The
  Court of Appeals granted the Stateâ€™s petition for a writ of certiorari to
  review that order.
A claim of
  ineffective assistance of guilty plea counsel requires the applicant present
  evidence satisfying two prongs: first, evidence that counselâ€™s performance was
  deficient; and second, evidence that the applicant was prejudiced by that
  deficiency.Â  Hill v. Lockhart, 474 U.S. 52 (1985).Â  Plea counsel is
  ineffective within the meaning of the Sixth Amendment only when the applicant
  satisfies both requirements. Â Id.Â  In its opinion, the Court of Appeals
  reversed, finding no evidence that counsel was â€œineffectiveâ€ or any evidence
  that Stalk was prejudiced by counselâ€™s â€œineffectiveness.â€Â  In its analysis, the
  Court of Appeals mislabeled as â€œIneffective Assistance of Counselâ€ the section
  analyzing whether there was evidence to support the PCR judgeâ€™s finding that
  Stalk had shown plea counselâ€™s â€œdeficient performance.â€Â  We modify the Court of
  Appealsâ€™ opinion to the extent that it confuses the requirement that Stalk must
  show deficient performance, with the ultimate question: whether he has
  demonstrated ineffective assistance of counsel entitling him to PCR.

ISSUE

	Did the
  Court of Appeals misapprehend the prejudice standard in a guilty plea
  ineffective assistance of counsel claim?

ANALYSIS
Stalk maintains
  that, assuming that he has shown counselâ€™s performance to be deficient, in
  order to obtain PCR he need only present testimony that but for that deficient
  performance, he would not have pleaded guilty but would have insisted on going
  to trial.Â  Stalk maintains that the question whether counselâ€™s deficient act(s)
  of omission or commission would have led to evidence which in turn would have
  affected the decision to plead guilty goes to the â€œdeficiency prongâ€ rather
  than to the â€œprejudice prongâ€ of an ineffective assistance claim.Â  He therefore
  argues the Court of Appeals in this case misapplied the ineffective assistance
  of plea counsel test.Â  We find no error in the Court of Appealsâ€™ prejudice
  analysis.

	In Hill, the
  United States Supreme Court explained:
	
		We
  hold, therefore, that the two-part Strickland v. Washington test applies
  to challenges to guilty pleas based on ineffective assistance of counsel.Â  In
  the context of guilty pleas, the first half of the Strickland v. Washington test is nothing more than a restatement of the standard of attorney competence
  already set forth in Tollett v. Henderson, supra, and McMann
    v. Richardson, supra.Â  The second, or â€œprejudice,â€ requirement, on
  the other hand, focuses on whether counselâ€™s constitutionally ineffective
  performance affected the outcome of the plea process.Â  In other words, in order
  to satisfy the â€œprejudiceâ€ requirement, the defendant must show that there is a
  reasonable probability that, but for counselâ€™s errors, he would not have
  pleaded guilty and would have insisted on going to trial.
		In many
  guilty plea cases, the â€œprejudiceâ€ inquiry will closely resemble the inquiry
  engaged in by courts reviewing ineffective-assistance challenges to convictions
  obtained through a trial.Â  For example, where the alleged error of counsel is a
  failure to investigate or discover potentially exculpatory evidence, the
  determination whether the error â€œprejudicedâ€ the defendant by causing him to
  plead guilty rather than go to trial will depend on the likelihood that
  discovery of the evidence would have led counsel to change his recommendation
  as to the plea.Â  This assessment, in turn, will depend in large part on a
  prediction whether the evidence likely would have changed the outcome of a
  trial.Â  Similarly, where the alleged error of counsel is a failure to advise
  the defendant of a potential affirmative defense to the crime charged, the
  resolution of the â€œprejudiceâ€ inquiry will depend largely on whether the
  affirmative defense likely would have succeeded at trial.Â  See, e.g., 
		Evans
    v. Meyer, 742 F.2d 371, 375 (CA7 1984) (â€œIt is inconceivable to usâ€¦that
  [the defendant] would have gone to trial on a defense of intoxication, or that
  if he had done so he either would have been acquitted or, if convicted, would
  nevertheless have been given a shorter sentence than he actually receivedâ€).Â 
  As we explained in Strickland v. Washington, supra, these
  predictions of the outcome at a possible trial, where necessary, should be made
  objectively, without regard for the â€œidiosyncrasies of the particular decision
  maker.â€Â  Id., 466 U.S., at 695, 104 S.Ct., at 2068.
	

Hill, 474 U.S. at 58-59 (footnote omitted).
The
  Court of Appeals followed Hill when it engaged in a prejudice analysis
  and found no evidence to support the PCR judgeâ€™s finding that Stalk had met his
  burden.Â  Stalkâ€™s prejudice claim rested on his assertion that his attorney was
  so unprepared that Stalk felt coerced into pleading guilty.Â  We agree with the
  Court of Appeals that to meet his prejudice burden Stalk was required to prove
  more than the fact of counselâ€™s inattentiveness, which is the â€œdeficiency.â€Â 
  For example, Stalk needed to present some evidence that had counsel done an investigation
  he would have found a witness or evidence that was helpful to Stalk, that is,
  something that would have affected counselâ€™s advice to Stalk to accept the plea
  bargain offered or that would have caused Stalk to decline to accept it.Â 
  Although appellate courts frequently â€œshort-handâ€ the prejudice prong in a
  guilty plea ineffective assistance claim as â€œbut for the deficient performance is
  there a reasonable probability that the defendant would not have pleaded guilty
  but would have insisted on going to trial,â€ Hill makes clear that this
  prejudice prong ordinarily requires more than simply a defendantâ€™s assertion
  that but for counselâ€™s deficient performance he would not have pled but would
  have gone to trial.Â  We find no error in this portion of the Court of Appeals decision.
CONCLUSION
The
  decision of the Court of Appeals is
AFFIRMED AS MODIFIED.
TOAL, C.J., WALLER and BEATTY, JJ.,
  concur.Â  KITTREDGE, J., not participating.



[1] Seven counts of second degree burglary, four counts of grand larceny, and one
  count of resisting arrest.

title: Duncan v. Little
description: This direct appeal arises out of an action brought by Appellants Frankey Galloway  and Cleo Galloway against Respondent SunTrust Bank involving its surrender of the contents of two safe deposit boxes.  The Galloway brothers appeal the trial courtâ€™s dismissal of their claims against SunTrust Bank.  We find SunTrust Bank breached a duty owed to Cleo Galloway and reverse.

<!DOCTYPE html PUBLIC "-//W3C//DTD HTML 4.01 Transitional//EN"

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court

	
		
			
				Ann G. Duncan, as Personal Representative of the Estate of
      Frankey Galloway, deceased, and Cleo Galloway, Appellants,
				v.
				Samuel D. Little, personally and as Personal Representative of
      the Estate of Joseph A. Galloway, a/k/a Avery Galloway, deceased; Betty Joy
      L. Iannazzone, personally and as Personal Representative of the Estate of
      Joseph A. Galloway, a/k/a Avery Galloway, deceased; The Estate of Joseph A.
      Galloway, a/k/a Avery Galloway, deceased; and SunTrust Banks, Inc., formerly
      Central Carolina Bank, a/k/a CCB, Defendants, 
				of whom SunTrust Banks, Inc., formerly Central Carolina Bank,
      a/k/a CCB, is Respondent.
			
		
	


Appeal from Pickens County
Â Charles B. Simmons, Jr., Special Referee

Opinion No.Â  26698
Heard April 7, 2009 - Filed August 10,
  2009Â  
AFFIRMED IN PART; REVERSED IN PART; AND
  REMANDED


	
		
			
				Larry
  Brandt, of Walhalla, for Appellants.
				Bernie
  W. Ellis, of McNair Law Firm, of Greenville and Robert L. Widener, of McNair
  Law Firm, of Columbia, for Respondent.
			
		
	


JUSTICE KITTREDGE:Â  This
  direct appeal arises out of an action brought by Appellants Frankey Galloway[1] and Cleo Galloway against Respondent SunTrust Bank involving its surrender of the
  contents of two safe deposit boxes. Â This matter was tried before a Special Referee,
  who dismissed Frankey and Cleo Gallowayâ€™s claims against SunTrust Bank. Â The Galloway brothers appeal the trial courtâ€™s dismissal of their claims against SunTrust
  Bank.Â  We find SunTrust Bank breached a duty owed to Cleo Galloway and reverse.Â  
I.
Factual/Procedural
  Background
In June 2003, Frankey Galloway, aging and paraplegic, was admitted into a nursing home while
  being treated for an illness.Â  Frankey had stored in excess of $250,000 cash
  throughout his home.Â  Away from his home, Frankey was concerned for the safety
  of his money and asked his brother Cleo Galloway to collect the money and store
  it in a safe deposit box.Â  Cleo went to Frankeyâ€™s home, found the cash in the
  locations Frankey described, and took it home where he counted it in the
  presence of his wife and daughter.
The
  precise amount of cash found in Frankeyâ€™s home was $253,843.Â  Frankey confirmed
  to Cleo that the cash found matched his expectation of the stored cash.Â  Cleo
  placed the cash in a safe deposit box at a Wachovia Bank branch in Pickens, South Carolina.Â  
Frankey did not
  approve of the selection of Wachovia Bank and so informed Cleo.Â  Cleo removed
  the cash from the Wachovia safe deposit box.Â  Cleo took the cash to the home of
  Avery, the third Galloway brother, where the two counted it once again.Â  Frankeyâ€™s
  money was taken to SunTrust Bank[2] (the Bank) and placed in two safe deposit boxes.Â  Cleo and Avery were listed on
  the safe deposit box lease agreements as co-lessees and were issued four keys,
  two for each box.
In
  August 2004, Frankey was released from the nursing home and Cleo and Avery gave
  him the keys to the safe deposit boxes.Â  
On
  November 24, 2004, Avery died.Â  In accordance with Averyâ€™s will, his stepson
  Sammy Little (Sammy) and stepdaughter Betty Joy Iannazzone (Joy) were appointed
  personal representatives of his estate.Â  Within a week of Averyâ€™s passing,
  Sammy and Joy went to the Bank to ask if Avery had any accounts.Â  Sharon
  Hamilton, a customer service representative, informed them that Avery and Cleo
  were co-lessees of two safe deposit boxes.Â  Hamilton instructed Sammy and Joy that
  if they wanted to access the boxes, they should get the keys from Cleo.
Sammy
  made no effort to contact Cleo or otherwise obtain the safe deposit box keys.Â  A
  few days later, Sammy informed Hamilton that the keys could not be located.Â 
  Relying on the â€œLost Keysâ€ provision in the lease agreement, Hamilton arranged
  for the boxes to be drilled opened.Â  No notice was given to Cleo.Â  
The safe deposit
  boxes were drilled open on December 1, 2004.Â  Present on December 1 were
  Hamilton, Sammy and Joy.Â  Hamilton presented Sammy and Joy with the Bankâ€™s
  forms entitled: â€œDrilling Certificate of
  Inventory Affidavitâ€ and â€œInventory of Contents of Safe Deposit Box.â€Â  On the
  drilling certificate form, the â€œlessee signatureâ€ line was left blank.Â  On the
  inventory form, Sammy signed as â€œsurviving co-lessee witnessing the qualified
  person making the inventory of the box.â€ Â Sammy
  and Joy left the Bank with the cash from both boxes and absconded with the
  money.Â  
In
  February 2005, Frankey and Cleo went to the Bank to withdraw a portion of Frankeyâ€™s
  cash.Â  Only then did Frankey and Cleo learn that the safe deposit boxes were
  closed and that Sammy and Joy had taken the money.
Frankey
  and Cleo filed a complaint alleging claims against Sammy and Joy[3] as well as claims against the Bank.Â  The parties consented to try the case
  before a Special Referee, who entered an order of judgment denying and
  dismissing Frankey and Cleoâ€™s claims against the Bank.Â  Frankey and Cleo appeal
  the trial courtâ€™s dismissal of their claims.
II.
IssueÂ  

	Did the
  Bank violate a duty to Frankey or Cleo Galloway by releasing the contents to
  Sammy and Joy without notice to Cleo?


III.
Standard of Review
An action to construe a contract is an
  action at law.Â  Pruitt v. S.C. Med. Malpractice Liab. Joint Underwriting Assâ€™n,
  343 S.C. 335, 339, 540 S.E.2d 843, 845 (2001).Â  In resolving this appeal, we
  must construe the lease agreement[4] between Cleo and Avery and the Bank.Â  Where a contract is unambiguous, the
  matter becomes one of law and the partiesâ€™ intent as clearly set forth in their
  agreement must be given effect. Â See McGill v. Moore, 381 S.C.
  179, 185, 672 S.E.2d 571, 574 (2009) (â€œWhere the contractâ€™s language is clear
  and unambiguous, the language alone determines the contractâ€™s force and
  effect.â€).Â  Conversely, where a contract is ambiguous, the fact finder must
  ascertain the partiesâ€™ intentions from the evidence presented.Â  Charles v.
    B&B Theatres, Inc., 234 S.C. 15, 18, 106 S.E.2d 455, 456 (1959)
  (â€œ[W]hen the written contract is ambiguous in its terms . . . parol and other
  extrinsic evidence will be admitted to determine the intent of the parties.â€).Â 
  â€œIn an action at law, tried without a jury, the trial courtâ€™s findings of fact
  will not be disturbed unless found to be without evidence which reasonably
  supports the courtâ€™s findings.â€Â  Stanley v. Atl. Title Ins. Co.,
  377 S.C. 405, 409, 661 S.E.2d 62, 64 (2008).Â  
IV.
Law/Analysis
A.
The
  Bank first argues it breached no duty to Frankey, for Frankey was not a party
  to the safe deposit box lease agreement.Â  We agree and affirm the trial court
  with respect to Frankeyâ€™s claim pursuant to Rule 220(c), SCACR.
B.
Cleo
  asserts the Bank breached a duty owed to him under the lease agreement.Â  The
  Bank counters that the lease agreement grants each co-lessee an absolute right
  of access to the safe deposit box.Â  In this regard, the Bank contends a
  personal representative of a deceased lessee has the right to â€œstand in the
  shoesâ€ of the decedent.Â  The Bankâ€™s position has initial traction based on the
  following general lease provision:

	Co-Lessees
	A
  Box taken in the name of two or more Lessees, as co-Lessees, is under the
  control of each of them as fully as if it stood in each Lesseeâ€™s name alone.Â 
  Either co-Lessee may have access alone, may surrender the Box and terminated
  [sic] the Agreement, may appoint attorneys-in-fact to have access and/or
  surrender the Box, and may cancel any such appointment made by either
  co-Lessee.Â  

The
  lease agreement, however, further provides explicit instructions regarding a
  â€œlost keysâ€ situation:

	Lost
  Keys
	If
  Lessee loses one or both keys to the Box, Lessee shall notify Lessor
  immediately.Â  Lessee shall pay all costs and expenses related to the loss of
  any of the keys to the Box; specifically including, but not limited to, the
  costs incurred in the following:
	i.  If
  Lessee loses one (1) of Lesseeâ€™s keys to the Box, Lessee shall bring the
  remaining key to Lessorâ€™s office or branch where the Box is located so that the
  Box may be opened and the lock changed.
	ii.  If
  Lessee loses all of Lesseeâ€™s keys to the Box, the Box must be forcibly broken
  and/or drilled open and the lock changed in the presence of the Lessee for
  which the Lessee is responsible for all fees and charges associated with the
  drilling.

Significantly,
  the lease agreement specifies that â€œ[a]ll reference to singular shall also mean
  plural.â€Â  When read in conjunction with the â€œlost keysâ€ section, we find that
  the language of the lease agreement requires that all lessees must be present
  when a box is forcibly opened or drilled.Â  
We
  reject the suggestion of an ambiguity.Â  In any event, were we to entertain the
  idea of an ambiguity, such ambiguity would have to be construed against the Bank
  which drafted the agreement.Â  Williams v. Teran, Inc., 266 S.C. 55, 60,
  221 S.E.2d 526, 529 (1976) (noting the rule of contract interpretation that an
  ambiguous contract will be construed against the drafting party); Chassereau v. Global Sun Pools, Inc., 373 S.C. 168, 175, 644 S.E.2d 718, 722 (2007) (â€œ[A] court will construe any doubts and ambiguities in an agreement against
  the drafter of the agreement.â€).
Moreover, an ambiguity would allow resort to the Bankâ€™s own forms,
  which are manifestly at odds with the Bankâ€™s position.Â  For example, the form entitled
  â€œInventory of Contents of Safe Deposit Boxâ€ provides a signature block for a
  â€œsurviving co-lessee.â€Â  That signature block expressly provides that the
  signature of the â€œsurviving co-lesseeâ€ is â€œ[o]nly required if surviving co-lessee
  and the qualified person are not the same person.â€ Â The Bank considered Sammy as the â€œqualified person,â€ yet
  Sammy was permitted to sign as the â€œsurviving co-lessee.â€Â  Cleo, as the surviving
  co-lessee, was entitled to notice and the right to be present at the inventory.
  Â 
We
  agree with the Bank that a personal representative has a right under law to
  â€œstand in the shoesâ€ of the decedent to claim personal property. SeeÂ  S.C.
  Code Ann. Â§Â§ 62-3-709; 62-3-711; 62-3-715 (2009).Â  The more targeted question
  is whether the statutory powers granted to a personal representative permit
  greater powers than the decedent had when living.Â  We answer the question no.Â 
  Section 62-3-711(a) speaks directly to this in providing that â€œa personal
  representative has the same power over the title to property of the estate that
  an absolute owner would have.â€Â  Accordingly, while a personal representative
  stands in the shoes of the decedent, the personal representativeâ€™s shoes are no
  bigger than the decedentâ€™s.Â  Because Avery (as a co-lessee) could not drill the
  safe deposit boxes without Cleo present, neither could Averyâ€™s personal
  representatives.[5]Â  
Lastly, the Bank argues that it is protected by the â€œgood faithâ€
  provision of the probate code.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 62-3-714 (2009) (â€œA person who in good faith either assists a personal
  representative or deals with him for value is protected as if the personal
  representative properly exercised his power.â€).Â  We disagree.Â  Cleoâ€™s direct claim against the Bank is premised on his
  contract with the Bank, not the propriety of the powers exercised by Averyâ€™s
  personal representatives.Â  Because the
  Bank breached the lease agreement, the statutory good faith protection is not
  available.Â  
V.
Conclusion
We affirm the trial courtâ€™s dismissal of Frankey Gallowayâ€™s claim
  against the Bank.Â  We reverse the dismissal of Cleo Gallowayâ€™s claim against
  the Bank and remand to the trial court for a determination of damages.
AFFIRMED IN
  PART; REVERSED IN PART; AND REMANDED.
WALLER,
  ACTING CHIEF JUSTICE, PLEICONES, BEATTY, JJ., and Acting Justice James E.
  Moore, concur.


[1]  Frankey Galloway died during the pendency of this appeal and his personal
  representative, Ann G. Duncan, has been substituted.Â  
[2]  At the time, SunTrust was known as Central Carolina Bank (â€œCCBâ€).
[3]  Frankey
  and Cleoâ€™s lawsuit against Sammy and Joy sought to impose a constructive trust
  upon them for absconding with the cash.Â  The trial court granted the relief and
  in a companion appeal we affirmed the imposition of a constructive trust.Â  Duncan v. Little (Duncan I), Op. No. 09-MO-040 (S.C. Sup. Ct. filed July 20, 2009).
[4]  We note that two safe deposit boxes were leased, but the Bankâ€™s standard
  lease agreement applied to both.Â  Hence our reference to lease agreement in the
  singular. 
[5]  Had Sammy and Joy presented the safe deposit box
  keys along with proof of their appointment as personal representatives of
  Averyâ€™s estate, the lease agreement would have entitled them to access and
  possession of the contents of the safe deposit boxes.

title: State v. Jones
description: In this capital case, Jones appeals his convictions and sentences, alleging the trial judge erred in:  (1) permitting the State to subpoena a witness against Jones who was an expert the defense had engaged to challenge evidence, and (2) admitting "barefoot insole impression" evidence.
text:
