THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court

	
		
			
				The State, Respondent,
				v.
				Jeffrey Louis
      Jones, Appellant.
			
		
	


Appeal From Lexington County
Â  Deadra L. Jefferson, Circuit Court Judge
Opinion No.Â  26699
Heard April 7, 2009 - Filed August 10,
  2009
AFFIRMED IN PART AND REVERSED IN PART


	
		
			
				Chief
  Appellate Defender Joseph L. Savitz, III and Deputy Chief Appellate Defender
  for Capital Appeals Robert M. Dudek, of South Carolina Commission on Indigent
  Defense, Â of Columbia, for Appellant.
				Attorney
  General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney General John W. McIntosh, Assistant
  Deputy Attorney General Donald J. Zelenka, and Senior Assistant Attorney
  General William Edgar Salter, III, of Columbia; and Solicitor Donald V. Myers,
  of Lexington, for Respondent.
			
		
	


JUSTICE
  BEATTY:Â  In this capital case, a jury
  convicted Jeffrey Louis Jones (Jones) of two counts of murder, and one count
  each of first-degree burglary, armed robbery, and criminal conspiracy.Â  After
  the jury recommended the death penalty, the trial judge sentenced Jones to
  death for each murder, thirty years each on first-degree burglary and armed
  robbery, and a consecutive five years for criminal conspiracy.[1]Â  
In
  this direct appeal, Jones alleges the trial judge erred in: Â (1) permitting the
  State to subpoena as a witness against Jones an expert the defense had engaged
  to advise on challenging the admissibility of the Stateâ€™s evidence purportedly
  matching Jonesâ€™s footprint to the insole of a boot alleged to have left a
  bloody print at the crime scene; and (2) admitting â€œbarefoot
  insole impressionâ€ evidence[2] that was consistent with having worn a boot linked to the murder
  scene because it was not scientifically reliable.Â  This case consolidates
  Jonesâ€™s direct appeal and the mandatory review provisions of S.C. Code Ann. Â§
  16-3-25 (2003).Â  Although we affirm as to the first issue, we reverse the trial
  judgeâ€™s decision regarding the second issue.Â  Accordingly, we reverse Jonesâ€™s
  convictions and sentences.


FACTS
On February 2,
  1996, the victims, John Pipkin and Susan Furman, were found dead in their West Columbia home by Pipkinâ€™s stepson, John Orr.Â  According to the autopsy, the victims
  were killed by blunt trauma to the head, consistent with having been beaten
  with a hammer and a piece of brick.Â  An investigation of the crime scene
  revealed that approximately 700 to 1,000 dollars was taken from the home.Â 
  Investigators did not find any physical evidence other than a bloody boot print
  at the scene.
The Stateâ€™s case
  against Jones was primarily based on the testimony of Jonesâ€™s friend, roommate,
  and self-confessed accomplice, James Brown.Â  According to Brown and other
  witnesses, Jones was angry with Pipkin, his employer at the canteen where he
  worked, because Pipkin had deducted an excessive amount from Jonesâ€™s paycheck
  for snacks and drinks consumed on the job.Â  
Brown
  testified that he and Jones planned the robbery of Pipkin.Â  Brown claimed that
  on the way to Pipkinâ€™s residence, Jones gave him a hammer and picked up a
  brick.Â  At the residence, Jones identified himself to Pipkin, who proceeded to
  open the door.Â  Once inside, Jones hit Furman repeatedly in the head with the
  brick while Brown held her arms.Â  According to Brown, he hit Pipkin once with
  the hammer and then gave the hammer to Jones who apparently bludgeoned Pipkin
  to death.Â  
After
  Brown confessed to his participation in the crimes and implicated Jones, he led
  investigators to the hammer used in the murder.Â  
At Jonesâ€™s
  first trial, the State relied on Brownâ€™s testimony and evidence that the
  single, bloody boot print found at the scene was made by â€œsteel toeâ€ boots
  which allegedly belonged to Jones.Â  In support of this theory, the State
  introduced testimony that the â€œbarefoot insole impressionsâ€ left in the â€œsteel
  toeâ€ boots were consistent with the boots having been worn by Jones.
The
  first trial resulted in the jury convicting Jones of two counts of murder, and
  one count each of first-degree burglary, armed robbery, and criminal
  conspiracy.Â  He received two death sentences for the murders, concurrent
  sentences of thirty years each on the burglary and armed robbery charges, and a
  concurrent five-year sentence for conspiracy.Â  
On
  appeal, this Court unanimously found that four errors in the guilt phase of the
  trial each warranted the reversal of Jonesâ€™s convictions and sentences.Â  State
    v. Jones, 343 S.C. 562, 541 S.E.2d 813 (2001).Â  Â Specifically, this Court
  held:Â  (1) the defense was entitled to cross-examine Brown regarding his past
  dealings with the solicitorâ€™s office; (2) â€œbarefoot insole impressionâ€ evidence
  was not scientifically reliable; (3) testimony that Jones was the prime suspect
  in the investigation was not admissible; and (4) the trial court could not
  change the reasonable doubt instruction after defense counselâ€™s closing
  argument.
Prior
  to Jonesâ€™s second trial, the State informed the defense that it intended to
  introduce â€œbarefoot insole impressionâ€ evidence.Â  As a result, defense counsel
  retained as a consultant William Bodziak, a renowned expert on this evidence.Â 
  Although the defense did not intend to call Bodziak as a trial witness, the
  State subpoenaed him to testify at trial.Â  The State also retained Robert
  Kennedy, another expert on â€œbarefoot insole impressionâ€ evidence.Â  Kennedy had
  testified for the State during Jonesâ€™s first trial.
Defense
  counsel filed two pre-trial motions seeking to quash the subpoena of Bodziak
  and suppress the introduction of the â€œbarefoot insole impressionâ€ evidence.Â 
  The trial judge denied both of these motions.
Ultimately,
  the jury convicted Jones of two counts of murder, and one count each of first-degree
  burglary, armed robbery, and criminal conspiracy.Â  Jones appeals his
  convictions and his sentences on two grounds.
DISCUSSION
I.
Jones
  argues the trial judge erred in compelling William Bodziak, a Florida resident
  who was a consultative expert for the defense on â€œbarefoot insole impressionâ€
  evidence, to testify for the State.Â  Because the defense did not list Bodziak
  as a trial witness, Jones contends the Stateâ€™s subpoena to call him as a
  witness violated the work-product doctrine, the attorney-client privilege and,
  more importantly, Jonesâ€™s Sixth Amendment right to the effective assistance of
  counsel.Â  In support of this contention, Jones points out that the State had
  retained its own expert witness, Robert Kennedy, a leading proponent of
  â€œbarefoot insole impressionâ€ evidence.Â  
In contrast, the
  State claims the trial judge did not abuse her discretion in permitting Bodziak
  to testify for the State given:Â  (1) Bodziak only testified during a pre-trial, in camera hearing; (2) Bodziak was not questioned regarding any matters
  protected by the attorney-client privilege or the work-product doctrine; and
  (3) it would be fundamentally unfair to the State for Jones to be allowed to
  challenge the scientific reliability of the â€œbarefoot insole impressionâ€
  evidence while simultaneously withholding non-privileged testimony from one of
  two internationally renowned experts whom the State initially contacted about
  retaining. 
Prior
  to trial, the judge conducted an in camera hearing on Jonesâ€™s motion to
  quash the Stateâ€™s subpoena of Bodziak. Â Defense counsel informed the trial
  judge that after this Court issued its decision in Jones I, the State indicated
  its intention to introduce â€œbarefoot insole impressionâ€ evidence during the
  second trial of Jonesâ€™s case.Â  As a result, defense counsel retained Bodziak as
  a consultant on the evidence.Â  Because the State declined to ship the crime scene
  evidence to Bodziak in Florida, defense counsel arranged for Bodziak to review
  the evidence at the Lexington County Sheriffâ€™s Department.Â  Upon his arrival at
  the Sheriffâ€™s Department, the State served Bodziak with a subpoena to testify

  762 P.2d 478, 485 (Alaska Ct. App. 1988) (finding Bodziak could testify as an
  expert in forensic foot morphology that the running shoes worn by the defendant
  matched the impressions left at the robbery scene based on his comparison of
  the insoles of the running shoes and impressions of the defendantâ€™s feet;
  concluding that forensic foot morphology involves â€œno novel scientific theory
  or techniqueâ€ and stating â€œ[a]lthough the comparison of insole wear patterns
  and foot morphology may be a relatively rare field of expertise, the underlying
  technique of physical comparisons is neither novel nor unacceptedâ€), abrogated
    on other grounds by Matthew v. State, 152 P.3d 469 (Alaska Ct. App.
  2007); United States v. Ferri, 778 F.2d 985 (3rd Cir. 1985) (holding
  trial court did not abuse its discretion in admitting testimony from physical
  anthropologist that shoes found at the crime scene belonged to the defendants
  based on a comparison of the insoles of these shoes with the defendantsâ€™ inked
  footprints); cf. Hurrelbrink v. State, 46 S.W.3d 350 (Tex. Crim.
  App. 2001) (applying Daubert and finding trial court did not abuse its
  discretion in admitting testimony of two anthropologists as to footprint
  comparison and analysis of bloody sock footprint found at the crime scene to
  that of defendantâ€™s footprint despite Kennedyâ€™s contrary testimony for the
  defense); see James T. Watson, Annotation, Admissibility of Expert
    Testimony that Item of Clothing or Footgear Belonged To, or Was Worn By,
    Particular Individual, 71 A.L.R.4th 1148 (1989 & Supp. 2008) (analyzing
  cases in which federal and state courts have addressed the admissibility of
  expert testimony for the purpose of establishing that an item of clothing or
  footgear belonged to, or was worn by, a particular person).
Two
  jurisdictions have rejected this evidence in cases where Kennedy was the
  primary witness for the prosecution.Â  State v. Berry, 546 S.E.2d 145
  (N.C. Ct. App. 2001) (discussing Jones I and finding it was harmless
  error to admit testimony regarding â€œbarefoot insole impressionâ€ evidence;
  concluding â€œbarefoot impression analysisâ€ as presented by Kennedy was not yet a
  reliable science at the time of defendantâ€™s trial); R. v. Dimitrov, 68
  O.R.3d 641 (Ontario Ct. App. 2003) (referencing Jones I, rejecting â€œbarefoot
  insole impressionâ€ evidence presented by Kennedy, and stating â€œ[i]n light of the
  significant issues as to reliability of the evidence, its lack of logical
  relevance and risk of distortion in the fact-finding process, the trial judge
  erred in principle in admitting Sergeant Kennedyâ€™s evidenceâ€). 
Cognizant
  of these cases and our limited standard of review,[7] we find the evidence presented in the instant case does not satisfy the
  requisite reliability factors in Jones.Â  As stated in Jones I,
  these reliability factors take into consideration: Â (1) the publications and
  peer reviews of the technique; (2) prior application of the method to the type
  of evidence involved in the case; (3) the quality control procedures used to
  ensure reliability; and (4) the consistency of the method with recognized
  scientific laws and procedures.Â  Jones I, 343 S.C. at 573, 541 S.E.2d at
  819.
Although
  the research of Kennedy and Bodziak has been presented and published, this does
  not satisfy the requirement of â€œpeer review.â€Â  Significantly, Bodziakâ€™s own
  book, Footwear Impression Evidence, discounts the technique.Â  In Chapter
  13, Bodziak presents an overview of the types of footwear impression evidence.Â 
  In terms of â€œbarefoot insole impressionâ€ evidence, Bodziak concludes:

	There
  have been many previously reported â€œidentificationsâ€ of a suspect as the wearer
  of a shoe.Â  The consensus among experienced examiners is that identifications
  are rare because the random individual characteristics necessary for an
  identification are rarely encountered.Â  Although, in theory, random individual
  characteristics could exist in a foot and be transferred to the shoe or foot
  impression, those characteristics are normally not present nor are they
  retained with the detail necessary to achieve an identification. Â 

In view of this conclusion,
  â€œexperienced examiners,â€ i.e., peer reviewers, have not accepted this
  evidence as reliable.Â  Furthermore, Bodziakâ€™s own testimony casts doubt on the
  reliability of this testing procedure wherein he stated it could not produce
  â€œ100 percent identification.â€Â  
In
  terms of prior application, the testimony revealed that Jonesâ€™s case was one of
  the first cases where this procedure was utilized by SLED.Â  Significantly, the
  procedure is no longer used by SLED or the F.B.I.
Regarding
  the third factor, this Court in Jones I found there was no established
  protocol or quality control procedure in place for Agent Derrickâ€™s testing of
  the evidence.Â  Agent Derrick admitted that he did not conduct any additional
  testing prior to Jonesâ€™s second trial other than to re-examine the evidence
  prior to his trial testimony.Â  
As
  to the consistency of the methodology, Dr. Edwards, a statistician, testified
  that the results from the research conducted by Kennedy and his colleagues were
  a â€œleap of faithâ€ given the random sample used for the research could not be
  applied to the general population.Â  Given the study involved barefoot
  impressions, as opposed to barefoot insole impressions, and â€œthe measurements
  were not made . . . in the same fashion [as barefoot insole impressions],â€
  Edwards concluded the findings in Kennedyâ€™s research would be inapplicable to
  the situation presented in the instant case.
Furthermore,
  we disagree with the trial judgeâ€™s finding that the probative value of this
  evidence outweighed its prejudicial effect under a Rule 403 balancing test.Â 
  Although we agree that â€œbarefoot insole impressionâ€ evidence is outside the
  realm of an average jurorâ€™s knowledge, the potential probative value of the
  evidence is clearly outweighed by the prejudicial impact.Â  As previously
  discussed, we find the evidence is not scientifically reliable.Â  In the absence
  of scientific reliability, the evidence could only operate to provide
  inaccurate and inconclusive information for the jury. 
Admittedly,
  this is a horrific case.Â  However, given the fact that investigators did not
  find any physical evidence at the crime scene other than a bloody boot print, we
  cannot employ a harmless error analysis. Â See State v. Reeves,
  301 S.C. 191, 194, 391 S.E.2d 241, 243 (1990) (â€œError is harmless when it could not reasonably have
  affected the result of the trial.â€). 
CONCLUSION
Based on the foregoing, we affirm the trial judgeâ€™s
  decision denying Jonesâ€™s motion to quash the Stateâ€™s subpoena of Bodziak.Â 
  Under the specific facts of this case, we conclude the Stateâ€™s actions did not
  violate the rights of Jones.Â  However, we reverse the trial judgeâ€™s decision
  denying Jonesâ€™s motion to suppress the admission of â€œbarefoot insole
  impressionâ€ evidence.Â  Because the State did not present any evidence in
  Jonesâ€™s second trial to establish that this procedure is now scientifically
  reliable, we hold the evidence should not have been admitted.Â  Accordingly, we
  reverse Jonesâ€™s convictions and sentences.[8]
AFFIRMED
  IN PART AND REVERSED IN PART.
WALLER,
  ACTING CHIEF JUSTICE, KITTREDGE, J., and Acting Justice James E. Moore,
  concur.Â  PLEICONES, J., concurring in a separate opinion.

JUSTICE PLEICONES:Â  I agree that this case must be reversed because the
  trial judge erred in admitting the â€œbarefoot insole impression evidence.â€Â  In
  light of this reversible error, and the fact that this evidence will not be
  admissible at a future trial,[9] I do not join the majorityâ€™s discussion of the Stateâ€™s right to subpoena the
  â€œexpertâ€ originally retained by the appellant.


[1]Â  This Court reversed Jonesâ€™s original convictions and
  sentence of death in State v. Jones, 343 S.C. 562, 541 S.E.2d 813 (2001)
  (Jones I).
[2]Â Â  In Jones I, this Court described this
  evidence as follows:

	The central thesis of â€œbarefoot insole
  impressionâ€ evidence is that the primary wearer of footwear, over time, begins
  to leave an impression of the wearerâ€™s foot in the footwearâ€™s insole. Â Inked
  impressions of the suspected wearerâ€™s feet, photos of the suspected wearerâ€™s
  known insoles, and a standing cast of the suspected wearerâ€™s foot are compared
  to the impressions in the boots, both visually and by using calipers to compare
  distances between toes and other features among the various exhibits.Â  

Jones I,
  343 S.C. at 572, 541 S.E.2d at 818.
[3] Â William J. Bodziak, Footwear Impression Evidence (2d ed. 2000).
[4] Rule 702 provides:

	If scientific,
  technical, or other specialized knowledge will assist the trier of fact to
  understand the evidence or to determine a fact in issue, a witness qualified as
  an expert by knowledge, skill, experience, training, or education, may testify
  thereto in the form of an opinion or otherwise.

Rule
  702, SCRE. 
[5]Â  In Council, this Court clarified the standard
  governing the admissibility of scientific evidence, stating:

	In considering the admissibility of
  scientific evidence under the Jones standard, the Court looks at several
  factors, including: Â (1) the publications and peer review of the technique; (2)
  prior application of the method to the type of evidence involved in the case;
  (3) the quality control procedures used to ensure reliability; and (4) the
  consistency of the method with recognized scientific laws and procedures.
	. . .
	While this Court does not adopt Daubert,
  we find the proper analysis for determining admissibility of scientific
  evidence is now under the SCRE. Â When admitting scientific evidence under Rule
  702, SCRE, the trial judge must find the evidence will assist the trier of
  fact, the expert witness is qualified, and the underlying science is reliable. Â The
  trial judge should apply the Jones factors to determine reliability. Â Further,
  if the evidence is admissible under Rule 702, SCRE, the trial judge should
  determine if its probative value is outweighed by its prejudicial effect. Â Rule
  403, SCRE. Â Once the evidence is admitted
  under these standards, the jury may give it such weight as it deems
  appropriate.

Council, 335 S.C. at 19-21, 515 S.E.2d at 517-18
  (citing State v. Jones, 273 S.C. 723, 259 S.E.2d 120 (1979)). 
[6] Â Rule 403 provides, â€œ[a]lthough relevant, evidence may be excluded if its probative
  value is substantially outweighed by the danger of unfair prejudice, confusion
  of the issues, or misleading the jury, or by considerations of undue delay,
  waste of time, or needless presentation of cumulative evidence.â€Â  Rule 403, SCRE.
      

[7]Â Â See Council, 335 S.C. at 21, 515 S.E.2d at 518 (recognizing the admission of
  evidence is reviewed on appeal under an abuse of discretion standard).
[8]Â  In view of our decision to reverse Jonesâ€™s
  convictions and sentences, we need not conduct the proportionality review as
  required by section 16-3-25(C) of the South Carolina Code.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§
  16-3-25(C) (2003).Â  
[9] While the possibility that the evidence would be
  admissible was left open in Jones I, that possibility is foreclosed by
  todayâ€™s decision.

title: Moore v. Weinberg
description: The Court affirmed the court of appeals and held that the Petitioner, an attorney, owed a duty to the Respondent by virtue of his role as an escrow agent.
text:
<!DOCTYPE html PUBLIC "-//W3C//DTD HTML 4.01 Transitional//EN"

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court


  
    
      
        Joseph H.
          Moore, Respondent,
        v.
        M.M. Weinberg,
          Jr., and Weinberg and Brown, LLP, Petitioners.
      
    
  


ON WRIT OF CERTIORARI TO THE COURT OF
APPEALS

Appeal from Sumter County
  Â Diane Schafer Goodstein, Circuit Court
Judge

Opinion No.Â  26702
Heard May 27, 2009 - Filed August 12, 2009Â  

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
        Harry
          C. Wilson, Jr. and David C. Holler, of Lee, Erter, Wilson, James, Holler &
          Smith, of Sumter, for Petitioners.
        A.
          Camden Lewis, Peter D. Protopapas and Brady R. Thomas, of Lewis & Babcock, of
          Columbia, for Respondent.
      
    
  


CHIEF JUSTICE TOAL:Â  Respondent Joseph H. Moore filed suit against Petitioners M.M. Weinberg, Jr. and Weinberg
  and Brown, LLP after Petitioners disbursed
  funds in which Moore claimed an interest.Â  The trial court granted Petitionersâ€™
  motion for summary judgment.Â  The court of appeals affirmed in part, reversed
  in part, and remanded.Â  Moore v. Weinberg, 373 S.C. 209, 644 S.E.2d 740
  (Ct. App. 2007).Â  This Court granted a writ of certiorari to review that
decision.Â  We affirm.
FACTUAL/PROCEDURAL BACKGROUND
Respondent Moore and Clarence Wheeler
  began a business relationship in the 1980s.Â  Over the course of their relationship,
  the two men entered into numerous loan agreements, and in November 1999,
  Wheeler approached Moore seeking to borrow money.Â  Wheeler informed Moore that
  he was currently the plaintiff in a lawsuit which involved the sale of his
  music business and that Petitioner Weinberg was representing him in the matter.Â 
  Weinberg had been Wheelerâ€™s attorney for approximately 30 years and had
  represented him in numerous matters, in addition to the music business matter. Â Wheeler
  further informed Moore that $100,000 had been deposited in an escrow account with
  the clerk of court pending the resolution of the litigation and proposed using
  the escrow funds as security for the loan. Â Moore then spoke with Weinberg regarding
  the escrow account and the proposed loan agreement.Â  After Weinberg assured
  Moore that the escrow account did in fact contain $100,000 and was pending upon
  the resolution of the litigation, Moore agreed to loan Wheeler $80,000. Â Wheeler
  executed a note to Moore for $92,000, which included a $12,000 built-in
  premium.Â  Weinberg then prepared an assignment securing the note which provided
  that: 

  Clarence
    Wheeler does by this instrument assign to Joseph Moore so much of any recovery
    that he may make from the debt owed to him by [the music business] and the escrow
    account, which is pending as a result of said litigation, unto Joseph Moore.Â  

In 2002, Weinberg
  settled the music business litigation on behalf of Wheeler for $100,000.[1]Â 
  After the clerk transferred the funds from the escrow account to Weinberg, Weinberg
  failed to remember that the escrow funds had been assigned to Moore and
  immediately disbursed $72,458 of the funds to Wheeler and retained $25,000 for
  attorneyâ€™s fees.Â  While Moore was out of town, Wheeler tendered $50,000 to Mooreâ€™s
  son for payment of the debt.[2]Â 
  Moore later informed Wheeler the $50,000 payment did not fully satisfy the
  note.Â  Accordingly, they signed a handwritten agreement on the bottom of the
  note, which provided:

  I, Clarence
    Wheeler, agree that I owe Joseph H. Moore $80,000 since March 17, 2000 and
    agree to pay him 6% interest on the $80,000 balance.Â  Clarence Wheeler paid
    $50,000 on June 19, 2002.

Wheeler failed to pay Moore
  in accordance with the new agreement.Â  
Moore
  filed claims against Weinberg for negligence, conversion, and civil
  conspiracy.Â  The trial court granted summary judgment in favor of Weinberg
  because Moore and Weinberg did not have a â€œlegal relationshipâ€ and because it
  found that the subsequent handwritten agreement contained on the note
  constituted a novation.Â  The court of appeals held that the trial court erred
  in granting summary judgment on the negligence claim because there was evidence
  that Weinberg owed a duty to Moore.Â  Additionally, the court held the defense
  of novation was not applicable in this tort action because novation is a
  defense sounding in contract.Â  Finally, the court of appeals held the trial
  court erred in granting summary judgment on Mooreâ€™s conversion claim because
  Moore had a valid assignment to a portion of the escrow account and Weinberg
  was on notice of the assignment.
This
  Court granted a writ of certiorari to review the following issue:

  Did the
    court of appeals err in holding that an attorney may be liable to a third party
    for disbursing funds to the attorneyâ€™s client where the attorney was aware that
    the funds were assigned to the third party?

STANDARD OF REVIEW
Summary
  judgment is appropriate where there is no genuine issue of material fact and
  it is clear the moving party is entitled to a judgment as a matter of law. Â Rule
  56(c), SCRCP.Â  In determining whether any triable issues of fact exist, the
  evidence and all inferences which can be reasonably drawn from the evidence
  must be viewed in the light most favorable to the nonmoving party. Â Koester
    v. Carolina Rental Ctr., 313 S.C. 490, 493, 443 S.E.2d 392, 394 (1994).Â  
LAW/ANALYSIS
I. Negligence
Weinberg
  argues that the court of appeals erred in
  reversing the trial courtâ€™s grant of summary judgment on the negligence claim.Â 
  We disagree.
In a negligence action, a plaintiff must show that (1) the
  defendant owes a duty of care to the plaintiff, (2) the defendant breached the
  duty by a negligent act or omission, (3) the defendantâ€™s breach was the actual
  and proximate cause of the plaintiffâ€™s injury, and (4) the plaintiff suffered
  an injury or damages.Â  Madison ex rel. Bryant v. Babcock
    Ctr., Inc., 371 S.C. 123, 136, 638 S.E.2d
  650, 656 (2006).Â  
Weinberg
  contends that allowing a cause of action against an attorney under these
  circumstances will intrude upon the attorney/client relationship and greatly
  hinder an attorneyâ€™s ability to represent his client.Â  In our view, Weinbergâ€™s
  argument misses the mark.Â  Weinberg acted as the escrow agent and owed a fiduciary duty to Moore by virtue
  of this role.Â  Therefore, it makes no difference that Weinberg was Wheelerâ€™s
  lawyer and represented him in other matters.Â  Under the facts of
  this case, the duty arises from an attorneyâ€™s role as an escrow agent and is
  independent of an attorneyâ€™s status as a lawyer and distinct from duties that
  arise out of the attorney/client relationship.Â  
Furthermore,
  we hold that Moore presented evidence that Weinbergâ€™s performance fell below
  the standard of care.Â  In addition to submitting an affidavit from an attorney
  stating that Weinberg breached the standard of care, Weinberg essentially admitted that he was negligent in failing
  to disburse the funds in accordance with the agreement by testifying that he
  simply overlooked the terms of the agreement.Â  
Accordingly, we hold that the trial court erred in granting
  Weinbergâ€™s motion for summary judgment on the negligence claim.
II. Conversion
Weinberg argues that the court of appeals erred in
  reversing the trial courtâ€™s grant of summary judgment on the conversion claim.Â 
  We disagree.
Conversion is defined as the unauthorized assumption and exercise
  of the right of ownership over goods or personal chattels belonging to another
  to the exclusion of the ownerâ€™s rights.Â  SSI Med.
    Servs., Inc. v. Cox, 301 S.C. 493, 498, 392 S.E.2d
  789, 792 (1990).Â  Money may be the subject of
  conversion when it is capable of being identified and there may be conversion
  of determinate sums even though the specific coins and bills are not
  identified.Â  Id.
Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  Moore
  alleged in the complaint that he owned an interest in the proceeds from the
  litigation pursuant to the assignment, that Weinberg was aware of his interest
  in the proceeds, and that Weinberg wrongfully disbursed those proceeds.Â 
  Viewing the evidence in a light most favorable to Moore, a genuine issue of
  material fact exists as to the conversion claim, and the court of appeals
  therefore correctly reversed the trial courtâ€™s grant of summary judgment.Â  

CONCLUSION
For the
  foregoing reasons, we affirm the court of appealsâ€™ decision and hold that the
  trial erred in granting Weinbergâ€™s motion for summary judgment on the
  negligence claim and conversion claim.Â  
WALLER,
  BEATTY, JJ., and Acting Justices James E. Moore and Dorothy Mobley Jones,
  concur.


[1] At the time of the settlement, the escrow account had earned $10,829 in
  interest.Â  The settlement agreement provided that Wheeler would retain
  $100,000, while the defendants would retain the $10,829 earned in interest.
[2] Wheeler testified that he mistakenly believed that he owed $50,000 on the debt.

title: Sundown Operating v. Intedge Industries
description: In this case, the court of appeals held that Petitioner failed to show good cause sufficient to overcome the entry of default pursuant to Rule 55(c), SCRCP.  We affirm.

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court

	
		
			
				Sundown
      Operating Company, Inc., a South Carolina Corporation; Sunrise Coin Company,
      Inc., a South Carolina Corporation; and High Noon Properties, Inc., a South
      Carolina Corporation; Respondents,
				v.
				Intedge
      Industries, Inc., a New Jersey Corporation; Quickie Food Stores of North Myrtle
      Beach, Inc., d/b/a Hardwickâ€™s Bar & Restaurant Supplies, a South Carolina
      Corporation; BFPE International, Inc., f/k/a Atlantic Fire Systems, Inc., a
      Maryland Corporation; Wormald Fire Systems, Inc., f/k/a Ansul Fire Systems,
      Inc., a Delaware Corporation; and Ansul Incorporated, a Delaware Corporation, Defendants,
				of whom BFPE
      International, Inc., f/k/a Atlantic Fire Systems, Inc., a Maryland
      Corporation is Petitioner.
			
		
	


ON WRIT OF CERTIORARI TO THE COURT OF
  APPEALS

Appeal from Horry County
Â Steven H. John, Circuit Court Judge
Â J. Stanton Cross, Jr., Circuit Court
  Judge
Opinion No. 26700
Heard February 5, 2009 - Filed August 17,
  2009Â Â  
AFFIRMED


	
		
			
				Eugene
  Matthews, of Richardson, Plowden & Robinson, of Columbia, and Michael S.
  Hopewell, of Turner, Padget, Graham & Laney, of Florence, for Petitioner.
				Daniel
  F. Blanchard, III, of Rosen, Rosen and Hagood, of Charleston, Peter F. Asmer,
  Jr., of Cozen Oâ€™Connor, of Charlotte, and Susan C. Rosen, of Rosen Law Firm, of
  Charleston, for Respondents.
			
		
	


CHIEF JUSTICE TOAL:Â  This
  action for negligence and breach of contract arises out of a fire that burned
  down a restaurant and pub owned by Respondents Sundown Operating Company, Inc.
  (â€œSundownâ€), Sunrise Coin Company, Inc. (â€œSunriseâ€), and High Noon Properties,
  Inc. (â€œHigh Noonâ€) (hereinafter referred to collectively as â€œRespondentsâ€).Â  Respondents
  filed suit against Defendant BFPE International, Inc. (â€œPetitionerâ€) and four
  other defendants (hereinafter referred to collectively as â€œDefendantsâ€).Â  The
  trial court granted a default judgment against Petitioner, and following a
  damages hearing, the master-in-equity awarded damages to Respondents.Â  Both
  parties appealed.Â  The court of appeals affirmed the trial court.Â  Sundown
    Operating Co. v. Intedge Indus., Inc., Op. No. 2007-UP-091 (S.C. Ct. App. filed Feb. 23, 2007).Â  We granted in part Petitionerâ€™s request for a writ of
  certiorari to review that opinion.Â  Â 
Factual/Procedural
  Background
On September 16,
  1998, Respondentsâ€™ restaurant and pub burned down.Â  On August 24, 2001, Respondents
  filed suit against Defendants, alleging that an electric fryer had
  malfunctioned and ignited a quantity of frying oil.Â  Respondents had a service
  contract with Petitioner to install, maintain, inspect, and service the
  restaurantâ€™s fire extinguishing and suppression systems.Â  Respondents asserted
  claims for negligence and breach of contract against Petitioner, on the grounds
  that Petitioner failed to properly maintain and inspect the fire suppression
  system.Â  
Petitioner is
  incorporated in Maryland and has various business locations in Maryland, Virginia, North Carolina, and South Carolina.Â  At the time of the lawsuit, Petitioner
  did not have a registered agent listed with the South Carolina Secretary of
  State.Â  
On August 27, 2001,
  Respondents mailed copies of the summons and complaint to Donald R. Leonard,
  who was Petitionerâ€™s registered agent in Maryland and North Carolina at the
  time, at two separate addresses in Myrtle Beach and Rocky Mount, North Carolina.Â  In Myrtle Beach, Petitionerâ€™s manager, Randy Adams, received the package
  and was advised by the mail carrier that he could sign for Leonard, who was
  absent.Â  Adams signed Leonardâ€™s name to the receipt, which was dated and
  returned to Respondents on August 28, 2001.Â  In Rocky Mount, Leonard himself
  signed the return receipt on September 4, 2001.Â  
On September 5,
  2001, Leonard gave the summons and complaint to the general manager of Petitionerâ€™s
  Clayton, North Carolina office, who then forwarded the papers to Petitionerâ€™s
  vice-president.Â  On or about September 14, 2001, Petitionerâ€™s vice-president
  notified Petitionerâ€™s insurance agent of the lawsuit.Â  On October 1, 2001, the
  vice-president forwarded the summons and complaint to the insurance agent.Â  On
  October 2, 2001, the insurance agent telephoned Respondentsâ€™ counsel to request
  an extension of time to file an answer to the complaint.Â  Respondentsâ€™ counsel
  informed the agent that he had already moved for an entry of default based upon
  the August 28, 2001 service date.Â  On October 2, 2001, the Horry County Clerk
  of Court filed the entry of default.Â  
On October 18,
  2001, Petitioner filed a motion to set aside default and permit enlargement of
  time.Â  On October 29, 2001, Respondents filed a motion for a default judgment. Â On
  December 10, 2001, Respondents moved for, and the Horry County Clerk of Court
  filed, a second entry of default based upon the September 4, 2001 service
  date.Â  
On March 18, 2002,
  the trial court conducted a hearing and found that Petitioner had shown good
  cause to set aside the entry of default and permit an enlargement of time to
  file an answer and instructed the company to submit a proposed order.Â  The
  trial court based its ruling in part on the recent court of appeals decision in Pilgrim v. Miller, 2002 WL 44112 (S.C. Ct. App. Jan. 14, 2002) (Pilgrim
    I).Â  The next day, Respondentsâ€™ counsel requested that the trial court
  delay its formal order in light of the Court of Appealsâ€™ decision to rehear Pilgrim
    I.Â  The trial court agreed.Â  On June 17, 2002, the court of appeals
  reversed its original opinion in Pilgrim I.[1]Â  Pilgrim v. Miller, 350 S.C. 637, 567 S.E.2d 527 (Ct. App. 2002) (Pilgrim
    II).Â  
On July 18, 2002,
  the trial court again heard Petitionerâ€™s motion to set aside the entry of default.Â 
  The trial court issued an order finding the August 28, 2001 service date to be
  invalid, but held that Petitioner was not entitled to set aside the entry of default
  with regard to the September 4, 2001 service date.Â  
The case was then referred
  to the master-in-equity for a hearing to assess damages.Â  The master entered
  judgment in the amount of: $273,336.00 in actual damages to Sunrise;
  $394,848.38 in actual damages to Sundown; and $524,800.70 in actual damages to
  High Noon.Â  The master denied Respondentsâ€™ requests for prejudgment interest.Â  
The parties filed
  cross-appeals.Â  The court of appeals held that Respondents were properly denied
  prejudgment interest; that both the August 28, 2001 and September 4, 2001
  service dates were valid; and that the trial court did not err in failing to
  set aside the entry of default.Â  Both parties filed petitions for a writ of
  certiorari with this Court.Â  We denied Respondentsâ€™ petition and granted in
  part Petitionerâ€™s petition.Â  Petitioner presents the following question for our
  review:
Did the
  court of appeals err in failing to set aside the entry of default?
Standard
  of Review
The decision whether to set aside an entry of default
  or a default judgment lies solely within the sound discretion of the trial
  judge.Â  Harbor Island Ownersâ€™ Assâ€™n v. Preferred Island Props., Inc.,
  369 S.C. 540, 544, 633 S.E.2d 497, 499 (2006).Â  The trial courtâ€™s decision will
  not be disturbed on appeal absent a clear showing of an abuse of that
  discretion. Â Mitchell Supply Co., Inc. v. Gaffney, 297 S.C. 160, 162-63,
  375 S.E.2d 321, 322-23 (Ct. App. 1988). Â An abuse of discretion occurs when the
  judge issuing the order was controlled by some error of law or when the order,
  based upon factual, as distinguished from legal conclusions, is without
  evidentiary support. Â In re Estate of Weeks, 329 S.C. 251, 259, 495
  S.E.2d 454, 459 (Ct. App. 1997).

Law/Analysis
Petitioner contends
  that it has shown good cause under the minimal standard required by Rule 55(c), SCRCP, and that the trial court and the court of appeals erred in applying a
  heightened standard to conclude that the company was not entitled to set aside
  the entry of default.Â  Although we have some concerns about the lower courtsâ€™ conflation
  of the Rule 60(b) and Rule 55(c) standards, we do not believe Petitioner meets
  even the most minimal showing of good cause, and is therefore not entitled to
  relief from the entry of default.Â Â Â  
I.Â  Differentiating the
  Standards for Relief Under Rule 55(c) and Rule 60(b)
We must acknowledge at the outset that there has been some recent
  confusion in the case law regarding the application of the standards for relief
  set forth in Rule 55(c) and Rule 60(b).Â  We take this opportunity to reassert
  the basic legal premise that the standard for granting relief under Rule 60(b)
  is more rigorous than under Rule 55(c), and that an entry of default may be set
  aside for reasons that would be insufficient to relieve a party from a default
  judgment.
Rule 55(a) provides that when a party fails to respond to a complaint,
  the clerk shall record an entry of default.Â  However, Rule 55(c) permits a
  party to move to set aside the entry of default. Â The standard for granting
  relief from an entry of default under Rule 55(c) is mere â€œgood cause.â€ Â Rule 55(c), SCRCP.Â  This
  standard requires a party seeking relief from an entry of default under Rule
  55(c) to provide an explanation for the default and give reasons why vacation
  of the default entry would serve the interests of justice.Â  Once a party has
  put forth a satisfactory explanation for the default, the trial court must also
  consider: (1) the timing of the motion for relief; (2) whether
  the defendant has a meritorious defense; and (3) the degree of prejudice to the
  plaintiff if relief is granted. Â Wham v. Shearson Lehman Bros., Inc.,
  298 S.C. 462, 465, 381 S.E.2d 499, 501-02 (Ct. App. 1989). Â The trial court
  need not make specific findings of fact for each factor if there is sufficient
  evidentiary support on the record for the finding of the lack of good cause.Â  Dixon v. Besco Engineering, Inc., 320 S.C. 174, 179, 463 S.E. 2d 636, 639
  (Ct. App. 1995).Â  A motion under Rule 55(c) is addressed to the sound
  discretion of the trial court. Â Williams v. Stalnaker, 312 S.C. 373,
  375, 440 S.E.2d 408, 409 (Ct. App. 1994).Â  Â 
Once a default judgment has been entered, a party seeking to be
  relieved must do so under Rule 60(b), SCRCP.Â  The standard for granting relief
  from a default judgment under Rule 60(b) is more rigorous than the â€œgood causeâ€
  standard established in Rule 55(c).Â  Ricks v. Weinrauch, 293 S.C. 372,
  374, 360 S.E.2d 535, 536 (Ct. App. 1987).Â  Rule 60(b) requires a more
  particularized showing of mistake, inadvertence, excusable neglect, surprise,
  newly discovered evidence, fraud, misrepresentation, or â€œother misconduct of an
  adverse party.â€Â  Rule 60(b), SCRCP.Â  The different standards under the two
  rules underscore the clear intent to make it more difficult for a party to
  avoid a default once the court has entered a judgment, which carries greater
  finality, and often occurs later than, a clerkâ€™s entry of default.Â  
It is often observed, as the court of appeals held in the present case,
  that the criteria for obtaining relief from judgment under Rule 60(b) -
  mistake, inadvertence, excusable neglect, surprise, newly discovered evidence,
  fraud, misrepresentation - are relevant in determining whether good cause has
  been shown under Rule 55(c), SCRCP. Â See New Hampshire Ins. Co. v. Bey Corp.,
  312 S.C. 47, 50, 435 S.E.2d 377, 378-79 (Ct. App. 1993) (holding that, â€œas a
  practical matter,â€ the 60(b) factors are relevant under both rules).Â  However,
  we caution that this language invites trial courts to apply a heightened
  standard to Rule 55(c) motions.Â  The Rule 60(b) factors are indeed relevant to
  a Rule 55(c) analysis, but only insomuch as proof of any one of these factors
  is sufficient to show â€œgood cause.â€Â  No trial court should ever find good cause
  lacking based solely on the absence of a Rule 60(b) factor.Â  
II.Â  The
  Merits of Petitionerâ€™s Appeal
Petitioner
  argues that the trial judge should have set aside the entry of default because the
  company showed â€œgood causeâ€ by asserting its insurance agent was negligent for
  failing to answer the complaint and because (1) it promptly moved for relief;
  (2) it has a meritorious defense; and (3) Respondents would suffer no prejudice
  if the court set aside the entry of default.Â  We disagree.Â  
Initially,
  we reject Petitionerâ€™s argument that it should be granted relief from the entry
  of default because it should not be held responsible for the negligence of its
  insurance agent in failing to answer the complaint.Â  This argument is without
  merit, as the law is clear that an attorney or insurance companyâ€™s misconduct
  is imputable to the client.Â  See Williams v. Vanvolkenburg, 312 S.C.
  373, 375, 440 S.E.2d 408, 409 (Ct. App. 1994) (observing that an attorneyâ€™s
  negligence in failing to answer is imputable to the defendant); Roberts v.
    Peterson, 292 S.C. 149, 151, 355 S.E.2d 280, 281 (Ct. App. 1987) (recognizing
  that negligence of an attorney or insurance company is imputable to a
  defaulting litigant).Â  Although the presence of other factors, in the totality
  of the circumstances, may amount to a showing of â€œgood cause,â€ a defendant may
  not be relieved from the entry of default solely because it relied to
  its detriment on a negligent insurance agent.Â  See Ricks, 293 S.C. 372,
  360 S.E.2d 535 (holding that good cause was shown in the totality of
  circumstances involving misplaced reliance on insurance agent).Â  
In
  this case, Petitioner shares the responsibility for the entry of default with
  its insurance agent.Â  Petitioner did not forward the summons and complaint to
  the insurance agent until approximately two weeks after initially notifying the
  agent of the lawsuit and several days after the time to answer expired.Â 
  Furthermore, Petitionerâ€™s â€œgood causeâ€ argument is based entirely upon the
  September 4, 2001 service date.Â  Petitioner has put forth no explanation with
  regard to the fate of the summons and complaint served on Randy Adams on August
  28, 2001.Â  As the court of appeals correctly held, this service was proper
  pursuant to Roche v. Young Bros., Inc. of Florence, 318 S.C. 207, 456
  S.E.2d 897 (1995).[2]Â 
  Even if we were to assume that Petitioner showed good cause as to why the
  summons and complaint that arrived in Rocky Mount was not answered in a timely
  manner, we must nevertheless affirm the entry of default because Petitioner has
  failed to show good cause as to why the summons and complaint that arrived in Myrtle Beach went unanswered. 
Conclusion
For the reasons
  stated herein, we affirm the opinion of the court of appeals.Â  
WALLER, PLEICONES, JJ., and Acting Justices R. Knox McMahon and E.
  C. Burnett, III, concur.


[1] Although the Pilgrim II opinion was vacated by this Court on April 25,
  2003, the court of appeals in the instant case observed that the portions
  relied upon by the trial judge are â€œstill good law.â€Â  See Bage v. Southeastern
    Roofing Co., S.C. Sup. Ct. Order dated July 23, 2009 (Shearouse Adv. Sh.
  No. 33 at 82) (discussing vacation of Pilgrim II opinion).Â  
[2] We declined to grant certiorari as to this particular question.

title: Lane v. Gilbert Construction
description: In this premises liability action the Court affirmed the trial court's granting of a motion for a new trial absolute.

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court

	
		
			
				Ronnie Lane, Respondent,
				v.
				Gilbert
      Construction Company, LTD., Appellant.
			
		
	


Appeal from Florence County
Thomas A. Russo, Circuit Court Judge
Opinion No.Â Â  26701
Heard May 12, 2009 - Filed August 17, 2009 
AFFIRMED


	
		
			
				Everett A. Kendall, II, of Sweeny, Wingate & Barrow, of
  Columbia, for Appellant.
				D.
  Kenneth Baker, of Darlington, James H. Moss and
				H.
  Fred Kuhn, Jr., both of Moss, Kuhn & Fleming,Â  of Beaufort, for Respondent.
			
		
	


JUSTICE
  PLEICONES:Â  In this premises liability action, a jury found for Respondent Ronnie Lane (Lane) in the amount of $75,000.Â  The trial court then granted Laneâ€™s
  motion for a new trial absolute, which ruling Gilbert now challenges on appeal.Â  We affirm.
FACTS
Appellant
  Gilbert Construction Company LTD (Gilbert) entered into an agreement to
  renovate McLeod Regional Medical Center (Hospital).Â  The renovation included
  work on a courtyard, accessible by an emergency exit from the building.Â  The
  superintendent of Gilbert testified that during the demolition/foundation phase
  of the project six holes for footings were created on the site, including one
  in the courtyard.Â  A number of the holes were covered, but Gilbert decided not
  to cover the hole in the courtyard.Â  The superintendent explained that he
  believed that the area was cordoned off.
Sometime
  between 2:30 and 3:30 a.m. Lane, an HVAC mechanic at the Hospital working the
  â€œgraveyard shift,â€ responded to the latest in a series of false fire alarms.Â  Lane
  testified that each time the alarm was activated the alarm system automatically
  alerted the fire department.Â  Since the fire department had previously
  responded to false alarms twice during Laneâ€™s shift that night, he decided to
  walk down to tell the switchboard operator to put the system in â€œtest modeâ€ so
  that it would not automatically alert the fire department.
Lane
  knocked on the door to the switchboard room and, receiving no answer, chose to
  walk out of the emergency exit and into the courtyard in order to reach another
  door to the security and switchboard area.Â  The emergency exit door was
  slightly ajar and when Lane opened it he saw â€œcaution tapeâ€ hanging down on the
  side of the door.Â  He then stepped out into what he described as â€œpitch black
  darkâ€ and fell into the hole, breaking his ankle.
Lane
  underwent a number of surgeries to repair his ankle and missed weeks of work.Â 
  All told, Laneâ€™s medical care related to the ankle injury totaled $73,754.Â  On
  cross examination, Lane admitted that he returned to work in his previous
  capacity as an HVAC mechanic in between his surgeries, though in sedentary
  work.Â  Following his last surgery, he was assigned to a new job as a computer
  operator.Â  In his new job, Lane works at a desk in shifts from 7:00 a.m. until
  3:30 p.m., rather than the â€œgraveyardâ€ shift he worked as an HVAC mechanic.
An
  expert for Lane conducted a vocational assessment and determined that Lane was
  not capable of performing the job that he had prior to the injury.Â  She further
  opined that Lane would only be eligible for minimum wage positions if he were
  to lose the position he currently has.
The
  jury found Lane 45% at fault and Gilbert 55% at fault and awarded $75,000 in
  actual damages.Â  Lane moved for a new trial absolute which the court granted.

	ISSUES
	I.    Did the trial court err in denying
  Gilbertâ€™s motion for a directed verdict?
	II.   Did the trial
  court err in granting a new trial?
	III.  Did the trial courtâ€™s order
  granting a new trial deprive Gilbert of its right to trial by jury?

DISCUSSION
I. Did the trial court err in denying Gilbertâ€™s motion
  for directed verdict?
Gilbert
  contends that the evidence does not support classification of Lane as an
  invitee and instead only supports classification as a licensee or trespasser.Â 
  Furthermore, Gilbert argues that there is no evidence to show a breach of the
  landownerâ€™s duty to a licensee or trespasser and therefore, Gilbert is entitled
  to a directed verdict.Â  We disagree.
â€œA
  motion for directed verdict goes to the entire case and may be granted only
  when the evidence raises no issue for the jury as to liability.â€ Ecclesiastes
    Production Ministries v. Outparcel Assoc., LLC, 374 S.C. 483, 490, 649
  S.E.2d 494, 497 (Ct. App. 2007), citing Carolina Home Builders, Inc.
    v. Armstrong Furnace Co., 259 S.C. 346, 358, 191 S.E.2d 774, 779 (1972).Â  
â€œUnder
  a premises liability theory, a contractor generally equates to an invitor and
  assumes the same duties that the landowner has, including the duty to warn of
  dangers or defects known to him but unknown to others.â€ Larimore v. Carolina Power & Light, 340 S.C. 438, 448, 531 S.E.2d 535, 540 (Ct. App. 2000).
The
  trial court classified Lane as an â€œinvitee.â€Â  An invitee is a person â€œwho
  enters onto the property of another by express or implied invitation, his entry
  is connected with the ownerâ€™s business or with an activity the owner conducts
  or permits to be conducted on his land, and there is a mutuality of benefit or
  a benefit to the owner.â€ Singleton v. Sherer, 377 S.C. 185, 199, 659
  S.E.2d 196, 204 (Ct. App. 2008), quoting Sims v. Giles, 343 S.C.
  708, 716-17, 541 S.E.2d 857, 862 (Ct. App. 2001).Â  
Gilbert
  contends that Lane was not an invitee because he had no consent, either express
  or implied, to be in the courtyard and because his presence in the courtyard
  was not to the interest or advantage of Gilbert.Â  We find that there was at
  least implied consent to use the area since it was immediately outside of an
  emergency exit.Â  Moreover, Lane was at least partly benefiting Gilbert by
  attempting to have the switchboard disable the automatic alert to the fire
  department.Â  Lane testified that the fire alarm repeatedly sounded during his
  shift.Â  Each time the alarm sounded, the alarm system automatically notified
  the fire department.Â  By instructing the switchboard to place the system in
  â€œtestâ€ mode, Lane could ensure that the business of both the Hospital and
  Gilbert would not be repeatedly interrupted by the sounding of the alarm,
  unnecessary evacuations, and arrival of fire department personnel.
Moreover,
  even if Lane did not provide a benefit to Gilbert, Gilbert would not be
  entitled to a directed verdict if Lane were classified as a licensee.
â€œA
  licensee is a person who is privileged to enter upon land by virtue of the
  possessorâ€™s consent.â€ Neil v. Byrum, 288 S.C. 472, 473, 343 S.E.2d 615,
  616 (1986).Â  â€œWhen a licensee enters onto the property of another, the primary
  benefit is to the licensee, not the property owner.â€ Singleton, 377 S.C.
  at 198, 659 S.E.2d at 203.
â€œA
  landowner owes a licensee a duty to use reasonable care to discover the
  licensee, to conduct activities on the land so as not to harm the licensee, and
  to warn the licensee of any concealed dangerous conditions or activities.â€Â  Singleton,
  377 S.C. at 201, 659 S.E.2d at 204.Â  In our view, the evidence presented at
  trial raised a jury question as to whether or not Gilbert met the duty owed to
  Lane as a licensee.Â  Therefore, even assuming Lane was a licensee, the trial
  judge did not err in denying the motion for a directed verdict.Â  See Ecclesiastes
    Production Ministries, supra.
We
  find that the trial court properly classified Lane as an invitee.Â  Moreover,
  even assuming Lane is not an invitee, Gilbert would not be entitled to a
  directed verdict.Â  Consequently, the trial judge did not err in denying
  Gilbertâ€™s motion for a directed verdict.
II. Did the trial court
  err in granting a new trial?
Gilbert
  argues that the trial court erred in granting Lane a new trial.Â  We disagree.
In South Carolina, a trial judge may grant a new trial following a jury verdict under the
  Thirteenth Juror Doctrine.Â  The doctrine â€œentitles the judge to sit, in
  essence, as the thirteenth juror when he finds â€˜the evidence does not justify
  the verdict,â€™ and then to grant a new trial based solely â€˜upon the facts.â€™â€ Norton
    v. Norfolk Southern Railway Co., 350 S.C. 473, 478, 567 S.E.2d 851, 854
  (2002), citing Folkens v. Hunt, 300 S.C. 251, 387 S.E.2d 265
  (1990).Â  As the thirteenth juror, the trial judge can hang the jury by refusing
  to agree to the juryâ€™s otherwise unanimous verdict. Id.
Upon
  review, a trial judgeâ€™s order granting or denying a new trial will be upheld
  unless the order is wholly unsupported by the evidence, or the conclusion
  reached was controlled by an error of law. Norton, 350 S.C. at 478, 567
  S.E.2d at 854.Â  This Courtâ€™s review is limited to consideration of whether
  evidence exists to support the trial courtâ€™s order. Id. at 478-79, 567
  S.E.2d at 854.Â  As long as there is conflicting evidence, this Court has held
  the trial judgeâ€™s grant of a new trial will not be disturbed. Id.
The
  judge is not required to explain the reasons for his decision. Id.Â  In this case, however, the trial judge provided an explanation in the order
  granting the motion for a new trial.Â  The court noted that Lane presented
  evidence at trial, which was â€œuncontested by the defendant,â€ of actual medical
  costs of $73,754, lost wages from the date of injury up until the time of trial
  of $17,248, and a 21% permanent impairment rating. Â The court also noted that
  the jury heard testimony from two experts opining that Lane suffered a loss of
  personal services to his family equivalent to $19,381, such as household
  chores, and is unable to perform the duties required by his prior job as an
  HVAC mechanic.Â  The court concluded:

	[A]fter careful review of all of the facts and
  circumstances of this case and other cases in the state of South Carolina, this
  Court believes that an amount of Seventy Five Thousand and no/100 ($75,000.00)
  Dollars can only be explained on the basis of passion, prejudice or caprice on
  the part of the jury.Â  The juryâ€™s verdict in this case shocks the conscience of
  this Court, as an award of damages, particularly the considerations, or lack
  thereof, of the uncontested damages presented by the Plaintiff, including a
  Twenty-One (21%) percent permanent impairment to health.Â  As such, this Court
  finds that the juryâ€™s verdict in this matter is grossly inadequate in light of
  the evidence presented.

The trial judge then granted Laneâ€™s
  motion for a new trial absolute.
A. Did the trial court commit legal error in viewing
  certain damages as â€œunconstested?â€
Gilbert
  first argues that it was legal error for the trial judge to base his order on
  the idea that certain damages were â€œuncontested.â€Â  Gilbert contends that it â€œdid
    contest those damages, denying them in its Answer, by not stipulating as to
  damages and by questioning Laneâ€™s claims in cross-examining various witnesses
  about them.â€Â  In Gilbertâ€™s view, the trial courtâ€™s Order implied that Gilbert
  was required to put up witnesses to contest the claim of damages and thereby
  shifted the burden of proof from the plaintiff to the defendant.Â  We disagree.
In
  considering a motion for a new trial, the trial judge must look to see if the
  evidence justifies the jury verdict. See Norton, 350 S.C. at 478,
  567 S.E.2d at 854.Â  The court, in making such an inquiry, is perfectly
  justified in noting whether the evidence presented to the jury was or was not
  challenged in front of the jury.
Moreover,
  the trial judgeâ€™s statement that certain evidence was â€œuncontestedâ€ was not
  factually incorrect, since the evidence in question was not challenged by
  Gilbert at trial, even on cross-examination.Â  Gilbertâ€™s counsel told the jury
  in his opening statement:

	We are not contesting that he was injured.Â  We are not
  going to challenge those areas about his life.Â  He was injured.Â  He has
  undergone a lot of medical treatment.Â  But, there is one part of his damages
  that we are going to talk about.Â  We do take exception to the future los[t]
  wages that you are going to hear.

As promised, Gilbert did not challenge the medical
  costs, lost wages prior to trial, or physical impairment rating.Â  Instead,
  Gilbert chose to focus on disputing Laneâ€™s claims for future lost wages, and
  succeeded as the jury awarded $0 for that particular claim.
The trial court committed no error in noting
  that certain damages were â€œuncontestedâ€ in its order granting a new trial.
B. Is there evidence to support the trial courtâ€™s
  order?
Gilbert
  contends that the trial court erred in granting a new trial because there is no
  evidence to support the order.Â  We disagree.
On a
  special verdict form, the jury awarded $75,000 in actual damages of which it
  attributed $0 to future diminished earning capacity.Â  Gilbert argues that the
  jury properly declined to award earning capacity since, at the time of trial, Lane
  was employed in a job that paid better than his previous job.Â  Gilbert also
  posits reasons why the jury might choose to reduce the awards for pre-trial
  personal services, pain and suffering, and medical bills.[1]
Gilbertâ€™s
  points are not entirely without merit.Â  However, the question before this Court
  on appeal is whether the trial courtâ€™s decision to grant a new trial is wholly
  unsupported by the evidence. See Norton, 350 S.C. at 478, 567
  S.E.2d at 854.Â  In the instant case, Lane presented evidence of $73,754 in
  medical bills and $17,248 in lost wages up to the time of trial, neither of
  which was challenged by Gilbert.Â  Lane also presented evidence that Lane has a
  21% physical impairment, experienced pain and suffering related to the
  accident, and suffered a loss of personal services to his family of $19,381.Â 
  We find the trial courtâ€™s decision order granting a new trial is supported by
  the evidence.

III. Was Gilbert denied
  its right to a trial by jury?
Gilbert
  contends that to grant a new trial after the jury verdict was â€œde facto to
  deny Gilbert its constitutional right to trial by jury.â€Â  In short, Gilbert
  contends that the Thirteenth Juror Doctrine is unconstitutional under the South Carolina constitution.Â  We disagree.
The
  Thirteenth Juror Doctrine is a well-established in South Carolina as the
  standard for granting a new trial. See Norton, 350 S.C. 477, 567
  S.E.2d at 854.Â  This Court has reviewed the doctrine on several occasions and
  has refused to abolish it. Id. at 478, 567 S.E.2d at 854.
The
  right to trial by jury is a fundamental right. See Wright v. Colleton
    County School Dist., 301 S.C. 282, 291, 391 S.E.2d 564, 570 (1990).Â  As
  such, any abridgement of that right is subject to strict scrutiny. See City
    of Beaufort v. Holcombe, 369 S.C. 643, 632 S.E.2d 894 (Ct. App. 2006).Â  To
  meet strict scrutiny, a law or policy must meet a compelling state interest and
  be narrowly tailored to effectuate that interest. See In re Treatment
    and Care of Luckabaugh, 351 S.C. 122, 140-41, 568 S.E.2d 338, 347 (2002).
The
  Thirteenth Juror Doctrine does not abridge the right to a trial by jury since
  the effect of a trial judgeâ€™s decision to grant a new trial is to allow another
  jury trial.Â  Therefore, the parties are not deprived of a trial by jury.
We affirm
  the trial courtâ€™s exercise of power under the Thirteenth Juror Doctrine.
CONCLUSION
The
  trial court did not err in declining to grant a directed verdict for Gilbert
  based on Laneâ€™s status for purposes of premises liability.Â  Furthermore, the
  trial court did not err in granting a new trial under the Thirteenth Juror
  Doctrine, nor is the doctrine unconstitutional.Â  Therefore, the decision of the
  trial court is
AFFIRMED.
WALLER,
  BEATTY, KITTREDGE, JJ., and Acting Justice James E. Moore, concur.


[1] Gilbert contends that the jury may have reduced the amount of damages based on
  medical bills because (1) though the bills were introduced, there was no
  testimony that they had been paid, and (2) the jury could have reasonably
  concluded from Laneâ€™s answer that the summary of medical expenses was correct
  â€œto my knowledgeâ€ that Lane did not know how much he had been billed, or
  actually paid for medical expenses.

title: State v. Wallace
description: The Court reversed the Court of Appeals, and held that a close degree of similarity is required before evidence of prior bad acts can be admitted under the common scheme or plan exception to Rule 404(b), SCRE in a child sexual case.

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court


  
    
      The State, Petitioner,
      v.
      Karl Wallace, Respondent.
    
  


ON WRIT OF CERTIORARI TO 
THE COURT OF APPEALS

Appeal from Greenville County
J. Michael Baxley, Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No. 26703
  Heard March 18, 2008 - Filed August 17,
2009

REVERSED


  
    
      
        Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy
          Attorney General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Salley W.
          Elliott, Senior Assistant Attorney General Harold M. Coombs, of Columbia; and
          Solicitor Robert M. Ariail, of Greenville, for petitioner.
        C. Rauch Wise, of Greenwood; and Everett P. Godfrey, Jr.,
          of Godfrey Law Firm, of Greenville, for respondent.
      
    
  


ACTING JUSTICE
  BURNETT:Â  Respondent Karl
  Wallace was convicted of criminal sexual conduct with a minor, second degree,
  for the sexual abuse of his stepdaughter (Victim).Â  On appeal, the Court of
  Appeals reversed, holding the admission of evidence that respondent abused
  Victimâ€™s older sister (Sister) was improperly admitted.[1]Â 
  We reverse.
FACTS
Victim
  testified the abuse began when she was twelve years old.Â  Â When she was in
  seventh grade, respondent would periodically call her into his bedroom and tell
  her to go into the adjoining bathroom and take off her clothes.Â  Victimâ€™s
  mother and Sister worked nights and were not at home when this happened.Â 
  Respondent would touch Victimâ€™s breasts and would warn her, â€œDonâ€™t tell anyone
  â€˜cause theyâ€™re not going to believe you anyway.â€Â  This conduct continued during
  the time Victim was in the seventh and eighth grade.Â  
One
  night when Victim was in ninth grade, respondent told her to sit on his bed.Â  Victimâ€™s
  mother was not home and Sister had moved out of the house.Â  Respondent forced
  Victim back on the bed, pulled off her pants and underwear, forced open her
  legs and â€œpushed his hands up [her] private parts.â€Â  When Victim screamed,
  respondent put a pillow over her face and threatened to hit her if she did not
  stop.Â  Victimâ€™s younger brother came to the door and respondent told Victim to
  go into the bathroom and dress.Â  After the brother left, respondent forced
  Victim back onto the bed and took off her pants again but only looked at her.Â 
  He then let her get back up and get dressed, and she left the room.Â  Victim telephoned
  Sister who came to the house but respondent would not let Sister come inside.Â  
The
  next day, Sister visited Victim at school to find out why Victim had called.Â  Sister
  asked if respondent had â€œmessed with herâ€ and Victim told Sister what
  respondent had done.Â  Sister reported the abuse and a police report was filed.Â  
At
  trial, after an in camera hearing, the trial judge allowed Sister to testify that
  she was also sexually abused by respondent from the time she was in seventh
  grade until she moved out of the house after graduating high school.Â  Sister
  testified that respondent would rub her back and sometimes put his hands up
  under her shirt and touch her breasts.Â  After a while, he started touching her
  â€œprivate areaâ€ and performing oral sex on her.Â  This would occur sporadically
  in respondentâ€™s bedroom or in Sisterâ€™s bedroom when her mother was not at
  home.Â  Sister testified respondent â€œwould always tell me, you know, at the end,
  you know, â€˜You better not tell anyone. . . . â€˜Theyâ€™re not going to believe
  [you] so donâ€™t tell anyone.â€™â€Â  The trial judge found this evidence admissible under
  Rule 404(b), SCRE, as evidence of common scheme or plan.Â  
ISSUE

  Did
    the Court of Appeals err in finding Sisterâ€™s testimony inadmissible as evidence
    of common scheme or plan?

DISCUSSION
Rule 404(b)
Evidence
  of other bad acts is not admissible to prove the defendantâ€™s guilt except to
  show motive, identity, existence of a common scheme or plan, absence of mistake
  or accident, or intent.Â  Rule 404(b), SCRE; see also State v. Lyle,
  125 S.C. 406, 11 S.E. 803 (1923).[2]Â 
  The Court of Appeals found it was error to admit Sisterâ€™s testimony as evidence
  of common scheme or plan because â€œthe trial court did not address any connection
  between the two crimes.â€ Â Rather than viewing the similarity of the two events
  as establishing the required connection, the Court of Appeals found some
  further link was necessary.[3]
The process of analyzing bad act evidence begins with Rule 401,
  SCRE.[4]Â 
  Pursuant to Rule 401, the trial court must determine whether the evidence is
  relevant.Â  Upon determining the evidence is relevant, the trial court must then
  determine whether the bad act evidence fits within an exception of Rule 404(b) as
  interpreted by our jurisprudence. 
Rule 404(b) allows the admission of evidence of a common scheme or
  plan.Â  Such evidence is relevant because
  proof of one is strong proof of the other.Â  When determining whether evidence is admissible as common scheme
  or plan, the trial court must analyze the similarities and dissimilarities
  between the crime charged and the bad act evidence to determine whether there is a close degree of similarity. Â State v.
    Parker, 315 S.C. 230, 433 S.E.2d 831 (1993).Â  When the similarities
  outweigh the dissimilarities, the bad act evidence is admissible under Rule
  404(b).Â  
Although
  not a complete list, in this type of case, the trial court should consider the
  following factors when determining whether there is a close degree of
  similarity between the bad act and the crime charged:Â  (1) the age of the
  victims when the abuse occurred; (2) the relationship between the victims and
  the perpetrator; (3) the location where the abuse occurred; (4) the use of
  coercion or threats; and (5) the manner of the occurrence, for example, the
  type of sexual battery.Â  See State v. Hallman, 298 S.C. 172, 379
  S.E.2d 115 (1989) (evidence admissible as common scheme or plan where all
  victims were foster children of similar age and the types of sexual batteries
  were similar); State v. McClellan, 283 S.C. 389, 323 S.E.2d 772
  (1984) (evidence admissible as common scheme or plan where both victims were
  defendantâ€™s daughters, were the same age at time of the initial attack, and
  defendant gave same explanation for his actions).Â  We emphasize that these
  factors are set out merely for guidance and that other factors may be relevant
  in weighing the similarities and the dissimilarities between the crime charged
  and the bad act evidence.
A close degree of similarity establishes the required
  connection between the two acts and no further â€œconnectionâ€ must be shown for
  admissibility.[5]Â 
  Here, the similarities between the acts include petitionerâ€™s relationship to
  the victims (his stepdaughters), abuse beginning at about the same age, abuse
  occurring in the family home when the mother was absent, and an admonishment
  not to tell because no one would believe it.Â  In sum, there are similarities in
  the class of victim, timing, place, and warning that outweigh any dissimilarity.Â 
  We find the Court of Appeals erred in ruling that Sisterâ€™s testimony was
  improperly admitted under Rule 404(b).Â Â  
Redaction
At the in camera
  hearing, Sister testified that digital penetration and oral sex eventually
  progressed to intercourse.Â  The trial court ruled that in order to avoid unfair
  prejudice to respondent, any testimony regarding intercourse would not be
  allowed when Sister testified before the jury.Â  The Court of Appeals found this
  was error because it made the two acts seem more similar than they actually
  were.Â  We disagree.
We note that the
  trial court redacted only the last step in a progressive course of abuse.Â 
  Sisterâ€™s abuse began with touching of the breasts, digital penetration and oral
  sex, and then progressed to the point of intercourse.Â  The fact that Victimâ€™s
  abuse was interrupted before it could culminate in intercourse does not diminish
  the similarity between the progression the abuse took in each case.Â  Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  Moreover,
  the trial court may properly redact dissimilar particulars of sexual conduct to
  avoid unfair prejudice to the defendant.Â  

Rule 403
Once bad act evidence is found admissible
  under Rule 404(b), the trial court must then conduct the prejudice analysis
  required by Rule 403, SCRE.[6]Â  The probative value of evidence falling
  within one of the Rule 404(b) exceptions must substantially outweigh the danger
  of unfair prejudice to the defendant.Â  State v. Gillian, 373 S.C. 601,
  646 S.E.2d 872 (2007).Â  Here,
  the probative value of Sisterâ€™s testimony as redacted substantially outweighs
  the danger of unfair prejudice.Â  We conclude the trial court properly admitted
  the evidence.Â  The decision of the Court of Appeals is
REVERSED.
TOAL,
  C.J., and WALLER, J., concur. BEATTY, J., concurring in result only. PLEICONES,
  J., dissenting in a separate opinion.

JUSTICE PLEICONES:Â  I respectfully dissent.Â  In my opinion, our cases
  holding that evidence of other acts of sexual misconduct is admissible in a
  trial for criminal sexual conduct with a minor as a â€œcommon scheme or planâ€
  under Rule 404(b), SCRE, have, in effect, created an exception to the ruleâ€™s
  exclusion of propensity evidence.Â  Compare, e.g., Vogel v. State,
  315 Md. 458, 554 A.2d 1231 (Ct. App. 1989).Â  We have repeatedly held in
  non-sexual offense cases that, â€œthe mere presence of similarity only serves to
  enhance the potential for prejudice,â€ State v. Tuffour, 364 S.C. 497,
  613 S.E.2d 814 (Ct. App. 2005) vacated on other grounds 371 S.C. 511,
  641 S.E.2d 24 (2007) internal citations omitted, yet under the
  majorityâ€™s view, similarity is the touchstone of admissibility in child sexual
  offense cases.Â  In my view, if we are to permit the admission of propensity
  evidence in these types of cases, then we should propose a new rule of
  evidence, and encourage public comment.Â  See e.g. Rules 413 and
  414, Fed. R. Evid.; Rule 404(c), Az. R. Evid.Â  In light of the controversy
  engendered by these rules in other jurisdictions,[7] I believe that thorough scrutiny is warranted.


[1] State v. Wallace, 364 S.C. 130, 611 S.E.2d 332 (Ct. App. 2005).
[2]Bad
  act evidence that is not subject to a conviction must be shown by clear and
  convincing evidence and is reviewed under an â€œany evidenceâ€ standard on
  appeal.Â  State v. Wilson, 345 S.C. 1, 545 S.E.2d 827 (2001).Â  Here,
  there is no challenge to the proof of the bad act.
[3] In support, the Court of Appeals points to Lyle, supra, in which this Court allowed evidence of a â€œsimilar crimeâ€ that
  occurred on the same date in the same town (Aiken), but disallowed evidence of
  â€œsimilar crimesâ€ that occurred on other dates in other locations (Georgia).Â 
  The Lyle court observed that there was no connection to show the Georgia crimes were â€œpractically â€˜a continuous transaction,â€™â€ 125 S.C. at 427, 118 S.E. at
  811, and therefore the evidence was inadmissible.Â  The Court of Appeals read
  this holding in Lyle to mean a similarity in the acts is not enough
  without some further connection.Â  
A
  careful reading of Lyle does not support the Court of Appealsâ€™
  conclusion.Â  The crime charged in Lyle was uttering a forged check.Â  The Lyle court allowed the Aiken bad act evidence not only because it had
  occurred on the same date, but because it had a close degree of similarity to
  the particulars of the crime chargedâ€”the forged checks were issued using the
  same name and the same address.Â  118 S.E. at 807-808.Â  The evidence that was not allowed was evidence of simply uttering other forged checks with no particulars
  in common with the events giving rise to the charge for which the defendant was
  tried.Â  In other words, the commission of acts that fall into the same criminal
  definition is not sufficient.Â  The acts must bear some factual similarity to
  constitute a connection between them.
[4]Rule
  401 provides that relevant
  evidence is â€œevidence having any tendency to make the existence of any fact
  that is of consequence to the determination of the action more probable or less
  probable than it would be without the evidence.â€
[5]The Court of Appeals relied on State v. Tutton,
  354 S.C. 319, 580 S.E.2d 186 (Ct. App. 2003), which appears to require a
  connection beyond a degree of similarity in the details of the crime charged
  and the bad act evidence.Â  We find this interpretation to be an overly
  restrictive view of our case law.Â  Requiring a â€œconnectionâ€ between the crime
  charged and the bad act evidence is simply a requirement that the two be factually
  similar and does not add an additional layer of analysis.
[6]Rule
  403 states:

  Although relevant, evidence may be excluded if its
    probative value is substantially outweighed by the danger of unfair prejudice,
    confusion of the issues, or misleading the jury, or by considerations of undue
    delay, waste of time, or needless presentation of cumulative evidence.Â Â  

[7] I note that The Advisory Committees on Criminal and Civil Rules, except for the
  Department of Justice representative, the Study Committee, except for the DOJ
  representative, and the Judicial Conference unanimously urged Congress to
  reconsider these Rules.

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA

        The State, Petitioner/Respondent,
        v.

          Hubner, Respondent/Petitioner.
      
    
  


ON WRIT OF CERTIORARI TO THE COURT OF APPEALS

Appeal From Richland County
Â James C. Williams, Jr., Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No. 26704Â  
  Heard March 18, 2008 - Filed August 17,
2009

REVERSED 


  
    
      
        Attorney
          General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney General John W. McIntosh, Assistant
          Deputy Attorney General Charles H. Richardson, and Assistant Attorney General
          David A. Spencer, of Columbia; and Solicitor Warren B. Giese, of Columbia, for

          B. Buffkin, of Crime Victim Legal Network, of Columbia,Â  for Amicus Curiae South Carolina Crime Victim Legal Network.
        Ernest
          Charles Grose, Jr., of Greenwood, for Amicus Curiae South Carolina
          Association of Criminal Defense Lawyers.
      
    
  


 
ACTING
  JUSTICE BURNETT:Â  Respondent/Petitioner (Hubner) was convicted of six counts of lewd act upon a
  child and was sentenced to three consecutive twelve-year terms of imprisonment,
  two concurrent twelve-year terms of imprisonment, and one fifteen-year term of
  imprisonment, which was suspended on service of five yearsâ€™ probation.Â  Hubner
  appealed.
The
  Court of Appeals reversed the convictions, holding the trial judge committed
  reversible error in admitting evidence of a prior sexual assault against a
  different victim.Â  State v. Hubner, 362 S.C. 572, 608 S.E.2d 463 (Ct.
  App. 2005).Â  In light of our holding in State v. Wallace, Op. No. 26703
  (S.C. Sup. Ct. filed August 17, 2009), the decision of the Court of Appeals is
REVERSED.

JUSTICE PLEICONES:Â  For the reasons given in my dissent in State v.
  Wallace. Op. No. 26703 (S.C. Sup. Ct. filed August 17, 2009 ), I
  respectfully dissent.

title: State v. Clasby
description: We affirm Appellant's conviction for lewd act upon a child, finding the trial judge properly admitted prior bad act evidence.
