THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court


  
    
      
        The State, Respondent,
        v.
        Janice M.
          Clasby, Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From Pickens County
Â Larry R. Patterson, Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No.Â  26705
Heard May 28, 2009 - Filed August 17, 2009Â  

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
        Chief
          Appellate Defender Joseph L. Savitz, III and Appellate Defender LaNelle C.
          DuRant, of South Carolina Commission on Indigent Defense, Â of Columbia, for
          Appellant.
        Attorney
          General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney General John W. McIntosh, Assistant
          Deputy Attorney General Salley W. Elliott, Senior Assistant Attorney General
          Harold M. Coombs, Jr., all of Columbia, and Solicitor Robert M. Ariail, of
          Greenville, for Respondent.
      
    
  


JUSTICE
  BEATTY:Â  Janice M. Clasby appeals her
  conviction for lewd act upon a child,[1] arguing the trial judge erred in admitting evidence of prior bad acts involving
  the victim for which she was not indicted under the common scheme or plan
  exception to State v. Lyle, 125 S.C. 406, 118 S.E. 803 (1923), and Rule
  404(b), SCRE.Â  Pursuant to Rule 204(b), SCACR, this Court certified this appeal
  from the Court of Appeals.Â  We affirm.
FACTUAL/PROCEDURAL HISTORY
On
  August 6, 1994, a daughter, B.C., was born to Clasby and Bug Holliday.Â 
  Although the couple lived together at the time of B.C.â€™s birth, the couple
  separated approximately a month and a half later.Â  After the separation, Clasby
  had physical custody of B.C. 
According to
  Holliday, he did not have contact with B.C. until she was four years old given
  he â€œnever could find where [Clasby and B.C.] were staying at.â€Â  Despite this
  reunion, Holliday stated that he did not establish a relationship with B.C.
  until she was six years old because Clasby â€œleft againâ€ with B.C.Â  At that
  time, Holliday was awarded legal custody of B.C. after a family court custody
  proceeding. Even though the family court granted Clasby visitation, Holliday
  testified that Clasby did not exercise this right on a regular basis. 
When Clasby became
  homeless in November 2003, Holliday permitted her to move in with him but the
  two did not maintain a romantic relationship.Â  One month later, Clasby moved
  out of the home.Â  Clasby did not establish contact with Holliday and B.C. until
  May 2004 when she sought to exercise her visitation rights.Â  While Holliday was
  reluctant to permit Clasby to have visitation, he testified he did so in order
  to be in compliance with the family court order.Â  Shortly thereafter, Holliday
  made the decision to seek a modification of Clasbyâ€™s visitation schedule so
  that he could get â€œsome help from the police if [Clasby] didnâ€™t return [B.C.]â€
  and â€œto keep track of [Clasby] better.â€
Although the exact
  date is unclear, B.C. at some point expressed that she no longer wanted to
  visit with Clasby.Â  Because B.C. would not give a reason for this decision,
  Holliday decided to send B.C. to Cynthia Still, a licensed professional
  counselor.Â  Holliday believed that a counselor would help him assess B.C.â€™s
  relationship with Clasby prior to another family court proceeding. 
On June 23, 2004,
  Still began the first of twenty-seven counseling sessions with B.C.Â  During the
  sixth visit, on August 16, 2004, Still noticed that B.C. â€œseemed differentâ€ and
  appeared â€œanxious.â€Â  According to Still, B.C. described â€œsome situations where
  she had been around a lot of talk that involved sexual issues that she was very
  uncomfortable with.â€Â  In the course of an appointment two days later, B.C.
  conveyed to Still that she had been sexually abused.Â Â Â  In turn, Still relayed
  to Holliday her concerns for B.C.â€™s safety.Â Â Â  Â 
After
  receiving this information, Holliday spoke with B.C. who then revealed her
  claims of sexual abuse. Â Based on this discussion, Holliday met with law
  enforcement regarding B.C.â€™s allegations.Â  B.C. was then interviewed at the
  Pickens County Sheriffâ€™s Office.Â  Following this interview, Clasby was arrested
  for CSC with a minor, first degree.Â  
In
  September 2005, a Pickens County grand jury indicted Clasby for CSC with a
  minor, first degree and lewd act upon a child for offenses that allegedly
  occurred in June 2004. 
At
  the trial for these offenses in October 2005, the solicitor sought to introduce
  evidence of prior bad acts involving Clasby with the victim that allegedly
  occurred prior to the indicted June 2004 incidents.Â  The solicitor asserted
  that these incidents established â€œan escalating pattern of abuse that
  eventually culminated in criminal sexual conduct in the first degree.â€ Â Clasbyâ€™s
  counsel opposed the introduction of the evidence on the ground it did not fit
  within the Lyle exception of common scheme or plan.Â  Following arguments
  of counsel, the trial judge preliminarily ruled that the evidence could be
  introduced. 
After
  B.C. began her testimony, the trial judge conducted an in camera hearing
  regarding the alleged prior bad act evidence.Â  B.C. testified that when Clasby
  came to live with her and Holliday, she and Clasby would bathe together. Â B.C.
  testified that she would sit with her back against the bathtub while her mother
  sat with her back to her. Â She further testified that as she was washing her
  motherâ€™s hair, Clasby would â€œput her hair back . . . and touch my private and
  rub it.â€ 
B.C.
  testified that on another occasion she was watching a movie with her mother
  with a blanket over them in the living room and her mother â€œrub[bed] her
  privateâ€ inside of her underwear.Â  She further stated that her mother â€œplay[ed]
  with her privateâ€ while the two were sleeping together in her fatherâ€™s bed. 
In
  addition to the incidents that B.C. testified occurred at her fatherâ€™s house,
  B.C. relayed an incident after her mother moved out of Hollidayâ€™s home.Â  Following
  her motherâ€™s departure in the spring of 2004, B.C. testified that she would
  visit her mother at Clasbyâ€™s fatherâ€™s home.Â  B.C. recounted one time when her
  mother â€œrub[bed] her privateâ€ and her mother asked her to â€œsuck her breasts.â€ 
After
  outlining these prior incidents, the solicitor questioned B.C. regarding the
  June 1, 2004 incidents for which Clasby had been indicted.Â  Although B.C. could
  not remember the exact date, she testified that her mother â€œput her fingerâ€
  inside â€œher privateâ€ while they were lying on the floor in the bedroom of
  Heather Rhoda, Clasbyâ€™s sister.
At the conclusion
  of B.C.â€™s in camera testimony, the trial judge ruled the prior bad act
  evidence was â€œclear and convincingâ€ and admissible under the â€œcommon scheme or
  planâ€ exception to Lyle. 
B.C. gave
  essentially the same testimony before the jury as she did during the in
    camera hearing.Â  When questioned as to why she did not immediately reveal
  the abuse, B.C. claimed that her mother told her she would kill her if she
  told.Â  
During her
  testimony, Clasby adamantly denied ever touching B.C. in a â€œsexually
  inappropriate manner.â€Â  Through her testimony, Clasby inferred the sexual abuse
  allegations stemmed from animosity that existed between her and Holliday over
  their custody and visitation arrangement.Â  Specifically, Clasby testified that
  Holliday told her â€œhe would do whatever it took to keep [her] away from [B.C.].â€Â 
  In terms of the incidents described by B.C., Clasby explained the alleged
  misconduct would have occurred when B.C. visited her at Clasbyâ€™s fatherâ€™s
  doublewide trailer which was shared by nine other relatives.
Heather Rhoda,
  Clasbyâ€™s sister, testified there was no privacy in the trailer given the number
  of people who resided there.Â  Rhoda claimed that B.C. usually slept with her
  cousin when she visited and was not alone with Clasby.Â  She described Clasby
  and B.C. as having a â€œreally good relationship.â€Â  She further testified that
  she overheard Holliday tell Clasby that â€œhe would do whatever he had to do to
  make sure that [Clasby] would not be able see [B.C.] again.â€ 
Ultimately, the
  jury convicted Clasby of lewd act upon a child, but acquitted her of CSC with a
  minor, first degree.Â  The trial judge sentenced Clasby to fourteen years
  imprisonment.Â  Clasby appealed her conviction to the Court of Appeals.Â  This
  Court certified this appeal from the Court of Appeals.
DISCUSSION
Clasby
  argues the trial judge erred in admitting B.C.â€™s testimony in which she
  described four uncharged incidents of sexual misconduct involving Clasby.Â 
  Because she was not indicted for these acts, Clasby contends the evidence was
  inadmissible in that it did not rise to the level of common scheme or plan
  evidence under Lyle.Â  Specifically, Clasby asserts the prior bad acts
  were â€œseparate in time and had no connection with the incident from which she
  was chargedâ€ and, thus, served only to show that she had a â€œpropensity for
  child molestation.â€ If the admission of this evidence is found to have been in
  error, Clasby claims its admission did not constitute harmless error.Â  
The trial judge
  has considerable latitude in ruling on the admissibility of evidence and his
  decision should not be disturbed absent prejudicial abuse of discretion. Â State
    v. Brazell, 325 S.C. 65, 78, 480 S.E.2d 64, 72 (1997).Â  Â  
As a
  threshold matter, the trial judge must initially determine whether the
  proffered evidence is relevant as required under Rule 401 of the South Carolina
  Rules of Evidence.Â  Rule 401, SCRE (â€œâ€˜Relevant
  evidenceâ€™ means evidence having any tendency to make the existence of any fact
  that is of consequence to the determination of the action more probable or less
  probable than it would be without the evidence.â€).
If the trial judge
  finds the evidence to be relevant, the judge must then determine whether the
  bad act evidence fits within an exception of Rule 404(b).Â  According to Rule
  404(b), evidence of prior crimes or misconduct is inadmissible to prove the
  specific crime charged unless the evidence tends to establish: Â (1) motive; (2)
  intent; (3) the absence of mistake or accident; (4) a common scheme or plan
  embracing the commission of two or more crimes so related to each other that
  proof of one tends to establish the proof of the other; or (5)
  the identity of the person charged with the present crime. Â Rule 404(b), SCRE
  (â€œEvidence of other crimes, wrongs, or
  acts is not admissible to prove the character of a person in order to show
  action in conformity therewith. Â It may, however, be admissible to show motive,
  identity, the existence of a common scheme or plan, theabsence of mistake or accident, or intent.â€); Lyle, 125
  S.C. at 416, 118 S.E. at 807.
â€œTo be admissible, the bad act must logically relate to the crime
  with which the defendant has been charged.â€ Â State v. Gaines, 380 S.C.
  23, 29, 667 S.E.2d 728, 731 (2008). Â â€œIf the defendant was not convicted of the
  prior crime, evidence of the prior bad act must be clear and convincing.â€Â  Id.
When considering whether there is clear and convincing evidence of
  other bad acts, an appellate court is bound by the trial judgeâ€™s factual
  findings unless they are clearly erroneous. Â State v. Wilson, 345 S.C.
  1, 6, 545 S.E.2d 827, 829 (2001).Â  The determination of a witnessâ€™s credibility
  is left to the trial judge who saw and heard the witness and is therefore in a better position to evaluate his
  or her veracity. Â Id. (analyzing
  prior bad act evidence and finding the appellate court committed error by
  basing its ruling on its own
  view of the witnessâ€™s credibility).Â  If the trial judge concludes there is
  clear and convincing evidence that the defendant committed the uncharged acts, he
  or she must determine whether the prior acts fall within the common scheme or
  plan exception to Lyle.Â  Â Â 
â€œWhere there is a close degree of similarity between the crime
  charged and the prior bad act, both this Court and the Court of Appeals have
  held prior bad acts are admissible to demonstrate a common scheme or plan.â€ Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  Gaines, 380
  S.C. at 30, 667 S.E.2d at 731.Â  â€œWhen
  determining whether evidence is admissible as common scheme or plan, the trial
  court must analyze the similarities and dissimilarities between the crime
  charged and the bad act evidence to determine whether there is a close degree
  of similarity.â€Â  State v. Wallace, Op. No. 26703 (S.C. Sup. Ct. filed August 17, 2009).Â  â€œWhen the similarities outweigh the dissimilarities, the bad
  act evidence is admissible under Rule 404(b).â€Â  Id.
â€œEven if prior bad act evidence is clear
  and convincing and falls within an exception, it must be excluded if its
  probative value is substantially outweighed by the danger of unfair prejudice
  to the defendant.â€Â  Gaines, 380 S.C. at 29, 667 S.E.2d at 731; see Rule 403, SCRE (providing that evidence, although relevant, may be excluded if
  its probative value is substantially outweighed by the danger of unfair
  prejudice); State v. Gillian, 373 S.C. 601, 609, 646 S.E.2d 872, 876
  (2007) (applying probative versus prejudicial test of Rule 403, SCRE, to â€œother
  crimesâ€ evidence).Â  â€œThe determination of the prejudicial effect of the
  evidence must be based on the entire record and the result will generally turn
  on the facts of each case.â€Â  State v. Fletcher, 379 S.C. 17, 24, 664
  S.E.2d 480, 483 (2008). 
We
  find the trial judge properly admitted the proffered evidence of the four
  incidents of uncharged sexual misconduct committed by Clasby on B.C. prior to
  the June 1, 2004 offenses for which she was indicted and tried.Â  The alleged
  prior bad act evidence reveals a close degree of similarity to the facts of the
  indicted charges.
All
  of Clasbyâ€™s alleged sexual misconduct was directed at the same victim.Â  The
  incidents described by B.C. occurred each time Clasby reunited with B.C. Â In
  November 2003, Clasby moved in with Holliday after becoming homeless.Â  B.C.
  testified that during this month-long stay, the following incidents occurred:Â 
  (1) her mother touched her â€œprivateâ€ while the two bathed together; (2) her
  mother â€œrub[bed] her privateâ€ inside of her underwear; and (3) her mother
  â€œplay[ed] with her privateâ€ while the two were sleeping together in her
  fatherâ€™s bed.Â  After another extended absence, Clasby sought to exercise her
  visitation rights with B.C. in May 2004.Â  Â According to B.C., another incident
  occurred in the spring of 2004 where her mother â€œrub[bed] her privateâ€ and
  asked her to â€œsuck her breastsâ€ while they were lying on the floor together.Â 
  Each of the incidents established a pattern of escalating abuse which
  ultimately culminated in Clasbyâ€™s digital penetration of B.C.Â  The four prior
  incidents of sexual misconduct by Clasby reveal the same illicit conduct with B.C.
  during periods of visitation prior to the June 1, 2004 indicted offenses.Â  
Because
  a close degree of similarity exists between the crimes charged and the bad act
  evidence, we hold the proffered evidence satisfied the established requirements
  for the admissibility of evidence under the common scheme or plan exception. Â See Wallace (holding that in weighing the similarities and dissimilarities
  between the crime charged and the bad act evidence a trial court should
  consider, among other factors, the location where the abuse occurred, the use
  of coercion or threats, and the manner of the occurrence, for example, the type
  of sexual battery); see also State v. Whitener, 228 S.C. 244, 265,
  89 S.E.2d 701, 711 (1955) (recognizing that the common scheme or plan exception
  â€œis generally applied in cases involving sexual crimes, where evidence of acts
  prior and subsequent to the act charged in the indictment is held admissible as
  tending to show continued illicit intercourse between the same partiesâ€
  (emphasis added)).Â  To the extent Clasby claims the evidence was not â€œclear and
  convincingâ€ on the ground B.C. was not definitive in her testimony regarding
  the time and place of the four incidents, we find any issue regarding B.C.â€™s
  credibility was properly evaluated by the trial judge. 
Furthermore, under
  similar circumstances to the instant case, this Court and the Court of Appeals
  have found prior bad act evidence was properly admitted under the common scheme
  or plan exception.Â  See State v. McClellan, 283 S.C. 389, 392, 323
  S.E.2d 772, 774 (1984) (concluding that victimâ€™s testimony regarding prior
  attacks by defendant, which were not the subject of an indictment, was properly
  admitted under the common scheme or plan exception in trial for CSC with a
  minor, second degree where testimony showed â€œthe continued illicit intercourse
  forced upon her by [defendant]â€); State v. Kirton, 381 S.C. 7, 36, 671
  S.E.2d 107, 121-22 (Ct. App. 2008) (holding evidence that defendant began
  touching and committing other sexual misconduct with victim when she was six or
  seven years old was admissible to show common scheme or plan during trial for
  the indicted offense of CSC with a minor, second degree on the ground that the
  â€œsix to seven year pattern of escalating abuse of Victim by [defendant was] the
  essence of grooming and continuous illicit activityâ€); State v. Mathis, 359
  S.C. 450, 464, 597 S.E.2d 872, 879 (Ct. App. 2004) (concluding evidence of
  uncharged sexual misconduct committed by the defendant on the victim three
  times prior to the indicted offense of CSC with a minor, second degree was
  admissible where the â€œthree earlier assaults on the victim were all attempted
  in the same manner and under similar circumstancesâ€); State v. Weaverling,
  337 S.C. 460, 471, 523 S.E.2d 787, 792 (Ct. App. 1999) (finding victimâ€™s
  testimony regarding pattern of sexual abuse he suffered by the defendant was
  properly admitted as part of a common scheme or plan exception in trial for CSC
  with a minor and disseminating harmful material to a minor where the
  â€œchallenged testimonial evidence of [defendantâ€™s] prior bad acts show[ed] the
  same illicit conduct with the same victim under similar circumstances over a
  period of several yearsâ€).Â  Accordingly, we find a decision to affirm the
  admission of the prior bad evidence is consistent with our jurisprudence.[2]
Finally, we hold the
  probative value of this evidence substantially outweighed the danger of unfair
  prejudice to Clasby.Â  Given there was no physical evidence to corroborate
  B.C.â€™s testimony regarding the indicted offenses of CSC with a minor, first
  degree and lewd act upon a child, we find her testimony of Clasbyâ€™s sustained
  illicit conduct was extremely probative to establish the charged criminal
  sexual conduct underlying the offense of lewd act upon a child.Â  
CONCLUSION
Based
  on the foregoing, we find B.C.â€™s testimony regarding the four incidents of
  sexual abuse inflicted by Clasby prior to the indicted offenses constitutes the
  archetypal â€œcommon scheme or planâ€ evidence.Â  Therefore, we affirm Clasbyâ€™s
  conviction and sentence for lewd act upon a child.
AFFIRMED.
TOAL,
  C.J., WALLER, PLEICONES and KITTREDGE, JJ., concur.


[1]Â  SeeS.C. Code Ann. Â§ 16-15-140 (2003) (â€œIt is unlawful for a person
  over the age of fourteen years to wilfully and lewdly commit or attempt a lewd
  or lascivious act upon or with the body, or its parts, of a child under the age
  of sixteen years, with the intent of arousing, appealing to, or gratifying the
  lust or passions or sexual desires of the person or of the child.â€).
[2]Â  We, however, note the existence of the decision of
  the Court of Appeals in State v. Tutton, 354 S.C. 319, 580 S.E.2d 186
  (Ct. App. 2003).Â  In Tutton, the defendant was convicted of CSC with a
  minor, second degree and two counts of lewd act upon a child.Â  The charges
  arose out of allegations from two minor victims, who were sisters, that Tutton
  â€œrubbed their buttsâ€ and digitally penetrated one of the victims while they
  were spending the night at Tuttonâ€™s home.Â  Id. at 323, 580 S.E.2d at
  188.Â  
On appeal, Tutton
  claimed the trial judge erred by admitting evidence of uncharged criminal
  conduct under the common scheme or plan exception.Â  Specifically, Tutton
  challenged the testimony of the victim identified in the CSC with a minor
  charge.Â  This victim testified that Tutton sexually assaulted her four or five
  years prior to the time of the trial.Â  Id. at 324, 580 S.E.2d at 189.Â Â 
  The victim claimed while spending the night at Tuttonâ€™s, he forced her to lie
  on her back and take off her underwear.Â  According to the victim, Tutton then
  performed oral sex on her and forced her to perform oral sex on him.Â  Id.Â  The victim further testified that Tutton threatened to tell her parents that
  she was misbehaving if she spoke of the incident.Â  Id.Â  
The Court of
  Appeals reversed Tuttonâ€™s convictions, finding â€œthe similarities in this case
  are insufficient to support the inference that Tutton employed a common scheme
  or plan to commit the assaults alleged in this case.â€Â  Id. at 333, 580
  S.E.2d at 194.Â  Although the Court of Appeals recognized the incidents involved
  the same parties and occurred at Tuttonâ€™s residence, it found the
  dissimilarities were greater than these similarities.Â  Specifically, the Court
  of Appeals noted that unlike the charged incident, Tutton threatened the victim
  after the uncharged incident.Â  Additionally, Tutton did not attempt to assault
  the victimâ€™s sister at the time of the uncharged act with the victim.Â  The
  Court of Appeals also pointed out that the victims had stayed with Tutton
  without incident on several occasions during the interim between the uncharged
  act and the charged offense. Â Id. at 332-33, 580 S.E.2d at 193.
We conclude Tutton is distinguishable from the instant case.Â  Initially, we note that its holding
  was called into question by the majority opinion in Wallace on the
  ground the analysis constituted an overly restrictive view of our case law.Â  Tutton is also factually dissimilar from the instant case given the sexual battery in
  the charged offense and the uncharged act was not of the same type.Â  In
  contrast, the type of sexual misconduct of the charged offenses and the
  uncharged offenses were similar in the instant case.Â  Furthermore, unlike the
  single uncharged incident relied on in Tutton, the solicitor in the
  instant case presented B.C.â€™s testimony which detailed four prior incidents
  which occurred over a relatively short period of time.

title: In the Matter of Frank Rogers Ellerbe, III
description: In this opinion, the Court suspended Frank Rogers Ellerbe, III, from the practice of law for ninety days retroactive to the date of his interim suspension.

The Supreme Court of South Carolina

	
		
			
				In the Matter
      of Frank Rogers Ellerbe, III, Respondent.
			
		
	


ORDER

Respondent has petitioned the
  Court for rehearing in this matter.Â  We grant the petition, withdraw Opinion
  Number 26692 filed July 27, 2009, and substitute the attached opinion.
IT
  IS SO ORDERED.

  
    
    
      s/John H. Waller, Jr.                           
		J.
        
        s/Costa M. Pleicones                        
		J.s/Donald W. Beatty                            
		J.
        s/John W. Kittredge                           
		J.
		Toal, C.J., not participating 
    
  

Columbia, South
  Carolina
August 20, 2009

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court

	
		
			
				In the Matter of Frank Rogers Ellerbe, III, Respondent.
			
		
	


Opinion No. 26692Â Â 
Submitted June 30, 2009 - Refiled August
  20, 2009
DEFINITE SUSPENSION


	
		
			
				Lesley M. Coggiola, Disciplinary Counsel, and 
				Barbara M. Seymour, Deputy Disciplinary Counsel, of Columbia, for Office of Disciplinary Counsel.
				JohnÂ  Barton, of Columbia, and Burnet Rhett Maybank, III, of
  Nexsen Pruet of Columbia, for Respondent.
			
		
	


PER CURIAM:Â Â  In this attorney disciplinary
  matter, respondent and the Office of Disciplinary Counsel have entered into an
  Agreement for Discipline by Consent (Agreement) pursuant to Rule 21, RLDE, Rule
  413, SCACR.Â  In the
  Agreement, respondent admits misconduct and consents to the imposition of a ninety day suspension
  from the practice of law.Â  We accept the Agreement and suspend respondent from
  the practice of law in this state for ninety days, retroactive to the date of
  his interim suspension.[1]Â  The facts, as set forth in
  the Agreement, are as follows.

FACTS
Respondent
  pled guilty to one count of failure to file state income tax returns.Â 
  Respondentâ€™s sentence included a fine and payment of the costs of prosecution.Â 
  Respondent has paid the taxes owed, the fine and the costs of prosecution.
LAW
Respondent admits that by his conduct he has violated Rule
  8.4(b) of the Rules of Professional Conduct, Rule 407, SCACR (it is professional
  misconduct for a lawyer to engage in conduct that is prejudicial to the
  administration of justice).Â  We also find respondent violated the following
  Rules of Professional Conduct:Â  Rule 8.4(a)(it is
  professional misconduct for a lawyer to violate the Rules of Professional
  Conduct); Rule 8.4(b)(it is professional misconduct for a lawyer to commit a
  criminal act that reflects adversely on the lawyerâ€™s honesty, trustworthiness,
  or fitness); and Rule 8.4(d)(it is professional misconduct for a lawyer to
  engage in conduct involving dishonesty, fraud, deceit or misrepresentation).
Respondent
  also admits he has violated the following Rules for Lawyer Disciplinary
  Enforcement, Rule 413, SCACR: Rule 7(a)(4) (it shall
  be a ground for discipline for a lawyer to be convicted of crime of moral
  turpitude or serious crime); Rule 7(a)(5) (it shall be a ground for discipline for a lawyer
  to engage in conduct tending to pollute
  the administration of justice or to bring the courts or the legal profession
  into disrepute or conduct demonstrating an unfitness to practice law).Â  We also
  find respondent has violated Rule 7(a)(1), RLDE, Rule
  413, SCACR (it shall be a ground for discipline for a lawyer to violate the
  Rules of Professional Conduct or any other rules of this jurisdiction regarding
  professional conduct of lawyers).
CONCLUSION
We find a ninety day suspension is the appropriate sanction for
  respondentâ€™s misconduct.Â  Accordingly, we accept the Agreement for Discipline
  by Consent and suspend respondent from the practice of law for a ninety day
  period, retroactive to the date of his interim suspension.Â  Respondent shall fulfill all obligations of his sentence before he
  may file a Petition for Reinstatement under Rule 32, RLDE. Within fifteen days of the date of this
  opinion, respondent shall file an affidavit with the Clerk of Court showing
  that he has complied with Rule 30, RLDE, Rule 413, SCACR.
DEFINITE SUSPENSION.
WALLER,
  ACTING CHIEF JUSTICE, PLEICONES, BEATTY and KITTREDGE, JJ., concur. TOAL, C.J.,
  not participating.


[1] Respondent was placed on interim suspension on May
  14, 2009.Â  In the Matter of Ellerbe, ___ S.C. ___, 677 S.E.2d 596
  (2009).

title: Major v. SCDPPPS
description: In this case, the South Carolina Department of Probation, Parole, and Pardon Services appeals the Administrative Law Court's decision that the Department erred in its interpretation of S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 16-23-490 regarding the implementation of the sentence imposed by the trial judge and Respondent's eligibilty for parole.  We affirm as modified.

The
  Supreme Court of South Carolina

  
    
      
        Brian Major, #176677, Respondent,
        
        v.
        South Carolina
          Department of Probation Parole and Pardon Services, Appellant.
      
    
  


ORDER

The petition for a rehearing
  is denied.Â  The attached opinions are, however, substituted for the opinions
  previously filed in this matter. 

  
    
     s/Jean H. Toal                                    C.J.
      
      s/John H. Waller, Jr.                           J.
      
    
      s/Donald W. Beatty                            J.
    
    
  

 We
would grant rehearing.

  
    
     
      s/Costa M. Pleicones                        J.
s/John W. Kittredge                           J.
    
  

Columbia, South
Carolina
August 24, 2009

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court


  
    
      
        Brian Major # 176677, Respondent,
        v.
        South Carolina
          Department of Probation, Parole and Pardon Services, Appellant.
      
    
  


John D. Geathers, Administrative Law Court
Judge

Opinion No.Â  26672
  Heard February 5, 2009 - Refiled August
24, 2009

AFFIRMED AS MODIFIED


  
    
      
        Deputy
          Director of Legal Services Teresa A. Knox, Assistant Chief Legal Counsel J.
          Benjamin Aplin, Legal Counsel Tommy Evans, Jr., of Columbia, for Appellant.
        W.
          Gaston Fairey, of Columbia, for Respondent.
      
    
  


JUSTICE BEATTY: Â In this case, the South Carolina Department of Probation, Parole and Pardon
  Services (the Department) appeals the Administrative Law Courtâ€™s (ALCâ€™s)
  decision that the Department erred in its interpretation of section 16-23-490[1] of the South Carolina Code of Laws regarding the implementation of the sentence
  imposed by the trial court and Brian Majorâ€™s eligibility for parole.Â  This
  Court granted the request of the Court of Appeals for certification pursuant to
Rule 204(b), SCACR.Â  
FACTS
On February 8,
  1996, Major was convicted of murder and possession of a weapon during the
  commission of a violent crime.Â  The trial judge sentenced Major to a term of
  life imprisonment for murder and five years imprisonment for the weapons
  charge.Â  The sentencing sheet for the weapons offense merely stated
  â€œconsecutive.â€ Â 
On
  May 8, 2002, the South Carolina Department of Corrections (DOC) informed Major
  that he was no longer eligible for parole on his life sentence[2] because he could not begin serving the five-year weapons charge sentence until
  he completed his life sentence for murder.Â  The DOCâ€™s notification was based on
  the Departmentâ€™s interpretation of section 16-23-490.Â  
In a
  PCR application, Major challenged the Departmentâ€™s interpretation of his
  sentence and the denial of parole eligibility. Â The PCR judge dismissed the
  application without prejudice so that the issues could be properly raised in
  the ALC in accordance with Al-Shabbaz v. State, 338 S.C. 354, 527 S.E.2d
  742 (2000).[3]Â Â 
  Major timely filed a petition for a writ of certiorari for this Court to review
  the PCR judgeâ€™s order.
While
  awaiting a hearing before the ALC and a decision by this Court, Major filed a
  motion for clarification of his sentence. Â Relying on this Courtâ€™s decision in Tilley
    v. State, 334 S.C. 24, 511 S.E.2d 689 (1999),[4] Major challenged the sequence in which he was to serve his sentences.Â 
  Specifically, Major claimed that he had already served the five-year weapons
  charge sentence given he was awarded almost five years of credit for time
  served since his conviction.Â  Thus, in light of Tilley, Major asserted
  that he should only be serving a life sentence which would make him eligible
  for parole. Under the Departmentâ€™s interpretation, Major averred that he would
  never be eligible for parole because he must serve his life term before serving
  the mandatory, five-year sentence.Â  
Without
  a hearing, the trial judge denied Majorâ€™s motion, explaining the sentence needs
  no clarification.
Following
  the circuit court judgeâ€™s decision, Major sought another review by the Department
  of his parole eligibility.Â  The Department issued a â€œfinal decisionâ€ and informed
  Major that he was not eligible for parole.Â  As part of this notification, the
  Department informed Major that he had the right to appeal its decision to the
  ALC.Â  Major moved for rehearing by the Department. 
In the interim, having
  granted Majorâ€™s petition for a writ of certiorari to review the PCR judgeâ€™s
  dismissal of his PCR application, this Court issued an opinion on December 11,
  2006 in which it affirmed the decision of the PCR judge. Â Major v. State,
  Op. No. 2006-MO-042 (S.C. Sup. Ct. filed Dec. 11, 2006). Â Citing Al-Shabazz,
  this Court explained that â€œMajor must pursue his requested relief through the
  procedures provided in the Administrative Procedures Act in order to have his
  sentence reordered in accordance with our decision in Tilley v. State,
  334 S.C. 24, 511 S.E.2d 689 (1999) (holding that the consecutive nature of the
  sentence does not mandate that the sentence be served in a specific order
  absent the sentencing courtâ€™s clear articulation that the sentence be served in
  a specific order).â€ 
Because of the
  procedural posture of Majorâ€™s case, the Department delayed its final
  â€œrehearingâ€ of Majorâ€™s challenge to the agencyâ€™s determination of his parole
  eligibility until after this Court issued its decision.Â  On February 16, 2007,
  the Department sent Major a â€œfinal decisionâ€ letter, affirming its prior
  determination that he was ineligible for parole and directing him to file an
  appeal with the ALC. 
Major
  filed his notice of appeal with the ALC. Â In his notice of appeal, Major argued
  that the Department incorrectly interpreted section 16-23-490 to require him to
  complete his life sentence on his murder conviction before beginning his
  five-year sentence on the weapons charge.Â  Because the sentencing judge did not
  make any statement at the time of sentencing that the sentences were to be
  served in a specific order, Major claimed that his sentences should be
  â€œreorderedâ€ to comply with this Courtâ€™s decision in Tilley. 
The
  ALC issued an order reversing the Departmentâ€™s determination that Major was
  ineligible for parole.Â  The ALC prefaced its decision by stating that criminal
  sentences must be interpreted in light of the sentencing judgeâ€™s intent.Â  In
  view of this principle, the ALC concluded that substantial evidence would not
  support the Departmentâ€™s finding â€œthat the sentencing court intended for the
  five-year sentence to commence after [Major] completes his life sentence.â€Â  
Ultimately,
  the ALC held that the Department erred in sequencing the sentences such that
  Major would never be eligible for parole.Â  In so holding, the ALC reasoned
  â€œ[t]here is no basis in logic or in the law for the intent to require an
  offender to serve an additional sentence after the completion of a life
  sentence.â€Â  The ALC further stated â€œ[t]he imposition of such a sentence would
  be a meaningless act absent the specific intent to preclude that individual
  from ever becoming eligible for parole.Â  Further, the inference of such [ ] intent
  presumes that the sentencing judge was willing to invade the province of the
  legislature by circumventing its parole eligibility laws.â€Â  
The Department
  appealed the ALCâ€™s decision to the Court of Appeals.Â  This Court granted the
  Court of Appealsâ€™ request for certification.Â  
DISCUSSION
The Department asserts the ALC erred in reversing its
  determination that Major is not parole eligible.Â  Based on the terms of section
  16-23-490 and the sentence structure imposed by the sentencing judge, the Department
  claims that Major is effectively serving a life sentence without eligibility
  for parole. Â The Department contends the sentencing judgeâ€™s initial order
  indicated a clear intention for Major to serve the five-year mandatory term
  after completion of his life sentence.Â  However, even if the original sentence
  could be construed as ambiguous, the Department avers that the sentencing judge
  clarified any question regarding his intention in the written order denying
  Majorâ€™s motion for sentence clarification.Â  
Essentially,
  the Department claims the sentencing judge definitively ordered that Major was
  to serve the five-year weapons sentence at the conclusion of his life sentence
  for murder thereby denying Major an opportunity for parole.
The
  decision of the ALC should not be overturned unless it is
  unsupported by substantial evidence or controlled by some error of law. Â S.C.
  Code Ann. Â§ 1-23-610(B) (Supp. 2008); Olson v. S.C. Depâ€™t of Health &
    Envtl. Control, 379 S.C. 57, 63, 663 S.E.2d 497, 500-01 (Ct. App. 2008)
  (â€œ[T]his court can reverse the ALC if the findings are affected by error of
  law, are not supported by substantial evidence, or are characterized by abuse
  of discretion or clearly unwarranted exercise of discretion.â€). Â The ALCâ€™s
  order should be affirmed if supported by substantial evidence in the record. Â Olson,
  379 S.C. at 63, 663 S.E.2d at 501.Â  
At
  least facially, our decision in Tilley supports a finding that the ALC
  properly reordered the sequence of Majorâ€™s sentences to ensure parole
  eligibility given the sentencing sheets do not clearly articulate a particular
  order for which Majorâ€™s sentences were to be served other than that they were
  to be â€œconsecutive.â€Â  This position is also bolstered by this Courtâ€™s order
  affirming the PCR judgeâ€™s dismissal of Majorâ€™s PCR application, wherein we
  stated â€œMajor must pursue his requested relief through the procedures provided
  in the Administrative Procedures Act in order to have his sentence reordered in
  accordance with our decision in Tilley v. State, 334 S.C. 24, 511 S.E.2d
  689 (1999).â€Â  Major v. State, Op. No. 2006-MO-042 (S.C. Sup. Ct. filed Dec. 11, 2006). 
Because
  our decision in Tilley left some questions unanswered, we take this
  opportunity to expound on the decision in Tilley and address fundamental issues concerning the
  role of the General Assembly, the authority of a sentencing judge, and the
  discretion of the Department with respect to an inmateâ€™s parole eligibility
  when a defendant is convicted of multiple offenses resulting in consecutive
  sentences.Â  
We preface our analysis with the general principle that parole is
  a privilege, not a matter of right.Â  State v. Dingle, 376 S.C. 643, 649,
  659 S.E.2d 101, 104 (2008); Sullivan v. S.C. Depâ€™t of Corr., 355 S.C.
  437, 443 n.4, 586 S.E.2d 124, 127 n.4 (2003).Â  Parole is a creature of statute
  and is exclusively in the province of the legislative branch of government.Â 
  The General Assembly empowers the Department to administer the parole program.Â  
The General Assembly established this parole privilege and
  identified which criminal offenses are parole-eligible by statute.Â  See Hair
    v. State, 305 S.C. 77, 79, 406 S.E.2d 332, 334 (1991) (discussing parole
  eligibility of certain offenses established by the General Assemblyâ€™s
  enactments); State v. De La Cruz, 302 S.C. 13, 16, 393 S.E.2d 184, 186
  (1990) (noting that the penalty established for a particular crime is purely a
  matter of legislative prerogative, and that â€œ[i]f the legislature so chooses,
  parole may not be made available to those who commit certain offensesâ€). 
Confined by these legislative enactments, and the doctrine of separation
  of powers, a sentencing court is not authorized to determine parole eligibility.Â 
  Instead, a courtâ€™s final judgment in a criminal case is the pronouncement of
  the sentence which includes the ability to designate whether sentences run
  concurrent or consecutive, subject to statutory restrictions.Â  State v.
    McKay, 300 S.C. 113, 115, 386 S.E.2d 623, 623 (1989); see De La
      Cruz, 302 S.C. at 15, 393 S.E.2d at 186 (â€œJudicial discretion in
  sentencing, in suspending sentences, and in designating that sentences run
  concurrent or consecutive is subject to statutory restriction.â€).Â  
In effectuating a sentencing courtâ€™s order, the Department has the
  sole authority to look to the statutes to determine whether a defendant is
  eligible for parole separate and apart from the courtâ€™s authority to sentence a
  defendant.Â  See Dingle, 376 S.C. at 649, 659 S.E.2d at 104-05
  (noting that the Department has the sole authority to determine parole
  eligibility separate and apart from the courtâ€™s ability to sentence); Cooper
    v. S.C. Depâ€™t of Prob., Parole & Pardon Servs., 377 S.C. 489, 496, 661 S.E.2d 106, 110 (2008) (same).Â  
Nevertheless, a court may order the Department to structure a
  sentence in such a way as to carry out the intent of the parties with regard to
  parole.Â  Tilley, 334 S.C. at 28-29, 511 S.E.2d at 692 (ordering the Department
  to consider the consecutive, five-year mandatory term for possession of a
  firearm as being served first such that the prisoner would be considered
  eligible for parole as the parties had intended).
Our law, however, is well-established that a sentencing judge does
  not have the authority to determine parole eligibility through sentencing.Â  McKay, 300 S.C. at 115, 386 S.E.2d at 623.Â  A sentencing court only has the ability to order whether a sentence is consecutive or concurrent.Â  See S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 16-23-490(B) (2003) (providing that a sentencing court may
  make the additional five years consecutive or concurrent). Â Â In other words, a
  sentencing judge has the authority to structure a sentence but this authority
  is specifically limited by the intention of the General Assembly in its
  legislative enactments concerning parole-eligible offenses and an inmateâ€™s
  service of a sentence.Â  The General Assembly has not statutorily authorized the
  courts or the Department to nullify its power to grant parole or determine
  parole-eligible offenses. 
The General Assembly has specifically
  identified certain crimes where the sentence must be consecutive and must be served last in time.Â  See, e.g., S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 16-15-395(D)
  (Supp. 2008) (providing that the sentence of a person convicted of first-degree
  criminal exploitation of a minor â€œmust run consecutively with and commence
    at the expiration of another sentence being servedâ€) (emphasis added).Â  Clearly,
  the General Assembly does not intend to define consecutive to mean last in
  time.Â  Significantly, the General Assembly has not indicated that a consecutive
  sentence on a weapons charge must be served last.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§
  16-23-490(B) (2003).Â  
With these principles in mind, we turn to the facts of
  the instant case. Â Initially, we note that it is not entirely clear what the
  sentencing judge intended as the sequence for Majorâ€™s sentence given there was
  no clear pronouncement in the sentencing sheets.Â  
However, even if the items in this case are construed
  as expressing a clear intent by the sentencing judge for Major to serve his
  murder sentence before the weapons sentence, we find the judge was not authorized to make Majorâ€™s
  normally parole-eligible sentence ineligible for parole.Â  Â An order to this
  effect would essentially create a de facto life without parole sentence
  which would defeat the parole privilege created by the General Assembly for
  Majorâ€™s murder charge.Â  Clearly, this would be a violation of the separation of
  powers doctrine.
Moreover, the Departmentâ€™s construction of
  the sentencing judgeâ€™s intent and interpretation of the law contradicts this Courtâ€™s
  pronouncement and rationale announced in State v. Atkins, 303 S.C. 214,
  399 S.E. 2d 760 (1990). Â In Atkins, this Court said â€œfor purposes of
  parole eligibility, consecutive sentences should be treated as one general
  sentence by aggregating the periods imposed in each sentence.â€Â  Id. at 219, 399 S.E.2d at 763 (citing Mims v. State, 273 S.C. 740, 259 S.E.
  2d 602 (1979)).Â  More importantly, for purposes of this case, the Atkins Court concluded that â€œ[m]ultiple life sentences cannot be aggregated in the
  imposition of prison time.Â  Accordingly, they are to be considered as one
  general sentence, the parole eligibility for which is 20 years.â€[5]Â  Id. Â This Court recognized
  its limitations and refused to invade the province of the General Assembly.
Adopting the reasoning of the Atkinsâ€™
  Court, it follows that if a consecutive life sentence could not nullify parole
  eligibility on a parolable life sentence, then a five-year consecutive sentence
  cannot either.
The question now becomes what is the
  efficacy of a consecutive sentence?Â  The answer is two fold.Â  First, following
  the guidance of Mims, the time is aggregated and parole eligibility is
  calculated on the aggregated sentence.Â  Secondly, if the consecutive sentence
  is a non- parolable offense then its sentence must be served and credited first
  against the aggregated sentence.Â  This is necessary to give effect to the
  legislative grant of parole eligibility on the parole-eligible offense.[6]
Considering the above discussion, the
  meaning of â€œconsecutiveâ€ needs further attention.Â  Because this term is not
  defined in our code of laws, we must employ the rules of statutory construction
  to ascertain and effectuate the intent of the General Assembly.Â  See Hawkins v. Bruno Yacht Sales, Inc., 353 S.C. 31, 39, 577 S.E.2d 202, 207
  (2003) (â€œThe cardinal rule of statutory construction is
  to ascertain and effectuate the intent of the legislature.â€); Hitachi Data Sys. Corp. v. Leatherman, 309 S.C. 174, 178, 420 S.E.2d 843, 846
  (1992) (stating the words of a statute must be given their plain and ordinary
  meaning without resorting to subtle or forced construction to limit or expand a
  statuteâ€™s operation); Lee v. Thermal Engâ€™g Corp., 352 S.C. 81, 91-92,
  572 S.E.2d 298, 303 (Ct. App. 2002) (â€œWhere a word is not defined in a statute,
  our appellate courts have looked to the usual dictionary meaning to supply its
  meaning.â€).
â€œConsecutiveâ€ means sentences run
  successively and the service of the sentence cannot run at the same time as the
  other sentences.Â  See Blackâ€™s Law Dictionary 1367 (7th ed.
  1999) (defining â€œconsecutive sentencesâ€ as â€œ[t]wo or more sentences of jail
  time to be served in sequence.Â  For example, if a defendant receives
  consecutive sentences of 20 years and 5 years, the total amount of jail time is
  25 years. - Also termed cumulative sentences; accumulative sentences.â€); Websterâ€™s Concise Dictionary 150 (2003) (â€œFollowing in uninterrupted
  succession; successive.â€); see generally R.P.D., Annotation, When
    Sentences Imposed by the Same Court Run Concurrently or Consecutively; and
    Definiteness of Direction with Respect Thereto, 70 A.L.R. 1511 (1931 &
  Supp. 2008) (outlining cases and discussing question of whether sentences on
  different counts or different offenses were intended to be served concurrently
  or consecutively and whether the sentence or sentences were sufficiently
  definite for the purpose intended).Â  
Thus, a notation that a sentence is
  â€œconsecutive,â€ for sentencing purposes, does not necessarily delineate that the
  particular sentence has to run last.Â  It merely indicates that all the
  sentences are to run successively, and not to run at the same time.Â  See Atkins, 303 S.C. at 219, 399 S.E.2d at 763 (noting that â€œfor purposes of parole eligibility, consecutive sentences
  should be treated as one general sentence by aggregating
  the periods imposed in each sentenceâ€).Â  Therefore, despite
  the fact that the weapons sentence was the last one imposed and it was denoted
  as â€œconsecutiveâ€ there was no indication that the weapons sentence was to be
  the last sentence to be served.Â  See Tilley,
  334 S.C. at 28-29, 511 S.E.2d at 692 (ordering the Department to treat the
  consecutive weapons sentence as being served first such that the inmate could
  be considered for parole).
The General Assembly has specifically
  noted several crimes with limits on parole, and it has not indicated that a
  mandatory weapons conviction will affect parole eligibility.Â  See, e.g.,
  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 16-3-20(A) (Supp. 2008) (holding a person convicted of murder
  with aggravating circumstances is not eligible for parole); S.C. Code Ann. Â§
  16-11-330(A) (2003) (providing that a person convicted of committing a robbery
  while armed with a deadly weapon must be sentenced to a mandatory minimum of
  ten years up to a maximum of thirty years, and the person will not be parole
  eligible until he or she has served at least seven years). 
Because there is no indication in section
  16-23-490 that the General Assembly intended the mandatory five-year sentence
  to completely negate any possibility of parole on other parolable offenses, we
  conclude the Departmentâ€™s interpretation of section 16-23-490 was erroneous
  given its decision amounts to a denial of parole eligibility for an offense the
  General Assembly has determined is eligible for parole.[7]Â  
CONCLUSION
Based on the terms of section 16-23-490 and the
  respective roles of the General Assembly, the sentencing court, and the Department,
  we hold the ALC correctly concluded that the Department erred in its
  determination of Majorâ€™s parole eligibility.Â  We modify the ALCâ€™s order to the
  extent the ALC based its decision solely on the Departmentâ€™s erroneous
  interpretation of the sequence of Majorâ€™s sentences.Â  Accordingly, the decision
  of the ALC is
AFFIRMED AS MODIFIED. Â 
WALLER, J., concurs. TOAL, C.J., concurring in a
  separate opinion. PLEICONES, J., dissenting in a separate opinion in which
  KITTREDGE, J., concurs.

CHIEF JUSTICE TOAL:Â  Although
  I concur with the majority opinion, I write separately to address the dissentâ€™s
  interpretation of State v. Atkins, 303 S.C. 214, 399 S.E.2d 760 (1990).Â 
  The dissent is correct to observe that we recognized in Atkins the
  logical impossibility of aggregating multiple life sentences.Â  However, the
  dissent errs in failing to extend that logic to the present case.Â  It is just
  as much a logical impossibility to aggregate multiple life sentences as it is
  to aggregate a life sentence with any other sentence.Â  Moreover, the
  lesson from Atkins as applied to the present case is that there is no
  sentence greater than life.Â  Whether aggregated to a five year sentence or a
  second life sentence, the ultimate time served remains the same.Â  Accordingly,
  I believe Atkins controls the inquiry in the present case, and stands
  for the proposition that a life sentence may not be aggregated with another
  sentence so as to affect parole eligibility where statute does not so provide.Â  

JUSTICE PLEICONES:Â  I respectfully dissent.Â  In my view, the sentence at
  issue here is unambiguous and not subject to interpretation.Â  Where a trial
  judge imposes two sentences, only one of which is denominated â€œconsecutive,â€ it
  of necessity follows the other.Â  Moreover, while I agree that a judicial
  officer is not empowered to determine whether parole will be granted, I
  fundamentally disagree with the suggestion that a judge cannot structure a
  sentence in such a way that the defendant is never eligible to be considered
  for parole.Â  In order to find that the Legislature intended such a result where
  a defendant is convicted of both a violent offense and of using a weapon in the
  commission of that offense, one need look no further than S.C. Code Ann. Â§
  16-23-490(B) (2003), which specifically authorizes the judge to make the five
  year weapons sentence consecutive.
 In interpreting
  sentences, the Department looks to the sentences imposed, not to the statutes.Â 
  Moreover, only if there is an ambiguity in the sentences, must the Department
  or the court ascertain the intent of the judge, not, as the majority suggests,
  the intent of the parties.Â  Finally, while certain parole eligibility
  determinations are statutorily committed to the Department,[8] as is the decision whether to grant parole,[9] there is no authority for the statement that a judge violates the separation of
  powers doctrine when he structures a sentence so that an otherwise
  parole-eligible defendant will never receive a hearing before the Board.Â  See cases collected in People v. Montgomery, 669 P.2d 1387 (Colo. 1983) (no separation of powers issue in sentence structuring).
Finally, I read Mims
  v. State, 273 S.C. 740, 259 S.E.2d 602 (1979) to hold that where a
  defendant receives consecutive sentences, they are to be â€œaggregated,â€ i.e.
  added together, in order to determine the date upon which the defendant first
  becomes parole eligible.Â  In State v. Atkins, 303 S.C. 214, 399 S.E.2d
  760 (1990), the Court simply recognized the logical impossibility of
  aggregating multiple life sentences.Â  Here, we are asked to aggregate a life
  sentence and a consecutive five year sentence, a sentence which the General
  Assembly specified could, in the sentencing judgeâ€™s discretion, be made
  consecutive.Â  The result is admittedly harsh,[10] and perhaps not desirable, however, it is not an unlawful sentence.
I would reverse the
  order of the ALC.
KITTREDGE, J., concurs.


[1]Â  Although the code provision in effect at the time
  Major committed the offenses in 1990 has since been amended, we cite to the
  current version of section 16-23-490 given there have been no substantive
  changes that would affect the decision in this case.Â  Act No. 184, 1993 S.C.
  Acts 3292.Â  
Section
  16-23-490 provides for additional punishment for persons possessing a weapon
  during the commission of a violent crime.Â  Persons who are in possession of a
  firearm or knife during the commission of a violent crime, and are convicted of
  the underlying violent crime, must additionally be sentenced to five years in
  prison.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 16-23-490(A) (2003).Â  The five-year sentence is
  mandatory and non-parolable.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 16-23-490(B), (C) (2003).Â  The
  statute further provides that a sentencing court may make the additional five
  years consecutive or concurrent.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 16-23-490(B) (2003).
[2]Â  At the time Major committed the murder, the
  applicable statute provided for parole eligibility after the service of twenty
  years on a sentence of life imprisonment.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 16-3-20(A) (1985).
[3]Â  Al-Shabbaz v. State, 338 S.C. 354, 527 S.E.2d
  742 (2000) (holding inmate was entitled to seek judicial review under
  Administrative Procedures Act after Department reached its final decision).
[4]Â  In Tilley, the defendant pled guilty to
  kidnapping, first-degree criminal sexual conduct, and possession of a firearm
  during the commission of a violent crime.Â  He was sentenced to life
  imprisonment for kidnapping, eighteen years for first-degree CSC, and five
  years for possession of a weapon during the commission of a violent crime.Â  The
  sentences were to be served consecutively.Â  Tilley, 334 S.C. at 26, 511
  S.E.2d at 690.Â  
Tilley filed a PCR
  application after the Department informed him by letter that he was ineligible
  for parole due to the consecutive nature of the sentencing structure.Â  Even
  though, in theory, Tilley was eligible for parole he was essentially ineligible
  because he was required to serve out his life term before serving the mandatory
  five-year term.Â  Id. at 27, 511 S.E.2d at 691.Â  
The PCR judge granted
  Tilley relief on this issue.Â  Because the sentencing judge did not order that
  Tilleyâ€™s sentences be served in a particular sequence, only that they be served
  consecutively, the PCR judge ordered that Tilleyâ€™s sentences be served in a way
  that corrected the Departmentâ€™s interpretation of his sentence.Â  Id. at 28-29, 511 S.E.2d at 692.
This Court agreed with the PCR judgeâ€™s
  decision to rearrange the order of Tilleyâ€™s sentences, placing the mandatory
  weapons sentence first, then the eighteen-year sentence for CSC, and finally
  the life sentence for kidnapping.Â  The Court reasoned that the order would
  still effectuate the intent of the sentencing court, but the consecutive,
  mandatory five-year sentence on the weapons charge would not affect parole
  eligibility on the other offenses.Â  Id. at 29, 511 S.E.2d at 692.
[5]Â  Atkins, like Major, was charged under the old law.Â 
  The old law allowed parole after service of twenty years. Atkins, 303
  S.C. at 219, 399 S.E.2d at 763.
[6]Â  The argument that this approach is
  contrary to prior practice was made in part by the dissent in Atkins to
  no avail.
[7]Â  Interestingly, service of the five-year mandatory,
  no-parole sentence is not always required.Â  See S.C. Code Ann. Â§
  16-23-490(B) (2003) (â€œService of the five-year sentence is mandatory unless a
  longer mandatory minimum term of imprisonment is provided by law for the
  violent crime.Â  The court may impose this mandatory five-year sentence to run
  consecutively or concurrently.â€).Â  
Major received a mandatory-minimum sentence which
  exceeded five years.Â  Thus, he is not necessarily required to serve the
  no-parole, five-year sentence.Â  If he is not required to serve it, then we
  question why it should prevent parole eligibility on an otherwise parolable
  offense.
[8] E.g.,
  whether multiple violent offenses are part of a continuous course of conduct.Â 
  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 24-21-640 (2003); State v. McKay, 300 S.C. 113, 386
  S.E.2d 623 (1984).
[9] S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 24-21-30 (2003).
[10] Respondent committed murder in 1990, at which
  time the possible sentences for murder were death, life with twenty year parole
  eligibility, or life with thirty year eligibility where an aggravating
  circumstance is found but a death sentence not imposed.Â  Â§ 16-3-20 (Supp.
  1990).Â  He received a â€œtwenty-yearâ€ life sentence.Â  In the weapons statute, the
  General AssemblyÂ  has specified that the five year weapons sentence â€œdoes not
  applyâ€ in only three situations: where the defendant is sentenced to death or
  to life without the possibility of parole, Â§ 16-23-490(A), or where a mandatory
  minimum sentence in excess of five years is required for the violent offense
  itself.Â  Â§ 16-23-490(B).Â  A person convicted of murder under the current
  statute would not be subject to the five year weapons sentence since the three
  sentencing choices currently are death, life without the possibility of parole,
  or a mandatory minimum thirty year sentence.Â  Â§ 16-3-20(A).Â  Respondent,
  however, is not subject to the â€œmandatory minimumâ€ exemption.
