THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court

	
		
			
				The Vestry and
      Church Wardens of the Church of the Holy Cross, a South Carolina Corporation, Respondent,
				v.
				Orkin
      Exterminating Company, Inc., Petitioner.
			
		
	


ON WRIT OF CERTIORARI TO THE COURT OF
  APPEALS

Appeal From Sumter County
Â Thomas W. Cooper, Jr., Circuit Court
  Judge
Opinion No. 26706
Heard February 3, 2009 - Filed August 24,
  2009Â Â  
REVERSED


	
		
			
				Ernest A.
  Finney, Jr., of The Finney Law Firm, of Sumter, J. Rutledge Young, III, of
  Duffy & Young, of Charleston, Kenneth R. Young, of Young, Reiter, Keffer
  & Donnald, of Sumter, and LeeAnn Jones, of Powell Goldstein, of Atlanta,
  for Petitioner.
				Thomas
  S. Tisdale, Jr., and David J. Parrish, both of Nexsen Pruet, of Charleston, for
  Respondent.
			
		
	


CHIEF
  JUSTICE TOAL: In this case,
  Respondents the Vestry and Church Wardens of the of the Church of the Holy
  Cross (â€œHoly Crossâ€) filed suit against Petitioner Orkin Exterminating Company
  (â€œOrkinâ€) for breach of contract.Â  The case was tried, and the jury returned a
  verdict for Orkin.Â  Shortly thereafter, the trial judge informed the parties
  that there were allegations of juror misconduct.Â  Holy Cross moved for a new
  trial.Â  After examining the jurors, the trial judge denied the motion.Â  The
  court of appeals reversed and remanded the case for a new trial.Â  See The
    Vestry & Church Wardens of the Church of the Holy Cross v. Orkin
    Exterminating Company, Inc., 373 S.C. 200, 644 S.E.2d 735 (Ct. App. 2007).Â 
  We granted Orkinâ€™s petition for a writ of certiorari to review the court of
  appealsâ€™ decision.Â Â Â  
Factual/Procedural
  Background
The Church of the
  Holy Cross is located in Sumter and listed on the National Historic Register as
  a National Historic Landmark.Â  In 1976, Holy Cross contracted with Orkin to
  annually treat and inspect the church for termites.Â  Holy Cross discovered
  termite damage in 2000 and brought this suit for breach of contract.Â  
A jury trial was
  conducted in August 2005.Â  Per his usual instructions, the trial judge
  instructed the jurors before swearing them in that they should not discuss the
  case among themselves or with any other person, and that they should not
  undertake any investigation into the facts or law not presented to them during the
  course of the trial.Â  At the end of a two-week trial, the jury returned a
  verdict in favor of Orkin.Â  
Three
  days later, the trial judge sent a letter to all parties to inform them of a
  possible case of juror misconduct.Â  The judge explained that he was contacted
  the morning after the trial by alternate juror Sherry Babb.Â  Babb informed him
  that juror Vicki Abrams had allegedly violated his instructions in the
  following instances: (1) early in the trial, Abrams questioned aloud the
  instructions not to talk about the case and made comments to other jurors in
  spite of these instructions; (2) she stated that â€œthe historic peopleâ€ â€œhave
  moneyâ€ and that Holy Cross was trying to get someone else to â€œpay their billsâ€
  when everyone knows that â€œold buildings fall downâ€; (3) she stated that she did
  not know why she had to hear both sides of the case and that she had discussed
  the case with her mother, who confirmed that â€œhistoric peopleâ€ have money and
  should â€œclean up their own messâ€; (4) she said she had talked to a painter who
  told her that termite damage can cause building walls to collapse; (5) she said
  that Holy Cross should tear down the church and bring in a double wide; and (6)
  on the day of deliberation, Abrams told jurors that she had prayed with her minister
  about the case, and that she had driven to Holy Cross over the weekend and that
  it looked fine to her.Â  Babb also informed the judge that the jurors admonished
  Abrams for violating his instructions and that the jurors paid little attention
  to Abramsâ€™ comments.Â  
Holy
  Cross filed a motion for new trial.Â  The trial judge summoned the jurors to
  appear at the courthouse on September 7, 2005, for sworn examinations.Â  The
  trial judge found that Babbâ€™s allegations were â€œin large measure . . .
  corroborated byâ€ the jurorsâ€™ testimony.Â  One jurorâ€™s testimony indicated that
  Abrams had commented that her minister had told her that â€œthe church should
  take care of the church,â€ and that â€œchurches need to stick together.â€Â  However,
  none of the jurors indicated that their final deliberations were affected by
  Abramsâ€™ misconduct.Â  
On
  November 10, 2005, the judge held a hearing on the issue of whether Abrams
  should be held in contempt of court.Â  Abramsâ€™s court-appointed attorney denied
  that she had committed any premeditated wrongdoing.Â  Nevertheless, the judge
  found Abrams to be in contempt of court.Â  
On
  February 22, 2006, the judge issued an order denying Holy Crossâ€™s motion for
  new trial.Â  The judge found that Holy Cross failed to â€œdemonstrate prejudice
  affecting the impartiality of the verdict,â€ and that â€œ[t]he statements and
  actions by Ms. Abrams were not of a kind to impermissibly influence the jury or
  effect the verdict.â€Â  The judge noted that there was nothing Abrams could have
  learned from driving to the church that was not already apparent from
  photographs in evidence.Â  Likewise, the judge found that the statement made by
  the painter was consistent with statements made by Holy Crossâ€™s witnesses and
  therefore did not unduly prejudice Abramsâ€™s deliberation.Â  Finally, the judge
  found that there was no evidence that Abramsâ€™s comments shaped the final
  deliberations or improperly influenced the other jurors, in light of the
  testimony indicating that the jurors admonished Abrams, â€œlaughed offâ€ her
  comments, and generally paid her little attention.Â  The judge concluded that,
  â€œhaving conducted an extensive individual voir dire of each juror and having
  viewed the conduct of the offending juror, this Court has found no indication
  that the juryâ€™s unanimous verdict was compromised, and [Holy Cross] has not
  made the showing of any prejudice by clear and convincing evidence, as required
  by the applicable case law.â€Â  Holy Cross appealed to the court of appeals.
In a
  split decision, the court of appeals reversed, holding that the trial judge
  erred in focusing his analysis on the eleven other jurors and in failing to
  adequately consider the question of whether Abramsâ€™s own conduct, which
  revealed her to be â€œunconcerned about granting [Holy Cross] the fair and
  impartial trial to which it was entitled,â€ deprived Holy Cross of its right to
  a fair trial.Â  In the opinion of the majority, under the circumstances of this
  case, â€œwhere at least one of [Abramsâ€™ acts of misconduct] was deemed so
  egregious by the trial judge that he punished [her] for criminal contempt, the
  failure of the trial judge to grant a new trial based upon those acts of
  misconduct amounts to an abuse of discretion.â€Â  373 S.C. at 206, 644 S.E.2d at
  739.Â  The dissent concluded that the trial judge conducted the appropriate procedure
  upon being presented with an allegation of misconduct, and did not err in
  denying Holy Crossâ€™s motion for new trial.Â  We granted a writ of certiorari to
  review the court of appealsâ€™ decision.Â  The following questions are presented
  for our review:

	
		
			I. 
			Did the court of appeals apply an
  incorrect standard of law regarding jury misconduct? 
 
		
		
			II.
			Did the court of appeals err in
  finding that the trial judge abused his discretion in denying Holy Crossâ€™s
  motion for new trial?
		
	


Standard
  of Review
The
  granting or refusing of a motion for a mistrial lies within the sound
  discretion of the trial court and its ruling will not be disturbed on appeal
  absent an abuse of discretion amounting to an error of law. Â State v. Harris, 340 S.C. 59, 63, 530 S.E.2d 626, 627-28
  (2000).Â  The trial court is in the
  best position to determine the credibility of the jurors; therefore, this Court
  grants broad deference on this issue. Â State v. Council, 335 S.C. 1, 12,
  515 S.E.2d 508, 514 (1999).
Law/Analysis
Orkin
  alleges that the court of appeals applied an incorrect standard of law
  regarding jury misconduct and erred in finding that the trial judge abused his
  discretion in denying Holy Crossâ€™s motion for new trial.Â  We agree on both counts.Â  
Under South Carolina law, litigants are guaranteed the
  right to an impartial jury. Â See S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 14-7-1050 (2008) (â€œin
  all civil cases any party shall have the right to demand a panel of twenty
  competent and impartial jurors from which to strike a jury.â€). Â If a potential
  juror has an interest in the lawsuit such that she is â€œnot indifferent in the cause,â€ the juror shall
  be deemed incompetent to serve on the jury. Â See S.C. Code Ann. Â§
  14-7-1020 (2008).
Misconduct
  that does not affect the juryâ€™s impartiality will not undermine a verdict. Â Harris, 340 S.C. at 63, 530 S.E.2d at 627. Â In determining whether outside influences have
  affected the jury, relevant factors include: (1) the number of jurors exposed,
  (2) the weight of the evidence properly before the jury, and (3) the likelihood
  that curative measures were effective in reducing the prejudice. Â Id. (citing Kelly, 331
  S.C. at 141-42, 502 S.E.2d at 104). Â The
  trial court has broad discretion in assessing allegations of juror misconduct,
  and should declare a mistrial only when absolutely necessary.Â  Council, 335 S.C. at 12, 515 S.E.2d at 514.Â  Instead, the trial court should exhaust
  other methods to cure possible prejudice before aborting a trial. Â Kelly,
  331 S.C. at 141-42, 502 S.E.2d at 104.Â  In order to receive a mistrial, the
  moving party must show error and resulting prejudice.Â  Id.
I.  Standard of Law in Cases of
  Juror Misconduct
Orkin
  first argues that the court of appeals applied the wrong standard of law by
  applying a general standard of â€œfundamental fairnessâ€ rather than the more specific
  standard of actual prejudice.[1]Â 
  Although considerations of â€œfundamental fairnessâ€ are relevant to analyses of
  jury misconduct, we agree that the court of appeals failed to grant due
  deference to the trial judgeâ€™s factual finding that Holy Cross did not suffer
  actual prejudice.
This Court has, in the past, used the language of â€œfundamental
  fairnessâ€ to describe the constitutional implications of juror misconduct.Â  See Shumpert
    v. State, 378
  S.C. 62, 661 S.E.2d 369 (2008) (holding that juror testimony involving internal misconduct â€œmay be
  received only when necessary to ensure fundamental fairnessâ€); State v.
    Aldret, 333 S.C. 307, 509 S.E.2d 811 (1999) (holding that premature jury
  deliberations â€œinvolve a matter of fundamental fairness.â€). Â However, not all
  juror misconduct impinges upon the fundamental fairness of a trial:Â  

	A
  defeated party is not entitled to a new trial for every act of misconduct by or
  affecting the jury, as such
  misconduct . . . does not ipso facto justify the grant of a new trial; but in order that a new trial may
  be granted on such ground the misconduct of the jury must relate to a material
  matter in dispute and must be such as to indicate an influence of bias or
  prejudice in the minds of the jurors.Â  

C.J.S. New Trial Â§ 54 (1998).Â  See also State v. Grovenstein,
  335 S.C. 347, 352, 517 S.E.2d 216, 218 (1999) (holding that misconduct does not
  entitle a party to mistrial unless it affects the verdict).
The
  court of appeals was thus entirely correct to discuss â€œfundamental fairnessâ€ in
  the context of jury misconduct.Â  The court erred, however, by invoking the premise
  of â€œfundamental fairnessâ€ - in the face of the trial judgeâ€™s determination that
  there was no evidence of actual prejudice - to support its conclusion that
  Abramsâ€™ misconduct was â€œso egregiousâ€ as to ipso facto justify the grant
  of a new trial.Â  The majorityâ€™s error is most evident from this passage:

	Although
  [Abrams] may not have learned anything from her visit to the site that she did
  not already know and her report to the other jurors of her actions may not have
  had any impact on them, [her] attempt to conduct an unsanctioned investigation
  into the facts of this case, when viewed with her other acts and comments,
  shows a juror unconcerned about granting Holy Cross the fair and impartial
  trial to which it was entitled.

373 S.C. at 207, 644 S.E.2d
  at 737.Â  The dissent correctly observed that the majority placed too much
  emphasis on the nature of Abramsâ€™ undoubtedly improper conduct and neglected
  the determinative question of whether this conduct deprived Holy Cross of a
  fair trial.Â  Id.Â  Indeed, in order to receive a mistrial, Holy Cross
  bore the burden of showing that Abramsâ€™ conduct deprived it of a fair and
  impartial trial, not merely that Abrams was â€œunconcernedâ€ about granting it a
  fair and impartial trial.Â  The trial judge conducted an extensive inquiry and
  concluded that, although improper, Abramsâ€™ misconduct did not actually
  influence the juryâ€™s verdict.Â  To the extent that the majority of the court of
  appeals reversed this determination because Abramsâ€™ lack of â€œconcernâ€ for her
  role as an impartial juror violated â€œfundamental fairness,â€ it was in error.Â  

II. Abuse of Discretion
Orkin
  next argues that the court of appeals erred in holding that the trial judge abused
  his discretion in finding that Abramsâ€™ conduct deprived Holy Cross of a fair
  and impartial trial.Â  We agree.Â  
As
  noted above, the majorityâ€™s reliance on an improper standard led it to conclude
  that â€œthe failure of the trial judge to grant a new trial based upon [Abramsâ€™]
  acts of misconduct amounts to an abuse of discretion.â€Â  Id.Â  In so
  holding, the majority appeared to be of the opinion that Abramsâ€™ participation
  in the deliberations was ipso facto evidence that her own bias tainted
  the juryâ€™s verdict.Â  Setting aside the legal problems with this conclusion -
  which are addressed above - it indicates that the majority failed to fully
  consider the facts as well.Â  Specifically, the trial judge examined the effect
  of Abramsâ€™s misconduct on the other jurorsâ€™ deliberations as well as her own.Â 
  The judgeâ€™s thorough fact-finding inquiry led him to the conclusion that Abrams
  did not expose herself to any evidence not already in the record.Â  
The
  trial judge thus found that there was no clear and convincing evidence that any
  of the twelve jurors - including Abrams - were improperly influenced by Abramsâ€™
  misconduct.Â  Bearing in mind the well-settled law that the refusal or grant of
  a mistrial â€œlies within the sound discretion of the trial court and its ruling
  will not be disturbed on appeal absent an abuse of discretion amounting to an
  error of law,â€ we hereby reverse the court of appeals. Â Harris, 340 S.C. at 63, 530 S.E.2d at 627-28. [2]Â  


Conclusion
For the reasons
  stated herein, we hereby reverse the court of appeals and reinstate the verdict
  for Orkin.Â  
WALLER, J., and
  Acting Justices E. C. Burnett, III and Alison R. Lee, concur. PLEICONES, J.,
  dissenting in a separate opinion.

JUSTICE PLEICONES:Â  I respectfully dissent and would affirm the Court
  of Appeals.Â  I agree with the Court of Appeals that it takes only one juror to
  deprive the parties of a fair and impartial trial.Â  While Abrams may not have
  influenced the other jurors, her actions and words are undeniable evidence of a
  juror who blatantly failed to honor her oath or to follow the instructions
  given her by the trial judge. I therefore agree with the majority of Court of
  Appeals and would uphold the grant of a new trial.


[1] â€œThe basic issue here, as we see it, is whether the juror misconduct in
  question affected Holy Crossâ€™ right to fundamental fairness at trial.â€Â  Holy
    Cross, 373 S.C. at 204, 644 S.E.2d at 737.Â  
[2] A review of this Courtâ€™s case law with regard to
  juror misconduct reveals few civil cases and even fewer instances where this
  Court has affirmed the finding that a mistrial was warranted.Â  See Shumpert
    v. State, 378 S.C. 62, 661 S.E.2d 369 (2008) (where a jurorâ€™s affidavit,
  alleging that deliberating jurors improperly considered defendantâ€™s failure to
  testify as evidence of guilt, did not raise sufficient questions of fundamental
  fairness so as to be admissible evidence of jury misconduct); State v.
    Pittman, 373 S.C. 527, 647 S.E.2d 144 (2007) (where a guilty vote by one
  juror was based on another jurorâ€™s reminder that everyone had to vote together
  to return a unanimous verdict, and a guilty vote by a second juror was based on
  other jurorsâ€™ insistence, were not instances of internal influence that
  implicated fundamental fairness such that defendant was entitled to a new
  trial); Alston v. Black River Elec. Co-op., 345 S.C. 323, 548 S.E.2d 858
  (2001) (holding that members of an electric cooperative should be per se disqualified from serving on a jury when the cooperative is a party); State
    v. Harris, 340 S.C. 59, 530 S.E.2d 626 (2000) (holding that jurorâ€™s
  misconduct in consulting legal dictionary for definitions of â€œmalice
  aforethoughtâ€ and â€œmanslaughterâ€ did not entitle defendant to new trial); State
    v. Aldret, 333 S.C. 307, 509 S.E.2d 811 (1999) (holding that although premature
  jury deliberations could affect fundamental fairness of a trial, defendant was
  procedurally barred from receiving a new trial);Â  State v. Grovenstein,
  335 S.C. 347, 517 S.E.2d 216 (1999) (holding that an alternate jurorâ€™s presence
  in jury room during first 20 to 30 minutes of deliberations was not grounds for
  mistrial); State v. Council, 335 S.C. 1, 515 S.E.2d 508 (1999) (holding
  that the trial judge did not abuse his discretion in death penalty case by
  refusing to disqualify juror, who was initially uncertain as to whether she
  could presume defendant was innocent, where each time judge clearly explained
  law juror affirmed she could presume defendant innocent); State v. Kelly,
  331 S.C. 132, 502 S.E.2d 99 (1998) (holding that a jurorâ€™s misconduct in
  sharing pro-death penalty pamphlet with other jurors during penalty phase did
  not violate defendantâ€™s right to fair trial); State v. Wasson, 299 S.C.
  508, 386 S.E.2d 255 (1989) (where the fact that two jurors read newspaper
  article discussing alleged, extraneous crimes by defendant and summarizing
  testimony did not entitle defendant to mistrial); Stone v. City of Florence,
  203 S.C. 527, 28 S.E.2d 409 (1943) (where, in action against city for injuries
  sustained by stepping into an unprotected drain-hole, some of the jurors visited
  the scene of accident and stepped from the curb into the hole, plaintiff was
  not entitled to a new trial on this ground).Â

title: Neal v. Brown
description: In this case, the Office of Ocean and Coastal Resource Management (OCRM) granted Respondent Neal a dock permit.  Petitioner Brown, an adjacent property owner, appealed the award of the permit, claiming that the issuance of the permit did not comply with OCRM regulations.  The Court of Appeals held that Respondent was entitled to a dock permit.  The Supreme Court granted a writ of certiorari and reversed the Court of Appeals decision, holding that the regulatory language was clear and unambiguous and the OCRM Appellate Panel is entitled to deference in the interpretation of its own regulations.

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court

	
		
			
				David Neal, Respondent,
				v.
				Don H. Brown
      and South Carolina Department of Health and Environmental Control, Office of
      Ocean and Coastal Resource Management, Defendants,
				of whom Don H.
      Brown is the Petitioner.
			
		
	


ON WRIT OF CERTIORARI TO THE COURT OF
  APPEALS

Appeal from Charleston County
Â Mikell R. Scarborough, Circuit Court
  Judge
Opinion No.Â  26707
Heard March 5, 2009 - Filed August 24,
  2009Â  
REVERSED


	
		
			
				Andrew
  Epting, Jr., of Charleston, Clayton B. McCullough, and Daniel S. McQueeney,
  Jr., both of Pratt-Thomas & Walker, of Charleston, for Petitioner.
				Michael
  A. Molony and Lea B. Kerrison, both of Young, Clement Rivers, of Charleston,
  for Respondent.
			
		
	


CHIEF JUSTICE TOAL:Â  In
  this case, the Office of Ocean and Coastal Resource Management (OCRM) granted
  Respondentâ€™s application for a dock permit, and Petitioner appealed to the
  administrative law court (ALC).Â  The ALC affirmed, and Petitioner appealed to
  OCRMâ€™s Appellate Panel, which reversed the grant of the permit.Â  Respondent
  appealed to the circuit court, which affirmed the Appellate Panelâ€™s ruling.Â 
  Respondent then appealed the Court of Appeals, which reversed the circuit court
  and held that Respondent was entitled to a dock permit.Â  We granted Petitioner
  a writ of certiorari to review the Court of Appealsâ€™ decision.Â Â Â  
Factual/Procedural Background
In 1997, the McIver
  family conveyed three parcels of land in â€œOld Villageâ€ Mount Pleasant to Neal
  Brothers, Inc., of which Respondent David Neal (â€œNealâ€) is a part owner.Â  The
  bulk of Nealâ€™s property is inland, and connected to Charleston Harbor by a narrow 5 foot wide, 119 foot long strip of property.Â  Neal conducted a survey of
  the three parcels prior to the purchase, and recorded the survey with the
  Charleston County Register of Mesne Conveyances on September 10, 1997.Â 
  Sometime thereafter, Neal Brothers transferred title of the property to
  Tompkins and Company, LLC (â€œTompkinsâ€), which is also partly owned by Neal.Â  
In 1998, Neal first
  applied for a critical area permit to build a dock from the propertyâ€™s five
  feet of â€œwater frontage.â€Â  The OCRM denied the first application on the grounds
  that the lot â€œdoes not meet the minimum lot width standard in order to qualify
  for a single family dock.â€Â  Neal filed and then withdrew an appeal, on the
  understanding that he could reapply for a permit. 
In September 1999,
  an adjacent property owner claimed ownership of the narrow strip that connects
  Nealâ€™s property to the water.Â  The trial court examined both chains of title
  and determined that Neal (through Tompkins) owned the property in fee simple
  absolute.Â  
In June 2001, Neal
  resubmitted his application for a critical area dock permit.Â  At the time, the
  regulation controlling dock permits provided:
For lots
  platted and recorded after May 23, 1993, before a dock will be permitted, a lot
  must have 75 feet of water frontage along the marsh edge and at least 75 feet
  of frontage between extended property lines . . . .Â  Lots less than 50 feet
  wide are not eligible for a dock.
23A S.C. Code Ann. Regs.
  30-12(A)(2)(o) (Supp. 2001) (â€œthe regulationâ€).Â  On September 12, 2001, the
  OCRM issued Neal a critical area dock permit, which allowed him to construct a
  4 foot wide, 300 foot long dock from his 5 feet of â€œwater frontage.â€Â 
  Petitioner Don Brown (â€œBrownâ€), an adjacent property owner, appealed the
  issuance of the dock permit to the ALC, arguing that the property was not
  platted and recorded until 1997 and therefore did not comply with the
  regulation.Â  The ALC found that â€œ[t]he term â€˜platted and recordedâ€™ assumes the
  platting and recording involves a change in the configuration of the
  property.â€Â  Finding that the 1997 recording of the survey was not the type of platting
  and recording intended to fall within the purview of the regulation, but was
  merely an action necessary to the purchase of land that had existed in the same
  configuration for over fifty years, the ALC upheld the issuance of the permit.Â  
Brown appealed the ALCâ€™s decision to the OCRMâ€™s Coastal Zone Management Appellate Panel (â€œthe
  Panelâ€).Â  The Panel issued a brief opinion in which it reversed the issuance of
  the permit on the grounds that the ALC erred in holding that the 1997 recording
  did not constitute a platting and recording for the purposes of the
  regulation.Â  
Neal appealed the
  Panelâ€™s decision to the circuit court, which affirmed the Panel.Â  Neal then
  appealed to the Court of Appeals, which reversed the circuit court in a split
  decision.Â  David Neal v. Don H. Brown and South Carolina Department of
    Health and Environmental Control, Office of Ocean and Coastal Resource
    Management, 374 S.C. 641, 649 S.E.2d 164 (Ct. App. 2007).Â  The majority of
  the court found that there was substantial evidence in the record to support
  the ALCâ€™s finding that the regulation did not bar Nealâ€™s dock permit because
  the property had been in the current configuration since 1940 and the 1997
  survey did not amount to having the property â€œplatted and recordedâ€ under the
  regulation.Â  The majority also found that the circuit court erred in making new
  findings of fact on matters not decided by the Panel.Â  Brown petitioned this
  Court for a writ of certiorari, and we granted the writ to answer the following
  question:

	Did the
  Court of Appeals err in reversing the circuit court and upholding the issuance
  of Respondentâ€™s dock permit?

Standard
  of Review
In permitting cases, the ALC serves as the finder of
  fact.Â  Brown v. South Carolina Depâ€™t of Health & Env. Control, 348
  S.C. 507, 520, 560 S.E.2d 410, 417 (2002).Â  The Panel can reverse the ALC if
  the findings are not supported by substantial evidence or are based on an error
  of law.Â  Dorman v. South Carolina Depâ€™t of Health & Env.
    Control, 350 S.C. 159, 165, 565 S.E.2d 119, 122 (Ct. App. 2002).Â  Judicial
  review of the Panelâ€™s decision is governed by S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 1-23-380(A)(5)
  (Supp. 2006), which provides:

	The
  court may not substitute its judgment for the judgment of the agency as to the
  weight of the evidence on questions of fact.Â  The court may affirm the decision
  of the agency or remand the case for further proceedings.Â  The court may
  reverse or modify the decision if substantial rights of the appellant have been
  prejudiced because the administrative findings, inferences, conclusions, or
  decisions are:
	(a)  in violation of constitutional or statutory
  provisions;
	(b)  in excess of the statutory
  authority of the agency;
	(c) Â made upon unlawful procedure;
	(d)  affected by other error of law;
	(e)  clearly erroneous in view of the reliable, probative,
  and substantial evidence on the whole record; or
	(f)   arbitrary and capricious or characterized by abuse of
  discretion or clearly unwarranted exercise of discretion.

Law/Analysis
The
  central question in this case is whether Nealâ€™s property was â€œplatted and
  recordedâ€ after May 23, 1993.Â  The Panel and the circuit court held that Nealâ€™s
  1997 survey constituted a â€œplatâ€ under the regulation, and therefore, because
  Nealâ€™s water frontage is less than 75 feet, Neal should not be granted a
  critical area dock permit.Â  The Court of Appeals held that Nealâ€™s 1997 survey
  did not constitute a â€œplat.â€Â  We agree with the former interpretation therefore
  reverse the Court of Appeals.Â  
We
  find this matter foreclosed by the fact that no single plat of the property in question
  was recorded prior to May 23, 1993.Â  The McIver property initially consisted of
  three distinct parcels, each recorded separately with its own separate deed.Â 
  Neal purchased these parcels together in 1997, conducted a â€œsurvey,â€ and
  recorded the property for the first time as a single lot.[1]Â 
  These facts alone indicate that this single piece of property was first
  â€œplatted and recordedâ€ after May 23, 1993, and that the regulation precludes
  the granting of a critical area dock permit.Â Â Â  
Furthermore,
  the majority of the Court of Appeals relied heavily on OCRM employee Richard
  Chinnisâ€™s testimony before the ALC as to his interpretation of the term
  â€œplat.â€Â  Chinnis drafted the regulation, and testified that the word â€œplatâ€ as
  used in the regulation, was intended to indicate a subdivision of property, not
  the recordation of a survey.Â  Based upon this testimony, the Court of Appeals
  concluded that Nealâ€™s â€œsurveyâ€ did not constitute a â€œplatâ€ that would bring him
  under the scope of the regulation, even though the Panel disagreed with
  Chinnisâ€™s interpretation.Â  
We
  find that the Court of Appeals erred in granting Chinnisâ€™s testimony deference
  over the Panelâ€™s interpretation for two reasons.Â  First, as we have previously
  held, an agencyâ€™s Appellate Panel, not its staff, is typically entitled to
  deference in interpreting agency regulations.Â  S.C. Coastal Conservation
    League v. S.C. Depâ€™t of Health & Env. Control, 363 S.C. 67, 75, 610
  S.E.2d 482, 486 (2005).Â  The majority of the Court of Appeals should have
  deferred to the Panelâ€™s interpretation, rather than Chinnisâ€™s.
Second,
  the regulatory language is clear and unambiguous, and the Court of Appeals
  erred in interpreting the regulation to permit the issuance of a dock permit.Â 
  â€œWhen a statuteâ€™s terms are clear and unambiguous on their face, there is no
  room for statutory construction and a court must apply the statute according to
  its literal meaning.â€Â  Sloan v. Hardee, 371 S.C. 495, 498, 640 S.E.2d
  457, 459 (2007).Â  In our reading, the distinction between a â€œsurveyâ€ and a
  â€œplatâ€ is illusory.Â  The key question is whether a piece of real property was
  mapped and recorded for the first time after the effective date of May 23,
  1993.Â  Chinnisâ€™s testimony indicates that he believed the regulation was
  intended to prevent the owners of newly-subdivided lots from building
  docks on less than seventy-five feet of water frontage.Â  However, this could
  have been easily incorporated into the language of the regulation if this was
  the true intent.Â  We believe the plain language of the regulation indicates
  that it was intended to prevent owners of all newly created lots - whether
  subdivided or amalgamated (as in the present case) - from building docks on
  less than seventy-five feet of water frontage.Â  Notwithstanding Chennisâ€™s
  involvement in the drafting of the regulation, the Panel is entitled to
  deference in interpreting its own regulation, and it found that the regulation
  prevented the granting of a permit in this case.Â  In our view, the plain
  language of the regulation supports this interpretation.Â  
Conclusion
For the reasons
  stated herein, we reverse the opinion of the Court of Appeals.Â  
WALLER,
  J., and Acting Justices James E. Moore, Perry M. Buckner and Brooks P.
  Goldsmith, concur.



[1] The current boundary of the property was actually first recorded in 2001, after
  a challenge by an adjacent landowner resulted in some minor changes to the
  configuration of the property.Â

title: Turner v. State
description: The Court affirms the PCR courtâ€™s denial of relief and holds that probation counsel was not ineffective for failing to inform the probationer of his right to appeal his probation revocation.

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court

	
		
			
				Harold B.
      Turner, Petitioner,
				v.
				State of South
      Carolina, Respondent.
			
		
	


ON WRIT OF CERTIORARI

Appeal from Spartanburg County
Â John M. Milling, Circuit Court Judge
Opinion No. 26708
Submitted April 22, 2009 - Filed August
  24, 2009Â Â  
AFFIRMED


	
		
			
				Deputy
  Chief Appellate Defender Wanda H. Carter, of South Carolina Commission on
  Indigent Defense, of Columbia, for Petitioner.
				Attorney
  General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney General John W. McIntosh,
  Assistant Deputy Attorney General Salley W. Elliott, Assistant Attorney General
  Prentiss Counts, all of Columbia, for Respondent.
			
		
	


CHIEF JUSTICE
  TOAL: In this case, the Court granted
  a writ of certiorari to review the post-conviction relief (PCR) courtâ€™s denial
  of relief to Petitioner Harold B. Turner.
Factual/Procedural Background

In
  1994, Petitioner pled guilty to second degree burglary and was sentenced to
  fifteen years imprisonment, suspended upon time served and five years
  probation.Â  Subsequently, his probation was revoked.Â  Petitioner did not
  directly appeal his probation revocation.Â  Petitioner filed an application for
  PCR alleging probation counsel was ineffective for failing to advise him of his
  right to a direct appeal.Â  
At
  the PCR hearing, Petitioner testified that after the revocation hearing, he
  asked probation counsel, â€œWhat can we do?â€ and that counsel responded â€œthe
  judge made his ruling,â€ and testified that he would have requested an appeal if
  he had known his rights.Â  Probation counsel testified that there were no
  appealable issues stemming from the probation revocation and that Petitioner
  never inquired about an appeal.Â  The PCR court found that there were no
  non-frivolous grounds for an appeal and that no extraordinary circumstances
  existed and denied Petitioner relief.Â  
This
  Court granted Petitionerâ€™s request for a writ of certiorari, and Petitioner
  presents the following issue for review:

	Did the
  PCR court err in finding probation counsel was not ineffective in failing to
  advise Petitioner of his right to a direct appeal from his probation
  revocation?

Standard of Review
The burden of proof is on the applicant in post-conviction
  proceedings to prove the allegations in his application.Â  Butler v. State, 286
  S.C. 441, 442, 334 S.E.2d 813, 814 (1985).Â  On certiorari, the PCR courtâ€™s ruling should be upheld if
  it is supported by any evidence of probative value in the record.Â  Cherry v. State, 300 S.C. 115, 119,
  386 S.E.2d 624, 626 (1989).Â  However, this Court will reverse the PCR courtâ€™s
  decision when it is controlled by an error of law.Â  Pierce v. State, 338
  S.C. 139, 145, 526 S.E.2d 222, 225 (2000).
Law/Analysis
As a
  primary matter, we must first address the basis upon which Petitioner claims he
  is entitled to relief.Â  Since Petitioner seeks relief due to ineffective
  assistance of counsel, Petitioner bases his PCR application on a violation of
  his Sixth Amendment right to counsel.Â  See Duckson v. State, 355 S.C.
  596, 598, 586 S.E.2d 576, 577 (2003), citing McKnight v. State, 320 S.C. 356, 465 S.E.2d 352 (1995) (observing that an ineffective assistance claim is premised on the violation of an individualâ€™s Sixth
  Amendment right to counsel).Â  However, a probationer does not have a Sixth
  Amendment right to counsel.[1]Â  Rather, the right to counsel
  may arise pursuant to the Due Process Clause under the Fifth and Fourteenth
  Amendments.Â  See Gagnon v. Scarpelli, 411 U.S. 778, 790 (1973).[2]Â  In South Carolina, however, all persons charged with
  probation violations have a right to counsel and must be informed of this right
  pursuant to court rules and case law.Â  Barlet v. State, 288 S.C. 481,
  483, 343 S.E.2d 620, 621 (1986); Rule 602(a), SCACR.
In Duckson,
  the parolee filed an application for PCR alleging that he received ineffective
  assistance of counsel at his parole revocation hearing.Â  In South Carolina, a
  parolee has a statutory right to have counsel present at a parole revocation
  hearing[3] but,
  similar to a probationer, does not have a Sixth Amendment right to counsel.Â  As Duckson makes clear, neither a parolee nor a probationer has a Sixth
  Amendment right to counsel.Â  Accordingly, this Court held that because the
  parolee could not assert a Sixth Amendment violation and because he did not
  contend his due process rights were violated, the parolee failed to allege the
  parole revocation was unlawful and thus failed to state a claim cognizable in a PCR action.Â  
We find
  the Duckson analysis instructive to the instant case.Â  Although parole
  revocation and probation revocation are different types of proceedings,[4] to the extent there is a
  constitutional right to counsel in either context, it exists only by virtue of
  the Due Process Clause.Â  See Gagnon,
  411 U.S. 778, 782 n.3 (observing that, despite minor differences between parole
  and probation, the revocation of probation is constitutionally
  indistinguishable from the revocation of parole).Â  Petitioner has only alleged
  a Sixth Amendment violation, namely that probation counsel was ineffective in failing to inform him of his right
  to a direct appeal, and thus, under Duckson, it appears he has failed to
  state a cognizable claim in a PCR action.

However, Duckson is distinguishable from the instant case in an important respect.Â 
  Unlike a parolee, we have held that, pursuant to court rule, a probationer has
  a right to counsel.Â  See Barlet and Rule 602(a).Â  A paroleeâ€™s statutory right to have counsel present is not
  comparable to a probationerâ€™s absolute right under state law to appointed
  counsel.Â  We now hold that because
  a probationer has a right to counsel, albeit not a Sixth Amendment right, the
  same analysis for ineffectiveness that applies in other PCR proceedings involving
  claims against counsel should, by analogy, apply in PCR proceedings involving
  claims against probation counsel.Â  In our view, this approach does not elevate
  form over substance by, for example, allowing a probationer to proceed on a due
  process violation but not allowing him to proceed on an ineffective assistance claim
  despite the fact that both claims stem from the failure to be informed of his
  right to appeal.Â  Additionally, this approach eases confusion as well as the
  burden on the lower courts by providing a uniform standard.[5]
To this end, we must
  determine whether, under our Strickland jurisprudence, probation counsel
  was ineffective for failing to inform Petitioner of his right to appeal the
  revocation of his probation.Â  We hold
  that he was not.Â  
Following
  a trial, counsel must inform a defendant who has been found guilty of a crime of the possibility of an appeal and the
  method for taking an appeal.Â  Frasier v.
    State, 306 S.C. 158, 161, 410 S.E.2d 572, 574 (1991).Â  In a plea
  proceeding, however, there is no requirement that plea
  counsel inform a defendant of the right to a direct appeal absent extraordinary
  circumstances.Â  Weathers v. State, 319
  S.C. 59, 61, 459 S.E.2d 838, 839 (1995); see also Roe v. Flores-Ortega, 528 U.S. 470 (2000) (holding that counsel
  has a constitutional duty to inform a defendant of his right to appeal a guilty
  plea if there is reason to think that a rational defendant would want to appeal
  or that the defendant demonstrated an interest in appealing).[6]
We
  hold that probation counsel is not required to inform a probationer of his
  right to an appeal absent extraordinary circumstances.Â  This holding is in
  accord with counselâ€™s duties at a plea hearing.Â  See Weathers,
  319 S.C. at 61, 459 S.E.2d at 839 (holding that, â€œabsent extraordinary
  circumstances, there is no constitutional requirement that a defendant be
  informed of the right to a direct appeal from a guilty plea.â€).Â  In our view, a probationer should not be afforded additional protections
  in a probation revocation hearing, a proceeding that is not a stage of criminal
  prosecution and that occurs after sentencing, which are not constitutionally
  mandated in a guilty plea hearing.Â  In other words, probation counsel is not held
  to a higher performance standard than that imposed upon plea counsel.Â  
In
  the instant case, the PCR court found probation counselâ€™s testimony more
  credible than Petitionerâ€™s testimony. Â Additionally, there is evidence in the
  record to support the PCR courtâ€™s finding that there were no non-frivolous grounds for an appeal and
  that no extraordinary circumstances existed.Â  Accordingly, because Petitioner failed to show extraordinary circumstances, he
  is not entitled to relief.

Conclusion
For these reasons,
  we affirm the PCR courtâ€™s order denying Petitioner relief.Â  
WALLER,
  PLEICONES, BEATTY and KITTREDGE, JJ., concur.


[1] In Huckaby v. State, 305 S.C. 331, 408 S.E.2d 242 (1991), we held that a
  probationer must be informed of his right to counsel and he must make a willing
  and knowing waiver of counsel.Â  We also stated that â€œa
  probationer retains his full Sixth Amendment right to counsel.â€Â  Id. at 335, 408 S.E.2d at 244.Â  Because a probationer does not have a Sixth
  Amendment right to counsel, this statement is incorrect, and any interpretation
  of the opinion asserting that a probationer is afforded the same constitutional
  protections as an accused is erroneous.Â  A South Carolina probationerâ€™s right
  to counsel in a probation revocation hearing is grounded in our case law and
  court rules.Â  A constitutional right to counsel may arise pursuant to
  the Due Process Clause, but cannot arise pursuant to the Sixth Amendment.
[2] In Gagnon v. Scarpelli, the Supreme Court held that whether a probationer has a
  constitutional right to counsel in a revocation hearing should be decided on a
  case-by-case basis, taking into consideration the complexity of alleged
  violations and whether the probationer can meaningfully contest the alleged
  violations.Â  
[3] S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 24-21-50 (Supp. 2002).
[4] Parole eligibility is a collateral consequence of sentencing and
  is a matter that falls within the province of the Board of Probation, Parole,
  and Pardon Services.Â  Brown
    v. State, 306
  S.C. 381, 382, 412 S.E.2d 399, 400 (1991); S.C.
  Code Ann. Â§ 24-21-13 (Supp. 2006).Â  Probation,
  on the other hand, is a matter within the jurisdiction of the trial court and
  is judicially-imposed at the time
  of sentencing.Â  Duckson, 355 S.C. at 598 n. 2, 586 S.E.2d at 578 n. 2; S.C.
  Code Ann. Â§ 24-21-450 (Supp. 2006).Â  
[5] Our holding today does not alter our PCR jurisprudence regarding claims of
  ineffective assistance of counsel, nor should it be interpreted as creating
  additional rights to PCR applicants.Â  Indeed, this Court has granted relief
  based on â€œineffective assistanceâ€ of PCR counsel despite the fact that the
  right to PCR counsel arises from Rule 71.1, SCRCP, and not from the
  constitution.Â  See e.g., Washington v. State, 324 S.C. 232, 478 S.E.2d
  833 (1996) (granting PCR where the defendant alleged ineffective assistance of
  PCR counsel due to so many procedural irregularities) and Austin v. State,
  305 S.C. 453, 409 S.E.2d 395 (1991) (recognizing that the constitutional right
  to counsel does not extend to discretionary appeals on collateral attack, but
  allowing a PCR applicant to receive a belated appeal from the denial of his
  initial PCR application where first PCR counsel failed to file a notice of
  appeal); but see Aice v. State, 305 S.C. 448, 451, 409 S.E.2d 392, 394 (1991) (holding
  that an allegation that prior PCR counsel was ineffective is not per se a sufficient reason allowing for a successive PCR application).Â  
[6] Although decided prior to Flores-Ortega, the Weathers analysis is
  compatible with the Flores-Ortega analysis and remains good law.

title: Richardson v. P.V., Inc.
description: The Court affirms the trial courtâ€™s entry of default and holds that service of process was effective and that the defendant failed to show good cause to set aside the entry of default.

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court

	
		
			
				Leola
      Richardson as Personal Representative of the Estate of Dominick Richardson, Respondent,
				v.
				P.V., Inc. and
      Harbor Inn, Inc., Appellants.
			
		
	

Appeal from Georgetown County
Â Benjamin H. Culbertson, Circuit Court
  Judge
Opinion No.Â  26709
Heard May 28, 2009 - Filed August 24, 2009Â  
AFFIRMED


	
		
			
				J.
  Dwight Hudson and Mary A. Graham, both of Hudson Law Firm, of Myrtle Beach, for
  Appellants.
				William
  Walker, Jr., of Walker & Morgan, of Lexington, for Respondent.
			
		
	


CHIEF JUSTICE TOAL:Â  Respondent filed suit against Appellants following the drowning
  death of Respondentâ€™s son.Â  Appellants failed to respond to the complaint and
  an entry of default was entered.Â  The trial court denied Appellantsâ€™ motion to
  lift the entry of default.Â  This appeal follows.
Factual/Procedural Background
On June 19, 2004, Dominick Richardson drowned in the
  swimming pool at Harbor Inn, a hotel owned by Jay Patidar located in Georgetown,
  South Carolina.Â  Respondent filed survival and wrongful death actions arising
  out of the drowning.Â  On May 12, 2005, a process server, Bobby Asbill, arrived
  at the Harbor Inn to serve the summons and complaint and asked the employee
  working at the desk, Demetria Cruel, if he could speak with the manager.Â  Cruel
  informed Asbill that Patidar[1] was out of town for several days.Â  
In
  her deposition, Cruel testified that Asbill told her that he was not coming
  back to the hotel and asked if she would call Patidar.Â  She complied and gave
  the phone to Asbill, but testified that she could not hear their conversation.Â 
  Cruel testified that after the phone conversation was finished, Asbill left the
  papers and walked out of the hotel.Â  She later spoke with Patidar and informed
  him that Asbill left the papers.Â  Patidar instructed Cruel to fax the summons
  and complaint to his insurance agent.Â  
Asbill
  testified that when he spoke to Patidar on the phone, he identified himself and
  the reason for his visit.Â  Patidar told him that he could leave the papers with
  Cruel or that he could come back when Patidar was there.Â  Asbill also testified
  that he asked Cruel if Patidar gave her permission to accept the papers and she
  said â€œyes.â€Â  
Finally,
  Patidar testified that he told Asbill that he would be back in four or five
  days, but that Asbill told him that he (Asbill) was not coming back.Â  Patidar
  then told Asbill it was up to Asbill whether or not to leave the papers.Â  
Appellants
  failed to answer the complaint and an entry of default was entered on June 24,
  2005.Â  Appellants subsequently moved to set aside the entry of default.Â  The trial
  court denied the motion finding that service was effective, thereby conferring
  personal jurisdiction on the court, and that Appellants failed to show good
  cause to set aside the entry of default.Â  This Court certified the appeal
  pursuant to Rule 204(b), SCACR, and Appellants present the following issues for
  review:

	
		
			I. 
			Did the trial court err in ruling that
  service of process was effective and that the court therefore had personal
  jurisdiction over Appellants?
 
		
		
			II.
			Did the trial court err in ruling
  that Appellants failed to show good cause to set aside the entry of default?
		
	

Standard of Review

The decision whether to set aside an entry of default or a default
  judgment lies solely within the sound discretion of the trial court.Â  Roberson v. S. Fin. of South Carolina, Inc., 365 S.C. 6, 9, 615 S.E.2d 112,
  114 (2005).Â  The trial courtâ€™s decision
  will not be disturbed on appeal absent a clear showing of an abuse of that
  discretion.Â  Id.Â  
Law/Analysis
I. Service of Process
Appellants argue the trial court erred in
  finding service of process was effective.Â  We disagree.
Service
  upon a corporation may be made â€œby delivering a copy of the summons and
  complaint to an officer, a managing or general agent, or to any other agent
  authorized by appointment or by law to receive service of process.â€Â  Rule
  4(d)(3), SCRCP.Â  Rule 4 serves at least two purposes: it confers personal
  jurisdiction on the court and assures the defendant of reasonable notice of the
  action.Â  Roche v. Young Bros., Inc. of Florence, 318 S.C. 207, 209, 456
  S.E.2d 897, 899 (1995).Â  Exacting
  compliance with the rules is not required to effect service of process.Â  Id.Â  

Not every employee of a corporation is an agent of the corporation
  for the purposes of service of process.Â  See Roberson, 365 at
  115, 615 S.E.2d at 11 (holding that a clerical employee was not an agent
  authorized to accept service of process for the corporation).Â  Whether an
  employee may accept service on behalf of a corporation depends on the authority
  the corporation conferred upon the employee.Â  In order to determine whether an
  employee is an authorized agent, the court must look to the circumstances
  surrounding the relationship and find authority which is either express or
  implied from the type of relationship between the defendant and the alleged
  agent.Â  Moore v. Simpson, 322 S.C. 518, 523, 473 S.E.2d 64, 67 (Ct. App.
  1996).Â  While actual authority is expressly conferred upon the agent by the
  principal, apparent authority is when the principal knowingly permits the agent
  to exercise authority, or the principal holds the agent out as possessing such
  authority.Â  Roberson, 365 at 115, 615 S.E.2d at 10-11.
In the instant case, even if Cruel did not have actual authority,
  we find that she had apparent authority to accept service of process.Â  When Asbill initially entered the hotelâ€™s office,
  Cruel was the only employee present, which represented to third parties that
  she was in charge.Â  Asbill testified that Patidar told him that he could leave
  the papers with Cruel or that he could come back.Â  Patidar similarly testified
  that he told Asbill it was up to him whether to leave the papers.Â  Under these
  facts, we find that Patidar knowingly permitted Cruel to exercise authority to
  accept service of process and further find that his manifestations to Asbill
  indicated that Cruel had such authority. 
For
  these reasons, we hold that evidence in the record supports the trial courtâ€™s
  finding that Cruel was authorized to accept service.Â  Brown v. Carolina Emergency Physicians, P.A., 348 S.C. 569, 583, 560 S.E.2d 624, 631 (Ct. App. 2001) (recognizing that the findings of the circuit court on factual issues arising
  on a motion to quash service of process for lack of jurisdiction are binding on
  the appellate court unless wholly unsupported by the evidence or controlled by
  error of law).

II.Â  Rule
  55(c)
Appellants argue
  that the trial court erred in
  ruling that they failed to show good cause to set aside the entry of default.Â 
  Specifically, Appellants claim that the insurance companyâ€™s failure to respond was
  inadvertent and constitutes good cause to justify setting aside the entry of
  default.Â  We disagree.
The standard for granting relief from an entry of default is good cause under Rule 55(c), SCRCP,
  while the standard is more rigorous for granting relief from a default judgment
  under Rule 60(b), SCRCP.Â  Sundown Operating Co., Inc. v. Intedge Indus.,
    Inc., Op. No. 26700(S.C. Sup. Ct. Filed August 17, 2009).Â  In deciding
  whether good cause exists, the trial court should consider the following
  factors: (1) the timing of the defendantâ€™s motion for relief, (2) whether the
  defendant has a meritorious defense, and (3) the degree of prejudice to the
  plaintiff if relief is granted.Â  Wham v. Shearson Lehman Bros., 298 S.C. 462, 465, 381 S.E.2d 499, 502 (Ct. App. 1989).Â  The
  decision whether to set aside an
  entry of default or a default judgment
  lies solely within the sound discretion of the trial judge and will not be
  disturbed on appeal absent a clear showing of an abuse of that discretion. Harbor
    Island Ownersâ€™ Assâ€™n v. Preferred Island Prop., Inc., 369 S.C. 540, 544,
  633 S.E.2d 497, 499 (2006).
As a
  primary matter, Appellants argue that the trial court erred in ruling on the
  merits of this issue because they did not have the opportunity to be heard and present
  evidence of good cause.Â  We disagree.Â  In
  their written motion to set aside the entry of default filed prior to the
  hearing, Appellants maintained that the entry of default was void because service
  of process was defective.Â  Additionally, Appellants requested that, if the trial
  court denied relief based on this ground, the trial court â€œschedule a
  subsequent hearing based upon the ground of mistake, inadvertence, surprise or
  excusable neglectâ€[2] because the insurance companies were still investigating the matter and they
  would â€œshortly have full information to support such a Motion.â€Â  At the hearing,
  Respondentâ€™s counsel told the trial court that Appellants were moving to set
  aside the entry of default based on improper service and good cause and argued
  the merits of the good cause issue.Â  Specifically, Respondentâ€™s counsel argued
  that there was nothing in the record from the insurance company explaining why
  it failed to answer the complaint and that, even if the failure to respond was
  due to negligent oversight, this did not constitute good cause.Â  In rebuttal, Appellantsâ€™
  counsel argued that although the discovery process concerning the insurance companyâ€™s
  failure to respond had not been completed, â€œwe just really donâ€™t think we need
  to go that far.â€Â  
After
  the trial court issued its order ruling that Appellants failed to show good
  cause, Appellants filed a motion to reconsider arguing that the trial court
  failed to consider the second part of the motion and never notified Appellants
  that it was denying their request for bifurcation.Â  Additionally, Appellants
  attached affidavits from the insurance agent and the insurance company
  explaining why the insurance company never responded to the complaint.Â  The
  trial court denied the motion for reconsideration.
In
  our view, bifurcation of this motion was not necessary, much less appropriate.Â 
  Both â€œhalvesâ€ of the motion went to the same issue, namely whether the trial
  court should set aside the entry of default, and Appellants had the opportunity
  to present evidence of improper service and good cause at the hearing.[3]Â  In any event, we find that Appellants failed to reserve their
  right to revisit this issue.Â  Appellants failed to move for bifurcation at the
  hearing, and even assuming that they requested bifurcation in the written
  motion filed prior to the hearing, Appellants did not seek a specific ruling on
  bifurcation from the trial court at the hearing.Â  Furthermore, if the insurance
  company was in fact still investigating the incident, Appellants failed to seek
  a continuance in order to complete discovery on this issue.[4]Â  In our view, Appellants were given a full and fair opportunity
  to be heard on this matter, and furthermore, Appellants had an opportunity to explain
  to the trial court why they needed more time to develop the record as to this
  issue.Â  
Nonetheless,
  even considering the affidavits, Appellantsâ€™ argument fails on the merits.[5]Â  The insurance
  agentâ€™s affidavit indicates that he received a copy of the incident report, the
  police report, and inspection reports from the Department of Heath and
  Environmental Control (DHEC) from Patidar shortly after the drowning occurred
  and that he mailed these documents to the insurance company.[6]Â 
  He also stated that after the complaint was filed, he began receiving
  correspondence from Respondentâ€™s counsel addressed to him as well as another
  attorney.Â  The insurance agent assumed the other attorney was defense counsel
  hired by the insurance company when in fact the attorney was another attorney
  for the plaintiff.Â  The insurance agent stated he was not aware that the
  summons and complaint that Patidar forwarded to him were not also forwarded to
  the insurance company.Â  An affidavit from the insurance company indicates that
  it never received the incident report from the insurance agent and the
  insurance companyâ€™s internal process of contacting the adjusting company was
  therefore never triggered.Â  
We
  hold that even assuming that the
  insurance company was at fault for not answering the complaint, Appellants
  failed to show good cause.Â  Negligence of an insurance company is imputed to a
  defaulting litigant and cannot constitute good cause to relieve Appellants from
  the entry of default.Â  See Roberts v. Peterson, 292 S.C. 149, 355 S.E.2d 280 (Ct. App.
  1987) (observing that the â€œcourts
  of this state have consistently held that the negligence of an attorney or
  insurance company is imputable to a defaulting litigantâ€) and Williams v. Vanvolkenburg, 312 S.C. 373, 440 S.E.2d 408 (Ct. App.
  1994) (imputing an attorneyâ€™s negligence to a defaulting litigant).Â 
  Moreover, the Wham factors do not weigh in favor of lifting the entry of
  default.Â  Appellants filed the motion to set aside over two months after the
  entry of default, and Appellants have not asserted a meritorious defense or
  argued that Respondent will not be prejudiced if the entry of default is
  lifted.Â  
Â Accordingly,
  we hold that Appellants have not established good cause to justify lifting the
  entry of default.
Conclusion
For the foregoing reasons, we
  affirm the trial courtâ€™s order refusing to set aside the entry of default.Â  
WALLER, PLEICONES, BEATTY
  and KITTREDGE, JJ., concur.


[1] Patidar is the registered agent for Harbor Inn.Â  
[2] Appellants appear to have confused the Rule 55(c) â€œgood causeâ€ standard with
  the more rigorous Rule 60(b) â€œexcusable neglectâ€ standard in the motion to set
  aside the entry of default.Â  See Sundown, Op. No. 26700 (S.C. Sup. Ct.
  Filed August 17, 2009) (explaining and comparing the applicable standards in a
  Rule 55(c) motion and a Rule 60(b) motion).
[3] Appellantsâ€™ counsel submitted a letter to the trial court the day after the
  hearing â€œregarding the issue of â€˜good causeâ€™â€ and including case law supporting
  their position. 
[4] We note that although Appellantsâ€™ counsel claimed the insurance company was
  still investigating the matter, he was able to submit the affidavits from the
  insurance company shortly after the hearing.Â  
[5] In their brief, Appellants request that this Court â€œconsider [the affidavits]
  and rule upon the â€˜good causeâ€™ issue.â€
[6] The insurance agent stated that he sells insurance policies and places coverage
  for his clients, but he has no role in the litigation process and once he reports
  a claim, the matter is transferred to the insurance company.

Petitioner  filed exceptions to the CCF’s Report and Recommendation.  The Office of Disciplinary Counsel (ODC) did  not file exceptions to the CCF’s Report and Recommendation.

title: State v. Edwards
description: In this case, Petitioners appeal their criminal convictions on the grounds that the trial court erred in quashing the first jury panel based upon a violation of Batson v. Kentucky.  The court of appeals affirmed the trial court.  We granted a writ of certiorari to Petitioners and reverse the court of appeals decision.

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court

	
		
			
				The State, Respondent,
				v.
				Jason Sinatra
      Edwards, Maceo Latonya Edwards and Jonais Edwards, Petitioners.
			
		
	


ON WRIT OF CERTIORARI TO THE COURT OF
  APPEALS

Appeal from Williamsburg County
Â Howard P. King, Circuit Court Judge
Opinion No. 26711
Heard June 11, 2009 - Filed August 31,
  2009Â Â  
REVERSED


	
		
			
				Steven
  S. McKenzie, of Coffee, Chandler & Kent, of Manning, for Petitioners.
				Attorney
  General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney General John W. McIntosh, Assistant
  Deputy Attorney General Donald J. Zelenka, and Senior Assistant Attorney
  General William Edgar Salter, III, all of Columbia; and Solicitor Cecil Kelly
  Jackson, of Sumter, for Respondent.
			
		
	


CHIEF JUSTICE TOAL: In
  this case, Petitioners, who were tried jointly, appeal their criminal
  convictions on the grounds that the trial court erred in quashing the first
  jury panel based upon a violation of Batson v. Kentucky, 476 U.S. 79
  (1986).Â  The court of appeals affirmed the trial court, and Petitioners filed a
  writ of certiorari asking this Court to review and reverse the court of appeals
  decision.Â  
Factual/Procedural
  Background
Petitioners
  Jason, Maceo, and Jonais Edwards, all brothers, were tried jointly for the
  murders of Joe Woods and Jimmy Robinson in January 2006.Â  During jury
  selection, the trial court was not able to impanel an entire twelve member jury
  because it ran out of venire persons during the selection process.Â  During the
  selection process, Petitioners had used sixteen of a possible twenty preemptory
  strikes to strike nine Caucasian and seven African American potential jurors.Â  The
  State made a Batson motion on the grounds that Petitionerâ€™s strikes were
  racially motivated, and the trial court heard the motion, despite the fact that
  a full jury was not yet impaneled.Â  The trial court granted the Stateâ€™s Batson motion, holding that jurors 19, 50, and 131 were struck on racially cognizable
  grounds.Â  The trial court quashed the first jury, and a new jury was
  selected.Â Â  Jurors 50 and 131 were selected for the second jury, and the case
  proceeded to trial.Â  
The
  jury found Petitioners Jason and Maceo Edwards guilty of murder and found
  Petitioner Jonais Edwards guilty of accessory after the fact of murder.Â 
  Petitioners appealed their convictions and sentences, and the court of appeals
  affirmed.Â  State v. Edwards, 374 S.C. 543, 649 S.E.2d 112 (Ct. App. 2007).Â  This Court granted Petitionersâ€™ petition for a writ of certiorari to
  review the following question:

	Did the
  trial court err in quashing the first jury panel based upon a violation of Batson
    v. Kentucky, 476 U.S. 79 (1986)?

Standard
  of review
In criminal cases, this Court will review errors of
  law only.Â  State v. Baccus, 367 S.C. 41, 48, 625 S.E.2d 216, 220
  (2006).Â  This Court is bound by the trial courtâ€™s factual findings unless they
  are clearly erroneous.Â  State v. Quattlebaum, 338 S.C. 441, 452, 527
  S.E.2d 105, 111 (2000).Â  On
  review, this Court is limited to determining whether the trial court abused its
  discretion. Â State v. Rochester, 301 S.C. 196, 200, 391 S.E.2d 244, 247
  (1990).Â  This Court does not re-evaluate the facts based on its own view of the
  preponderance of the evidence but simply determines whether the trial courtâ€™s
  ruling is supported by any
  evidence.Â  State v. Wilson, 345 S.C. 1, 6, 545 S.E.2d 827, 829 (2001).
Law/Analysis
Petitioners assert
  that the court of appeals erred in upholding the trial courtâ€™s decision to
  grant the Stateâ€™s Batson motion.Â  We agree.
The Equal Protection Clause of the Fourteenth Amendment to the
  United States Constitution prohibits the striking of a venire person on the
  basis of race or gender. Â State v.
    Hicks, 330 S.C. 207, 211, 499 S.E.2d 209, 211 (1998). Â When one party strikes a
  member of a cognizable racial group or gender, the trial court must hold a Batson hearing if the opposing party requests one. Â See State v. Haigler, 334 S.C. 623, 629-30, 515 S.E.2d 88, 90-91 (1999)
  (explaining the proper procedure for a Batson hearing). Â The proponent of the
  strike must offer a race or gender neutral explanation. Â Id. Â The opponent must show the race or gender neutral explanation was mere
  pretext, which is generally established by showing the party did not strike a
  similarly situated member of another race or gender. Â Id.Â  Under
  some circumstances, the explanation given by the proponent may be so
  fundamentally implausible the trial judge may determine the explanation was
  mere pretext, even without a showing of disparate treatment. Â Id.
Whether a Batson violation has occurred must be determined
  by examining the totality of the facts and circumstances in the record. Â Riddle v. State, 314 S.C. 1, 14, 443 S.E.2d 557, 565 (1994). Â The opponent of the strike carries the
  ultimate burden of persuading the trial court that the challenged party
  exercised strikes in a discriminatory manner. Â State v. Adams, 322 S.C. 114, 470 S.E.2d 366 (1996). Â Appellate courts give the trial judgeâ€™s
  finding great deference on appeal and review the trial judgeâ€™s ruling with a
  clearly erroneous standard. Â State v.
    Dyar, 317 S.C. 77, 79, 452 S.E.2d 603, 604 (1994).
The trial judgeâ€™s findings of purposeful discrimination rest
  largely on his evaluation of demeanor and credibility. Â Sumpter v. State, 312 S.C. 221, 224, 439 S.E.2d
  842, 844 (1994). Â Often the demeanor of the challenged attorney will be the best and only evidence of discrimination, and
  an â€œevaluation of the [attorneyâ€™s] mind lies peculiarly within a trial judgeâ€™s
  province.â€ Â Hernandez v. New York, 500 U.S. 352, 365 (1991). Â Furthermore, a strike must
  be examined in light of the circumstances under which it is exercised,
  including an examination of the explanations offered for other strikes. Â State v. Oglesby, 298 S.C. 279, 280, 379 S.E.2d
  891, 892 (1989).
If a
  trial court improperly grants the Stateâ€™s Batson motion, but none of the
  disputed jurors serve on the jury, any error in improperly quashing the jury is
  harmless because a defendant is not entitled to the jury of her choice.Â  State
    v. Rayfield, 369 S.C. 106, 114, 631 S.E.2d 244, 248 (2006).Â  However, if
  one of the disputed jurors is seated on the jury, then the erroneous Batson ruling has tainted the jury and prejudice is presumed in such cases â€œbecause
  there is no way to determine with any degree of certainty whether a defendantâ€™s
  right to a fair trial by an impartial jury was abridged.â€Â  Id. at 114,
  631 S.E.2d at 248.Â  The proper remedy in such cases is the granting of a new
  trial.Â  
Petitioners
  challenged jurors 50 and 131 during the first jury selection.[1]Â 
  Following the trial courtâ€™s quashing of the first jury, Petitioners were not
  allowed to strike these jurors from the second jury and jurors 50 and 131 were
  impaneled for Petitionersâ€™ trial.Â  
Petitioners
  initially challenged juror 50 on the grounds that he was a newspaper editor and
  might have knowledge of or have written a story about the case.Â  Petitioners
  challenged juror 131 on the grounds that she worked for the Department of Motor
  Vehicles (DMV) and interacted with law enforcement on a regular basis.Â  
The State argued in
  its Batson motion that both explanations were pretext for racial
  prejudice on the grounds that there was no evidence that juror 50 ever wrote an
  article about the case and that striking all DMV employees was so broad as to be
  evidence of pretext.Â  The trial court ruled that the explanations given for
  jurors 50 and 131 were not racially neutral, but the court did not specifically
  articulate its reasoning.Â  The court of appeals upheld the trial court, finding
  that â€œthe record contains sufficient justification to conclude there was no
  abuse of discretion.â€Â Â Â  
We find that the
  explanations given for jurors 50 and 131 were race neutral and that the trial
  court committed clear error in granting the Stateâ€™s Batson motion.Â  Employment
  is a well-understood and recognized consideration in the exercise of peremptory
  challenges.Â  State v. Williams, 379 S.C. 399, 402-03, 665 S.E.2d 228,
  230 (Ct. App. 2008); State v. Ford, 334 S.C. 59, 65, 512 S.E.2d 500, 504
  (1999) (holding place of employment is a race-neutral reason for a strike); State
    v. Adams, 322 S.C. 114, 125, 470 S.E.2d 366, 372 (1996) (finding type of
  employment is a race-neutral reason for a strike).Â  Petitionersâ€™ stated
  concerns that juror 50 was a journalist and juror 131 was a state employee who
  interacted regularly with law enforcement are race neutral reasons to strike.Â 
  The State bore the burden of demonstrating that these proffered explanations
  were pretext for racial discrimination.Â  We find no evidence that the State met
  this burden and the trial court clearly erred in finding otherwise.Â  Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  
Conclusion
For the forgoing
  reasons, we reverse the opinion of the court of appeals and remand for a new trial.Â  
WALLER,
  PLEICONES, KITTREDGE, JJ., and Acting Justice James E. Moore, concur.


[1] Although Petitionersâ€™ strike of juror 19 was also found to be discriminatory,
  Petitioners have not raised that issue in this appeal.

title: Metts v. Mims
description: This Court of Appeals certiorari case involves issues related to a defamation action against newspapers.

<!DOCTYPE html PUBLIC "-//W3C//DTD HTML 4.01 Transitional//EN"
