THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court

	
		
			
				Robert William
      Metts, Petitioner,
				v.
				Judy Mims,
      Berkeley Independent Publishing Company, Inc. d/b/a The Berkeley Independent
      and Summerville Communications, Inc. d/b/a The Goose Creek Gazette, Defendants,
				Of Which
      Berkeley Independent Publishing Company, Inc. d/b/a The Berkeley Independent
      and Summerville Communications, Inc. d/b/a The Goose Creek Gazette are the Respondents.
			
		
	


ON WRIT OF CERTIORARI TO THE COURT OF
  APPEALS 

Appeal From Berkeley County
Â R. Markley Dennis, Jr., Circuit Court
  Judge
Â  Deadra L. Jefferson, Circuit Court Judge
Â Roger Young, Circuit Court Judge
Opinion No.Â  26712
Heard October 8, 2008 - Filed August 31,
  2009Â  
AFFIRMED IN PART; REVERSED IN PART; AND
  REMANDED


	
		
			
				E.
  Paul Gibson, of Charleston, and Stephen F. DeAntonio, of DeAntonio Law Firm, Â of
  Charleston, for Petitioner.
				John
  J. Kerr, of Buist, Moore, Smythe & McGee, of Charleston, for Respondents.
			
		
	


JUSTICE WALLER:Â  We granted certiorari to review the
  Court of Appealsâ€™ opinion in Metts v. Mims, 370 S.C. 529, 635 S.E.2d 640
  (Ct. App. 2006). Â The Court of Appeals in Metts affirmed an order
  granting summary judgment to respondents (Newspapers), and therefore did not
  address the cross-appeals from the contempt order.Â  We affirm petitionerâ€™s
  issues related to the discovery order, reverse the summary judgment decision,
  and remand back to the Court of Appeals for resolution of Newspapersâ€™ appeal
  regarding the contempt order.
FACTUAL/PROCEDURAL
  BACKGROUND
Petitioner Robert William Metts is the Deputy County Supervisor of Berkeley County.Â  On July 30, 2003, Newspapers each published a front-page article with the
  headline:Â  â€œIt was helpful, but was it legal?â€Â  The article discussed a
  controversial work policy instituted by County Supervisor Jim Rozier which
  allowed county employees to work on private property in competition with
  private businesses.Â  In the story, defendant Judy Mims[1] was quoted as saying that county employees had been seen performing yard work
  on petitionerâ€™s private property.[2]Â  
Petitioner
  sued Newspapers claiming that the statements in the article were defamatory
  because they suggested he was improperly benefiting from the services of county
  employees.Â  According to petitioner, he had yard work performed by private
  companies and never utilized county employees.Â  Petitioner further contended
  that defendant Mims fabricated the story because she had a â€œlongstanding vendettaâ€
  against petitionerâ€™s supervisor, Rozier, who is an elected official.
During
  the discovery phase of the lawsuit, petitioner sought to obtain Newspapersâ€™
  financial information for use in the punitive damages portion of trial.Â  When Newspapers
  declined to provide the information, petitioner obtained an order compelling
  its production.Â  Newspapers subsequently sought a contempt order to permit them
  to immediately appeal the discovery order.Â  See, e.g., Tucker
    v. Honda of South Carolina Mfg., 354 S.C. 574, 577, 582 S.E.2d 405,
  406-07 (2003) (â€œan order compelling discovery may be appealed only after
  the trial court holds a party in contemptâ€).Â  The trial
  court issued the contempt order, but declined to impose any sanctions. Â Both
  petitioner and Newspapers filed appeals from the contempt order.Â  
After
  the contempt order was issued, the trial court heard Newspapersâ€™ summary
  judgment motion.Â  The trial court granted summary judgment in favor of
  Newspapers finding that petitioner failed to meet his burden of producing clear
  and convincing evidence that Newspapers acted with constitutional actual
  malice.Â  See Fleming v. Rose, 350 S.C. 488, 567 S.E.2d 857 (2002)
  (libel plaintiff who is a public figure must produce clear and convincing
  evidence of actual malice in order to withstand defendantâ€™s summary judgment
  motion).
Petitioner
  timely appealed from the trial courtâ€™s order granting summary judgment.Â  The
  appeals from the trial courtâ€™s orders were consolidated for review.Â  The Court
  of Appeals affirmed the summary judgment order and further held that this
  affirmance mooted the cross-appeals from the contempt order.Â  Metts, supra.Â 
  We granted petitionerâ€™s request for a writ of certiorari.
ISSUES

	
		
			I.
			Did the Court of Appeals err in holding that the 
			trial court had the authority to rule on Newspapersâ€™ summary 
			judgment motion?
 
		
		
			II. 
			Did the Court of Appeals err in declining to 
			address the merits of petitionerâ€™s appeal from the contempt order?
 
		
		
			III.
			Did the Court of Appeals err in affirming the grant 
			of summary judgment?
		
	

DISCUSSION
I.
Petitioner
  argues the trial court lacked jurisdiction to consider the summary judgment
  motion because he had filed an appeal from the contempt order before the
  order granting summary judgment was filed. Â Resolution of this argument requires
  a review of the following timeline of events:

	August
  25, 2004:Â  Judge Jefferson issues discovery
  order compelling Newspapers to provide the fÂ­Â­Â­Â­inancial information sought by petitioner.Â  
	
	December
  22, 2004: Newspapers move for summary
  judgment.Â  
	March
  8, 2005:Â  Judge Dennis hears contempt
  action filed by petitioner when Newspapers decline to comply with Judge
  Jeffersonâ€™s August 2004 discovery order.
	March
  8, 2005:Â  Unsigned Form 4
  order is filed, finding Newspapers in contempt and holding summary judgment
  motion in abeyance.Â  The form also states:Â  â€œFormal order to follow.â€
	April
  7, 2005: The Berkeley Count Clerk of Court
  asks the parties to disregard/destroy the unsigned Form 4 order dated March 8,
  2005.Â  This memorandum indicates the request is â€œa follow-up to previous
  conversations.â€Â  
	April
  28, 2005:Â  Judge Dennis issues order
  on March contempt hearing, finding Newspapers in contempt, but imposing no
  sanctions.Â  The trial court also states that Newspapersâ€™ summary judgment
  motion should be rescheduled for hearing but stays trial pending that hearing.Â 
  This order was filed at 4:56 p.m. on April 29, 2005.
	April
  29, 2005:Â  Judge Young hears Newspapersâ€™
  summary judgment motion.
	May
  27/June 2, 2005:Â  Newspapers and petitioner
  appeal Judge Dennisâ€™s order holding Newspapers in contempt but refusing to
  impose any sanctions.
	June
  20, 2005:Â  Judge Young issues an order
  granting Newspapers summary judgment.Â  

According
  to petitioner, the trial court lacked jurisdiction to consider the summary
  judgment motion because he had appealed Judge Dennisâ€™s contempt order on June
  2, 2005, before Judge Youngâ€™s order granting summary judgment was filed on June
  20, 2005.Â  We disagree.
Initially,
  we note that petitioner couches this argument as one involving the trial
  courtâ€™s subject matter jurisdiction.Â  Generally speaking, subject matter
  jurisdiction is the power to hear and determine cases of the general class to
  which the proceedings in question belong.Â  E.g. Dove v. Gold Kist,
    Inc., 314 S.C. 235, 442 S.E.2d 598 (1994).Â  Circuit courts have
  jurisdiction over general tort cases, such as the instant defamation case. Â See Sabb v. South Carolina State Univ., 350 S.C. 416, 422, 567 S.E.2d 231,
  234 (2002).Â  Accordingly, petitionerâ€™s â€œsubject matterâ€ jurisdiction claim
  is inapposite.
Petitioner
  also cites Rule 205, SCACR, in support of his argument.Â  Pursuant to Rule 205,
  the service of a notice of appeal gives the appellate court exclusive jurisdiction over the appeal.Â  Nonetheless, this rule also provides that a
  trial court may proceed â€œwith matters not affected by the appeal.â€Â  Here, the
  contempt order resulted from Newspapersâ€™ refusal to comply with a discovery
  order compelling it to provide financial data relevant to petitionerâ€™s punitive
  damages claim.Â  Newspapersâ€™ motion for summary judgment, however, was on the
  merits of petitionerâ€™s libel claim.Â  We find the summary judgment matter was
  unaffected by the appeal of the contempt order.Â  Cf. Grosshuesch v.
    Cramer, 377 S.C. 12, 31 n.7, 659 S.E.2d 112, 122 n.7 (2008) (where the
  Court noted that the trial court properly ruled on a second discovery matter
  involving a deposition after the parties had filed appeals from the trial
  courtâ€™s first order because the first order dealt with the subject of initial
  discovery responses).Â  The trial courtâ€™s ruling on the constitutional actual
  malice issue was clearly unrelated to the discovery dispute involving the
  Newspapersâ€™ financial data.Â  Thus, the trial court properly proceeded on the
  summary judgment motion, despite the pending appeal on the contempt order. Â Rule
  205, SCACR.
Petitioner
  further contends that because Judge Dennis orally held the summary judgment
  motion in abeyance, and this was memorialized in the unsigned Form 4 order
  filed in March 2005, Judge Young was unauthorized to hold the summary judgment
  hearing on April 29, 2005.Â  We disagree.Â  The Form 4 order was not signed by
  the judge and it specifically indicated a formal order would follow.Â 
  Therefore, this form order was not in any way final.Â  See Culbertson
    v. Clemens, 322 S.C. 20, 23, 471 S.E.2d 163, 164 (1996) (a decree leaving
  some further act to be done by the court is not final); see also Cheap-Oâ€™s Truck Stop, Inc. v. Cloyd, 350 S.C.
  596, 605, 567 S.E.2d 514, 518 (Ct. App. 2002) (a form
  order is a final order only if the circuit court indicates that nothing else
  remains to be done after it is signed).Â Â Â  
Finally,
  petitioner asserts that, as a matter of public policy, a party which has been
  held in contempt should not be heard by the court until the contempt has been
  resolved.Â  We find this argument is unpreserved for appellate review.Â  Although
  petitioner raised this argument at the summary judgment hearing, it was not
  addressed in the trial courtâ€™s order.Â  Petitioner then failed to include this
  issue in his motion for reconsideration.Â  Accordingly, the argument is procedurally
  barred, and the Court of Appeals properly did not address it. Â E.g., Elam
    v. S.C. Depâ€™t of Transp., 361 S.C. 9, 24, 602 S.E.2d 772, 780 (2004) (â€œA
  party must file [a Rule 59(e)] motion when an issue or argument has been
  raised, but not ruled on, in order to preserve it for appellate review.â€)
  (emphasis in original).
II.
Petitioner maintains
  the Court of Appeals erred in failing to address his argument that Judge Dennis
  improperly declined to impose sanctions on Newspapers for its contempt.Â  We
  disagree.
The
  Court of Appeals, having upheld the grant of summary judgment, declined to
  address the merits of the contempt cross-appeals citing Jarrell v. Petoseed
    Co., 331 S.C. 207, 209-10, 500 S.E.2d 793, 794 (Ct. App. 1998) (â€œCivil
  contempt proceedings designed to coerce compliance generally terminate along
  with the termination of the main action.â€).Â  Regardless, where a party chooses
  to be held in contempt in order to immediately appeal a discovery order, it is
  within the discretion of the trial court to forego sanctions. Â E.g., Lindsay
    v. Lindsay, 328 S.C. 329, 338, 491 S.E.2d 583, 588 (Ct. App. 1997) (â€œEven
  though a party is found to have violated a court order, the question of whether
  or not to impose sanctions remains a matter for the courtâ€™s discretion.â€).Â 
  Clearly, under the circumstances of the instant case, it was within Judge
  Dennisâ€™s discretion to not impose contempt sanctions on Newspapers.
III.
Finally, petitioner
  argues the Court of Appeals erred in affirming the trial courtâ€™s order granting
  summary judgment for Newspapers.Â  Because we find there is an issue of fact
  regarding actual malice, we agree with petitioner that the Court of Appeals
  erred by upholding summary judgment.
A motion for summary judgment shall be granted â€œif the
  pleadings, depositions, answers to interrogatories, and admissions on file,
  together with the affidavits, if any, show that there is no genuine issue as to
  any material fact and that the moving party is entitled to a judgment as a
  matter of law.â€ Rule 56(c), SCRCP. Â For summary judgment purposes, a court must
  view the facts in the light most favorable to the non-moving party. Â E.g., George v. Fabri, 345 S.C. 440, 452, 548 S.E.2d 868, 874 (2001).Â 
  Because it is â€œa drastic remedy, summary judgment should be cautiously invoked
  so that no person will be improperly deprived of a trial of the disputed
  factual issues.â€Â  Baughman v. American Tel. and Tel. Co., 306 S.C. 101,
  112, 410 S.E.2d 537, 543 (1991) (citation and internal quotation marks
  omitted).
In
  addition to the common law elements of defamation, a public figure has the
  constitutional burden of proving that the defendant published the alleged
  defamatory material with â€œactual malice.â€Â  Anderson
    v. Augusta Chronicle, 365 S.C. 589, 594-595, 619 S.E.2d 428, 431 (2005)
  (citing New York Times v. Sullivan, 376 U.S. 254, 269 (1964)). Â To establish
  â€œactual malice,â€ the plaintiff must show the defendant published the defamatory
  material with the knowledge it was false or with reckless disregard of whether
  or not it was false.Â  George v. Fabri, 345 S.C. at 451,
  548 S.E.2d at 874 (citing New York Times, supra).
â€œ[T]he
  reckless conduct contemplated by the New York Times standard is not
  measured by whether a reasonably prudent man would have published, or would
  have investigated before publishing.â€Â  Id. at 456, 548 S.E.2d at 876.Â  Instead, the actual
  malice standard â€œis a subjective one - there must be sufficient evidence to
  permit the conclusion that the defendant actually had a â€˜high degree of
  awareness of ... probable falsity.â€™â€Â  Harte-Hanks Comm., Inc. v. Connaughton,
  491 U.S. 657, 688 (1989) (citation omitted).Â  Reckless disregard â€œmay be found
  where there are obvious reasons to doubt the veracity of the informant or the
  accuracy of his reports.â€Â  St. Amant v. Thompson, 390 U.S. 727, 732 (1968).Â  Moreover, while the failure to investigate without more will not
  support a finding of actual malice, â€œthe purposeful avoidance of the truth is
  in a different category.â€Â  Harte-Hanks Comm., Inc. v. Connaughton, 491 U.S. at 692.Â  
Petitioner
  argues that the following evidence creates a genuine issue of fact regarding
  actual malice:

	
		
			1.
			Before publishing the story, the reporter obtained 
			from Berkeley County a list of people who had received the services 
			from county employees pursuant to the controversial policy; 
			petitionerâ€™s name was not on that list.
 
		
		
			2.
			The reporter had time to change the story, but she 
			did not.
 
		
		
			3.  
			The reporter did not attempt to contact petitioner 
			for comment or verification.
 
		
		
			4.
			The reporter did not ask Mims who had told Mims 
			they observed county employees doing yard work at petitionerâ€™s 
			property.
 
		
		
			5.
			The reporter was aware that Mims and petitionerâ€™s 
			boss, Rozier, had an adversarial relationship with one
  another.
		
	

Here,
  viewing the record in a light most favorable to petitioner, there was
  sufficient clear and convincing evidence to create an issue of fact on the
  question of actual malice.Â  The reporter obtained information from Councilwoman
  Mims, who was known to be a political nemesis of petitionerâ€™s supervisor.Â 
  Moreover, the information from Mims was directly contradicted by the list the
  reporter received because petitionerâ€™s name was not on the list of those
  getting yard services from county employees.Â  This is direct evidence that
  called into question the accuracy of Mimsâ€™ statements.Â  Therefore, the reporter
  arguably had reason to doubt Mimsâ€™ veracity.Â  St. Amant v. Thompson, supra (when there are obvious reasons to doubt the veracity of the informant or the
  accuracy of her reports, reckless disregard may be found); see also Stevens
    v. Sun Publâ€™g Co., 270 S.C. 65, 72, 240 S.E.2d 812, 815 (1978) (where
  the Court found that actual malice can be established when reporters â€œprint
  articles on the basis of an admittedly unreliable source, without further
  verificationâ€).Â  Looking at the totality of the evidence,
  a jury could infer reckless conduct sufficient to meet the New York Times standard of actual malice.
Accordingly,
  we hold summary judgment was improper.Â  
CONCLUSION
The decision of the
  Court of Appeals on the issue of summary judgment is reversed, but on all other
  issues raised by petitioner, the Court of Appeals opinion is affirmed.Â  Because
  Newspapersâ€™ original appeal from the contempt order is no longer moot, we
  remand the matter back to the Court of Appeals.
AFFIRMED IN
  PART; REVERSED IN PART; AND REMANDED.
TOAL, C.J.,
  BEATTY and KITTREDGE, JJ., concur. PLEICONES, J., concurring in part and
  dissenting in part in a separate opinion.

JUSTICE PLEICONES:Â  I concur in part and dissent in part.Â  I agree with
  the majority that the circuit court had jurisdiction to rule on the summary
  judgment motion.Â  I disagree, however, with the decision to reverse the Court
  of Appealsâ€™ decision which affirmed the circuit courtâ€™s grant of summary
  judgment to Newspapers.
I find no evidence
  of actual malice here. Â Actual malice is not satisfied by a showing of ill
  will, nor is the recklessness of a libel defendantâ€™s conduct â€œmeasured by
  whether a reasonably prudent man would have published, or would have
  investigated before publishing.â€Â  George v. Fabri, 345 S.C. 440, 548
  S.E.2d 868 (Â­2001) citing St. Amant v. Thompson, 390 U.S. 727, 731 (1968).Â  Petitioner was required to, but did not, produce evidence that the Newspapers
  â€œentertained serious doubts as to the truth ofâ€ councilwoman Mims statement.Â  See St. Amant v. Thompson, 390 U.S. at 731.Â  Only where the plaintiff can
  show â€œan extreme departure from the standards of investigation and reporting
  ordinarily adhered to by reasonable publishersâ€ can a public figure plaintiff
  withstand a motion for summary judgment on the issue of actual malice.Â  Anderson  v. Augusta Chronicle, supra.Â  In my view, petitioner did
  not meet this burden here.
â€œThe
  actual malice standard is premised on our â€˜profound national commitment to the
  principle that debate on public issues should be uninhibited, robust, and
  wide-open, and that it may well include vehement, caustic, and sometimes
  unpleasantly sharp attacks on government and public officials.â€™â€ George v.
    Fabri, 345 S.C. at 456-457, 548 S.E.2d at 876, citing New York Times v.
      Sullivan, 376 U.S. 254, 270 (1964).Â  Here, Newspapers published information
  about a county official, information given to them by another county official.Â 
  That petitionerâ€™s name was not on a list provided by a different county
  official is not evidence that publishing the story was â€œan extreme departure
  from investigative standardsâ€ nor was there any evidence that Newspapers in
  fact harbored serious doubts about councilwoman Mimsâ€™ story.Â  Moreover, the
  reporterâ€™s knowledge of the political enmity between councilwoman Mims and
  petitioner, combined with her failure to further investigate Mimsâ€™ statement
  before publishing it, is â€œpatently insufficientâ€ to prove actual malice.Â  Elder
    v. Gaffney Ledger, 341 S.C. 108, 533 S.E.2d 899 (2000).Â Â  Finally, the gist
  of the allegedly defamatory story, that county employees were seen performing
  yard work on petitionerâ€™s property, is not particularly inflammatory given that
  the county had in place a policy permitting this practice.
I would affirm the
  decision of the Court of Appeals.


[1] Mims, who was a county councilwoman at the time, is now deceased.
[2] After the story was published, Mims called the reporter and denied having made
  the statement attributed to her about petitioner; one of the Newspapers printed
  a correction.Â  Petitioner alleges, however, that while the correction included
  his own denial of what was reported, it essentially reiterated the
  objectionable statement from Mims.

title: Hill v. York County Natural Gas
description: We affirm the decision of the trial court finding that York County Natural Gas Authority has the authority to condemn certain real property.

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court

	
		
			
				Jean McMurray Hill, Trustee of the Jean M. Hill Revocable Trust, Appellant,
				v.
				York County Natural Gas Authority, Respondent.
				Thomas E. Fitz, Jr., Frances Fitz Gaines, John Gregory Fitz, and
      Joseph Daniel Fitz, II, Appellants,
				v.
				York County Natural Gas Authority, Respondent.
				Thomas E. Fitz, Jr., Frances Fitz Gaines, John Gregory Fitz, and
      Joseph Daniel Fitz, II, Appellants,
				v.
				York County Natural Gas Authority, Respondent.
				Madison C. Martin and Elizabeth Martin, Appellants,
				 
				v.
				York County Natural Gas Authority, Respondent.
				Irby Carlyle McGill, a/k/a Carlyle McGill, Appellant,
				v.
				York County Natural Gas Authority, Respondent.
				Carlyle McGill, Appellant,
				v.
				York County Natural Gas Authority, Respondent.
				Myrtle Petty, Appellant,
				v.
				York County Natural Gas Authority, Respondent.
				Carlyle McGill, Appellant,
				v.
				York County Natural Gas Authority, Respondent.
				Harry J. Callahan, Jr. and Beverly S. Callahan, Appellants,
				v.
				York County Natural Gas Authority, Respondent.
			
		
	


Appeal From York County
Â John C. Hayes, III, Circuit Court Judge
Opinion No. 26713
Heard June 23, 2009 - Filed August 31,
  2009Â Â  
AFFIRMED


	
		
			
				A.
  Camden Lewis and Ariail E. King, both of Lewis & Babcock, of Columbia, and Alford
  Haselden, of Haselden, Owen & Boloyan, of Clover, for Appellants.
				W. Mark
  White and W. Chaplin Spencer, Jr., both of Spencer & Spencer, of Rock Hill,
  for Respondent.
			
		
	


PER CURIAM:Â  A
  group of York County landowners challenge the power of the York County Natural
  Gas Authority to condemn land to construct a natural gas transmission
  pipeline.Â  The landowners appeal from the trial courtâ€™s determination that the York
  County Natural Gas Authority has the statutory authority to condemn their
  property and construct the pipeline.Â  We affirm.Â Â Â Â  
In
  July 2006, the York County Natural Gas Authority commenced proceedings to
  condemn real property in York County for the purpose of constructing a natural
  gas transmission pipeline.Â  Eleven of the affected property owners (Landowners)
  answered the notice of condemnation by filing a complaint in August 2006
  challenging the authority of the York County Natural Gas Authority to condemn
  their real property.Â  The case went to trial under various causes of action,
  and the trial court found that the York County Natural Gas Authority had the
  authority to condemn Landownersâ€™ property.
ISSUES

	Landowners
  appeal, raising two issues for review: 
	
		
			1) 
			 â€œThe evidence and statutory interpretation do 
			not support the [trial] courtâ€™s findings that Blacksburg is a new 
			source and thus, that Respondent did not exceed its authority under 
			the Enabling Act.â€ 
 
		
		
			2) 
			 â€œThe trial court erred in finding that the 
			Notices of Condemnation based on incorrect statutory authority can 
			be amended.â€ 
		
	

DISCUSSION
I.

The York
  County Natural Gas Authority (Authority) is a special purpose district and
  corporate entity created by Act No. 959 of 1954.Â  In 1957, by Act No. 694, section
  1 of the original Act was amended to read as follows:

	It shall
  be the function of the authority to purchase, lease, acquire, build, construct,
  maintain and operate natural gas distribution systems within the service area
  hereinafter defined and such transmission lines as may be necessary to
  transport natural gas to the distribution systems from the transmission lines
  to be constructed by [South] Carolina Pipeline Company or other sources from
    which natural gas may now or hereafter become available . . . .

Act No. 694, 1957 S.C. Acts
  1427 (emphasis added).Â  By Act No. 193, which became effective on June 12,
  1995, the Act was amended in several respects, including expansion of the
  Authorityâ€™s service area beyond York County.Â  Section 1 of the Act was amended
  to read as follows:

	It is
  the function of the authority to purchase, lease, acquire, build, construct,
  maintain, and operate natural gas distribution systems within the service area
  defined in this act and such transmission lines as may be necessary to
  transport natural gas to the distribution systems from the transmission lines
  owned by South Carolina Pipeline Company or other sources from which natural
    gas may become available after the effective date of this act.Â Â  

Act No. 193, 1995 S.C. Acts 1569
  (emphasis added).Â  
Because
  the outcome of this case turns on the meaning of the statutory term â€œother
  sources,â€ we need not delve extensively into the detailed factual history prior
  to the 1995 Act, including the Authorityâ€™s once exclusive reliance on the South
  Carolina Pipeline Company (SCPC) and the reasons that prompted a change in that
  relationship.Â  We simply note the Authority joined with its sister special
  purpose districts in Lancaster and Chester counties to form a joint agency
  called Patriots Energy Group (PEG) pursuant to the Joint Agency Act.[1]Â 
  The goal of PEG was to â€œenable these natural gas special purpose districts to
  jointly undertake the acquisition and construction of natural gas facilities.â€Â  
Under
  the authority provided in the Joint Agency Act, PEG issued bonds to cover its
  acquisition and construction costs.Â  One of PEGâ€™s construction projects was to
  integrate its transmission system with the Town of Blacksburgâ€™s natural gas
  system.Â  Blacksburg is in Cherokee County.Â  Blacksburg is connected to the Transcontinental
  Pipeline Corporationâ€™s interstate pipeline (the Transco pipeline).[2]Â 
  Thus, linking in with Blacksburgâ€™s natural gas system would allow the Authority
  (and its sister authorities, all under the umbrella of PEG) to connect to the
  Transco pipeline.Â  
Pursuant to this
  plan PEG and Blacksburg entered into a capacity sharing agreement.Â  The agreement
  included upgrading five miles of Blacksburgâ€™s system from Blacksburg, eastward
  to the Town of Kings Creek.Â  This upgrade, which has been completed, involved
  replacing the existing 6-inch distribution line with an 8-inch high-pressure steel
  transmission pipeline. 
In
  order to link up with the pipeline at Kings Creek, the Authority began
  condemnation proceedings (the proceedings being challenged in this lawsuit) to
  acquire rights-of-way to lay down 42.2 miles of 12-inch steel transmission
  pipeline.Â  The transmission pipeline will run from Kings Creek, eastward across
  York and Chester Counties.Â  
Landowners challenge the Authorityâ€™s power of eminent domain,
  contending the connection to the Blacksburg natural gas system and the Transco
  pipeline is not statutorily authorized.Â  Specifically, Landowners rely on that
  part of Act 193 that restricts the Authority to â€œother sources from which
  natural gas may become available after the effective date of this act.â€Â  The
  Act became law on June 12, 1995.Â  Because the Transco pipeline existed prior to
  June 1995, Landowners contend the Authority lacks statutory authorization to
  connect to the Transco pipeline and thus may not condemn their property.
The trial court
  did not read â€œother sourcesâ€ so narrowly.Â  The trial court noted that, â€œ[t]he
  Act references the pre-1995 sources as â€˜the transmission lines owned by South
  Carolina Pipeline Company.â€™Â  The source is not the South Carolina Pipeline
  Company, but rather its transmission lines.â€Â Â  
In discerning legislative intent, â€œ[a]ll rules of statutory
  construction are subservient to the one that legislative intent must prevail if
  it can be reasonably discovered in the language used, and that language must be
  construed in light of the intended purpose of the statute.â€Â  McClanahan v. Richland County Council, 350 S.C. 433, 438, 567 S.E.2d 240, 242 (2002).Â  â€œ[W]ords in a
  statute must be construed in context.Â  . . .Â  [T]he meaning of particular terms
  in a statute may be ascertained by reference to words associated with them in
  the statute.â€Â  S. Mut. Church Ins. Co. v. S.C. Windstorm & Hail
    Underwriting Assâ€™n, 306 S.C. 339, 342, 412 S.E.2d 377, 379 (1991) (internal
  citations omitted).Â  â€œThe language must also be read in a sense which
  harmonizes with its subject matter and accords with its general purpose.â€Â  Hitachi Data Sys. Corp. v. Leatherman, 309 S.C. 174, 178, 420 S.E.2d 843, 846
  (1992).Â  
Beginning with the
  premise that a source means transmission lines, the trial court went on to note
  that prior to the upgrade of the 5-mile pipeline from Blacksburg to Kings
  Creek, the 5-mile pipeline was a distribution line.Â  After the upgrade, the
  pipeline became a transmission line.Â  The trial court noted â€œ[t]he evidence
  demonstrates that the Town of Blacksburg was not an available source for
  transportation capacity to [the Authority] prior to June 12, 1995.Â  After the
  1995 Act, the Town of Blacksburg upgraded and expanded its system.â€ Â Therefore,
  the trial court found â€œ[t]he upgrade of the existing distribution line to a
  high pressure transmission line provides the Town of Blacksburg with the
  capacity to transport gas to [the Authorityâ€™s] system.Â  Accordingly, the Town
  of Blacksburg became an available source within the meaning of the 1995 Act
  upon completion of the upgraded line.â€Â  
The
  Authority takes no issue with the temporal limitation imposed by Act 193.Â  The
  Authority responds that â€œBlacksburgâ€™s system was not capable of providing PEG
  or [the Authority] with transportation services prior to 1995.Â  The
  construction upgrades from a distribution line did not even occur until 2004 or
  2005.â€Â  
When construing Act 193 in its entirety, we are persuaded the
  result reached by the circuit court is the correct one.Â  We believe the
  Legislature did not intend â€œother sourcesâ€ in the restrictive manner urged by
  Landowners.Â  We first recognize the Legislature stated that â€œ[i]t is the intent
  of this legislation to provide a means of ensuring that reasonably priced natural
  gas service is available to all citizens who desire the service within the
  service area of the authority.â€Â  Act No. 193 at 1574.Â  We next recognize, as
  did the trial court, the phrase immediately preceding â€œother sourcesâ€ grants to
  the Authority the power to construct and operate â€œnatural gas distribution
  systems . . . from the transmission lines owned by South Carolina
  Pipeline Company.â€ Â Act No. 193 at 1569 (emphasis added).Â  We construe â€œother
  sourcesâ€ as referring to transmission lines, consistent with the trial courtâ€™s
  interpretation.
The
  balance of Act 193 supports this interpretation.Â  For example, section 2
  provides the following: 

	The service area of the authority includes all of York
  County and each municipality within the county, all the Town of Smyrna to
  include that portion of the town which is within the boundaries of Cherokee
  County, and that portion of Cherokee County beginning at the intersection of
  the Broad River, the York County line, and the Cherokee County lines; extending
  in a northwesterly direction along the center line of the Broad River to the
  center of the Transcontinental Gas Pipeline Corporationâ€™s [Transcoâ€™s]
  right-of-way; thence in a northeasterly direction along the center line of the
  Transcontinental Gas Pipeline Corporationâ€™s right-of-way to its intersection
  with the North Carolina state line; thence east along the common boundary of
  North Carolina and Cherokee County to the York County line.Â  

Act No. 193 at 1569-70.

	The Act further
  provides:
	Those
  areas in Cherokee County, which may now or in the future be served by the Blacksburg municipal system, must be excluded from the [A]uthorityâ€™s distribution system,
	but
    may be served by its transmission system.
	(B) The Town of Blacksburg owns and operates a gas
  system which is capable of providing gas service to the portion of the service
  area of the [A]uthority in Cherokee County except for the portion located in
  the Town of Smyrna.Â  The town is responsible for the distribution of gas to end
  users located in such service area and may supply this gas service either
  through its transmission lines and distribution lines or by connecting its
    distribution lines to the transmission lines of the [A]uthority upon the
  payment of a reasonable tap fee and a reasonable transportation charge to the [A]uthority
  for the use of its transmission lines.

Act No. 193 at 1570 (emphasis
  added).
The Authority and Blacksburg have acted in accordance with this statutory authorization.Â  
The interpretation advanced by the Landowners would create
  an irreconcilable conflict in the Act.Â  Consequently, we construe the term
  â€œother sourcesâ€ in a manner that reconciles and harmonizes the language with
  other provisions of the Act.Â  See Hitachi
    Data, 309 S.C. at 178, 420 S.E.2d at
  846 (â€œThe language must also be read in a sense which harmonizes with its
  subject matter and accords with its general purpose.â€); see also S. Mut.
    Church Ins., 306 S.C. at 342, 412 S.E.2d at 379 (noting that the â€œCourt may
  not, in order to give [e]ffect to particular words, virtually destroy the
  meaning of the entire context; that is, give the particular words a
  significance which would be clearly repugnant to the statute, looked at as a
  whole, and destructive of its obvious intentâ€).Â  This result further gives efficacy to the Joint Agency Act.Â  Because Blacksburgâ€™s system was not capable of providing PEG (or the Authority) with
  transportation services prior to June 1995, the post-June 1995 addition of the
  transmission pipeline from Blacksburg to Kings Creek made the Blacksburg system
  an available source under the Act.Â  In view of the statutory authorization, the
  Authority is empowered to condemn the subject properties.Â  
II.
Landownersâ€™
  final challenge concerns the trial courtâ€™s failure to dismiss the condemnation
  proceedings based on the incorrect statutory authority referenced in the
  original condemnation notices.Â  The trial court ruled that the Authorityâ€™s â€œfailure
  to cite the proper statutory authority in the Notice of Condemnation may be
  appropriately redressed by an amendment to the notice.â€Â  We observe that no
  party was prejudiced by the reference to the incorrect statutory reference, for
  all parties were well aware of the central dispute concerning legislative
  intent in Act 193.Â  Moreover, Landowners concede that under Act 193 the
  Authority has the power to condemn property. Â We affirm the trial court
  pursuant to Rule 220(b)(1), SCACR.
CONCLUSION
For the reasons
  stated, the judgment of the trial court is
AFFIRMED.
TOAL, C.J.,
  WALLER, BEATTY, KITTREDGE, JJ., and Acting Justice James E. Moore, concur.


[1]  S.C. Code Ann. Â§Â§ 6-24-10 to -300 (Supp. 2008). 
[2]  The Transco pipeline is one of the primary pipelines providing natural
  gas to our state.Â  It originates in the Gulf of Mexico and runs through the
  Southeast then up into New England.

title: Eason v. Eason
description: This is a cross-appeal in a divorce case.
text:
<!DOCTYPE html PUBLIC "-//W3C//DTD HTML 4.01 Transitional//EN"

font-family: Arial, Helvetica, sans-serif;

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court

	
		
			
				Charlean L.
      Eason, Appellant/Respondent,
				v.
				Fredrick W.
      Eason, Respondent/Appellant.
			
		
	


Appeal From Greenville County
Â William J. Wylie, Jr., Family Court Judge
Opinion No. 26714
Heard June 24, 2009 - Filed August 31,
  2009Â Â  
AFFIRMED IN PART; REVERSED IN PART;
  REMANDED


	
		
			
				Kenneth
  C. Porter, of Porter & Rosenfeld, of Greenville, for Appellant-Respondent.
				J.
  Falkner Wilkes, of Greenville, for Respondent-Appellant.
			
		
	


JUSTICE
  WALLER: This is a cross-appeal from the family courtâ€™s order which granted appellant/respondent
  Charlean L. Eason (â€œWifeâ€) and respondent/appellant Fredrick W. Eason
  (â€œHusbandâ€) a divorce based on one yearâ€™s continuous separation. Â We reverse in
  part and remand on Wifeâ€™s appeal. As to Husbandâ€™s appeal, we affirm pursuant to
  Rule 220(b)(1), SCACR.Â  
FACTS
The parties married on November 29, 1973 and separated on October
  26, 2003.[1]Â 
  On October 31, 2003, Wife filed a complaint in family court seeking legal
  separation and alimony (â€œthe 2003 Actionâ€).Â  Husband filed an answer and
  counterclaim in the 2003 Action.Â  
Mediation for the 2003 Action was conducted in September 2004, and
  a number of issues were settled.Â  In the written mediation agreement, the
  parties each reserved â€œthe right to seek alimony from the other until such time
  as [Wife] is fully employed with benefits,[2] at which time this reservation will terminate.â€Â  
A few months later, the parties signed a written agreement (â€œthe
  Agreementâ€) which had been prepared by Husbandâ€™s lawyer and stated the
  following:

	Both parties agree that they will not seek a divorce on the
  grounds of adultery; they will proceed with divorce on the grounds of living
  separate and apart in excess of one year.Â  The parties also agree that
    neither party will use adultery as a bar to alimony.
	Further, both parties agree to be equally responsible for college
  tuition and costs for their son.

(Emphasis
  added).Â  The Agreement referenced the case number associated with the 2003
  Action.Â  Husband signed this document on December 29, 2004, and Wife signed on
  January 7, 2005.Â  Â Â Â  
Also on January 7, 2005, Wife filed a divorce complaint (â€œthe 2005
  Actionâ€).[3]Â 
  The 2005 Action sought a divorce based on continuous separation for one year.Â 
  Wife requested alimony, both pendente lite and permanently, as well as
  attorneyâ€™s fees.Â  Husband promptly filed an answer and counterclaim, also
  requesting a divorce based on continuous separation for one year.Â  The family
  court issued a temporary order awarding Wife spousal support in the amount of
  $1,236.00 per month, which represented one third of Husbandâ€™s gross pay at the
  time.Â  
Over one year later, however, Husband filed a motion to amend his
  answer.Â  Husbandâ€™s amended answer and counterclaim requested a divorce on the
  ground of adultery and also alleged that Wife was in a relationship â€œtantamount
  to marriage.â€Â  Husband claimed Wife should be denied alimony.Â  The family court
  granted his motion to amend.Â  
In March 2007, the family court held a final hearing.Â  At the
  hearing, the parties admitted the mediation agreement from the 2003 Action,
  stating that all issues had been resolved except for alimony and attorneyâ€™s
  fees with respect to the 2005 Action.[4]Â 
  The family court approved the mediation agreement, and it was incorporated into
  the final order.Â  
Wife testified that she no longer works as a nurse due to her
  depression.[5]Â 
  Her treating psychiatrist testified by deposition that Wife has major
  depression, an anxiety disorder, and bipolar disorder.Â  In his opinion, Wife is
  medically unable to work.Â  In February 2007, Wife applied for Social Security
  disability benefits.Â  According to her financial declaration, her only income
  is the temporary alimony from Husband.Â  Husband testified that he has worked
  for the railroad for 34 years.Â  According to his financial declaration, he
  earns $3,600.00 per month.Â  
Regarding the Agreement, Husband testified that he directed his
  attorney to prepare it.Â  Husband further explained as follows:

	Me and [Wife] talked, and we were supposed to get a divorce like
  adults.Â  I didnâ€™t want my children embarrassed by us going by adultery, knowing
  that their mama had adultery - committed adultery and I had adultery.Â  And I
  thought we was just going to get [the divorce] on the conclusion that weâ€™ll
  both go our separate ways.Â  I didnâ€™t know I was signing a paper for her to be
  with a man.Â  I didnâ€™t know I was giving her a license to cheat.

Husband
  acknowledged he was about to move in with his girlfriend when he signed the
  document.Â  
According
  to Wife, Husband asked her to sign the Agreement because â€œhe wanted to move in
  with his girlfriend, [and] he didnâ€™t want me to seek the divorce on the grounds
  of adultery.Â  And because I had no problem with him doing that, I didnâ€™t mind
  signing the paper.â€Â  Wife maintained she did not commit adultery prior to
  signing the paper, and would not have had sex with anyone but for the
  Agreement.
Husband attempted to establish that Wife was continuously living with
  her boyfriend, Calvin Moss.[6]Â 
  Wife and Moss met in May 2004 and became intimate in February 2005.Â  In
  exchange for helping Wife maintain her three trailer properties and repair her
  cars, Moss lives in one of Wifeâ€™s trailers without paying rent.Â  Both Moss and
  Wife admitted that although they had lived together at times, they never
  cohabited for more than two through four weeks at a time.Â  Moss testified they
  do not have any financial arrangements together.Â  Both Moss and Wife testified
  that their relationship is not exclusive and they date other people.Â  In
  addition, the partiesâ€™ 27-year-old son (â€œSonâ€) testified he had not witnessed
  his mother and Moss cohabiting for 90 continuous days.Â  
Husband raised questions about Wifeâ€™s decrease in utilities usage,
  such as water and gas, and introduced copies of the utilities bills to suggest
  that Wife was not actually living at the trailer she said she was.Â  Wife, Son,
  and Moss testified that she turned off the utilities and used kerosene lamps in
  an attempt to save money.
The family court issued a written order barring Wife from
  receiving alimony because Husband established by clear and convincing evidence
  that Wife and Moss had been in an adulterous relationship since early 2005.Â 
  Regarding Wifeâ€™s argument that the Agreement estopped Husband from requesting
  alimony be denied, the family court found the Agreement was an unenforceable
  contract and in contravention of public policy.Â  The family court specifically
  declined to rule on the statutory issue of whether Wife and Moss resided
  together for a period of 90 days or more.Â  See S.C. Code Ann. Â§
  20-3-130(B) (Supp. 2008).Â  Finally, the family court ruled that the parties
  shall pay their own legal fees.Â  

Wife
  and Husband both appeal from the family courtâ€™s order.
ISSUES
Wifeâ€™s Appeal

	
		
			1. 
			Did the family court err in finding Wife was barred 
			from receiving alimony when the parties agreed in writing that 
			neither would use adultery as a bar to alimony?
 
		
		
			2.
			Did the family court err in failing to award Wife 
			attorneyâ€™s fees?
		
	

Husbandâ€™s
  Appeal

	Did the family court err in failing to terminate Wifeâ€™s right to
  alimony based on continuous cohabitation with her boyfriend?

STANDARD OF REVIEW
In appeals from the family court, the appellate court
  has jurisdiction to find facts in accordance with its view of the preponderance
  of the evidence.Â  E.g., Strickland v. Strickland, 375 S.C. 76,
  82, 650 S.E.2d 465, 469 (2007).Â  However, this broad scope of review does
  not require this Court to disregard the findings of the family court.Â  Wooten
    v. Wooten, 364 S.C. 532, 540, 615 S.E.2d 98, 102 (2005).
â€œQuestions
  concerning alimony rest within the sound discretion of the family court judge
  whose conclusion will not be disturbed absent a showing of abuse of
  discretion.â€Â  Degenhart v. Burriss, 360 S.C. 497, 500, 602 S.E.2d 96,
  97 (Ct. App. 2004).Â  An abuse of discretion occurs when the decision is
  controlled by some error of law or is based on findings of fact that are
  without evidentiary support.Â  Id.


DISCUSSION
1.Â  Effect of the Agreement
Based
  on the doctrines of waiver and estoppel, Wife argues the Agreement should have
  been enforced to prevent Husband from asserting the bar on alimony based on
  adultery.Â  We agree.
South Carolina statutory law provides that no alimony may be awarded to a spouse who commits
  adultery before either: (1) the formal signing of a written property or marital
  settlement agreement, or (2) the entry of a permanent order of separate
  maintenance and support or of a permanent order approving a property or marital
  settlement agreement between the parties.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-3-130(A).
â€œWaiver is a voluntary and intentional abandonment or
  relinquishment of a known right.â€Â  Parker v. Parker, 313 S.C. 482, 487,
  443 S.E.2d 388, 391 (1994).Â  Stated differently, waiver requires a party
  to have known of a right and known he was abandoning that right.Â  Strickland, 375
  S.C. at 85, 650 S.E.2d at 471.Â  â€œEquitable estoppel occurs where a party is
  denied the right to plead or prove an otherwise important fact because of
  something which he has done or failed to do.â€Â  Parker, 313 S.C. at 487,
  443 S.E.2d 391.Â  This Court has recognized that â€œthe distinction between waiver and
  estoppel is close, and sometimes the doctrines merge into each other with
  almost imperceptible gradations.â€Â  Id. (citation omitted); Strickland, supra.
We
  find the Agreement here constitutes a waiver of the right to use adultery as a bar
  to alimony.Â  Clearly, Husband knew of this right as it was his lawyer who drew
  up the Agreement.Â  Therefore, Husband intentionally abandoned this right.Â  Strickland, supra.Â  Moreover, Husband actively sought Wifeâ€™s signature on
  the Agreement because he was about to move in with his girlfriend.Â  Thus, the
  trial court erred in not finding Husband was equitably estopped from using
  Wifeâ€™s subsequent adultery as a bar to alimony. Â See Parker, supra.
Husband argues that the Agreement contravenes public policy, and
  therefore, the family court correctly did not enforce the Agreement.Â  See Berkebile v. Outen, 311 S.C. 50,
  54 n.2, 426 S.E.2d 760, 762 n.2 (1993) (â€œThe general rule is that courts
  will not enforce a contract which is violative of public policy, statutory law,
  or provisions of the Constitution.â€).Â  We disagree.
In
  our opinion, the Agreement was a mutual promise to not sue for divorce based on
  adultery, and to not raise adultery as a bar to alimony.Â  In other words, the
  Agreement was not against public policy, it simply was a valid waiver.Â  Hence,
  it must be enforced.Â  See Degenhart v. Burriss, 360 S.C. at 501,
  602 S.E.2d at 98 (the family court â€œmust enforce an unambiguous contract
  according to its terms regardless of its wisdom or folly, apparent
  unreasonableness, or the partiesâ€™ failure to guard their rights carefullyâ€) (internal
  quote marks and citation omitted); cf. Maxwell v. Maxwell, 375
  S.C. 182, 650 S.E.2d 680 (Ct. App. 2007) (upholding a written non-modifiable
  separation agreement which included alimony to the wife as well as a promise
  not to bring a divorce action based on adultery, even though the husband later
  discovered the wife had committed adultery before the agreementâ€™s execution); Croom
    v. Croom, 305 S.C. 158, 406 S.E.2d 381 (Ct. App. 1991) (upholding
  court-approved written settlement of the parties which included alimony to the
  wife and an agreement to not bring divorce action based on adultery despite the
  wifeâ€™s subsequent cohabitation with her paramour).
Accordingly,
  we reverse the family courtâ€™s ruling that the Agreement was unenforceable and
  remand the matter for a determination of the proper type and amount of alimony
  for Wife.Â  See Â§ 20-3-130(C) (enumerating factors to be considered when
  making an alimony award).

2.Â  Attorneyâ€™s Fees
Wife argues the family court erred by not awarding her
  attorneyâ€™s fees. 
An
  award of attorneyâ€™s fees lies within the sound discretion of the family court
  and will not be disturbed absent an abuse of discretion.Â  E.g., Patel
    v. Patel, 359 S.C. 515, 533, 599 S.E.2d 114, 123 (2004).Â  In determining
  whether to award attorneyâ€™s fees, the court should consider each partyâ€™s
  ability to pay his or her own fees, the beneficial results obtained by counsel,
  the partiesâ€™ respective financial conditions, and the effect of the fee on the
  partiesâ€™ standard of living.Â  E.D.M. v. T.A.M., 307 S.C. 471, 476-77,
  415 S.E.2d 812, 816 (1992).
Given
  our disposition on Wifeâ€™s first issue, the family court should reconsider
  Wifeâ€™s request for attorneyâ€™s fees on remand.Â  See Semken v. Semken,
  379 S.C. 71, 664 S.E.2d 493 (Ct. App. 2008) (where the family courtâ€™s decision to terminate the husbandâ€™s 
alimony obligation was reversed, the issue of attorneyâ€™s fees was remanded for reconsideration).
Husbandâ€™s Appeal
Husband
  argues the family court erred by not finding Wife was barred from receiving
  alimony based on her continuous cohabitation with her boyfriend. Â We affirm
  pursuant to Rule 220(b)(1), SCACR, and the following authorities:Â  Strickland
    v. Strickland, 375 S.C. at 89, 650 S.E.2d at 472 (in order to bar alimony
  based on â€œcontinued cohabitation,â€ it must be established that the supported
  spouse lives â€œunder the same roof as the person with whom they are romantically
  involved for at least ninety consecutive daysâ€); Semken v. Semken, 379
  S.C. at 77, 664 S.E.2d at 497  (section 20-3-130 â€œrequires the spouse and
  the paramour to actually â€˜live under the same roofâ€™ for ninety consecutive
  days, rather then merely claim the same residence for that time periodâ€).

CONCLUSION
For
  the reasons discussed above, we reverse the family courtâ€™s finding that Wife is
  barred from receiving alimony and remand to the family court for:Â  (1) a
  determination of the appropriate alimony award; and (2) reconsideration of Wifeâ€™s
  request for attorneyâ€™s fees.
AFFIRMED
  IN PART; REVERSED IN PART; AND REMANDED.

TOAL, C.J.,
  PLEICONES, BEATTY and KITTREDGE, JJ., concur.


[1] The parties have one son who was over 18 and
  attending college at the time the parties separated.
[2] Wife received her associateâ€™s degree in nursing in
  1987 and became a licensed registered nurse in 1988.Â  From that time until
  2001, she worked full time as a nurse at Greenville Memorial hospital.Â  Wife
  stopped working due to depression. She briefly returned
  to nursing in 2004, but left the job after a few months when she had a
  breakdown and was hospitalized for depression.Â  
[3] The 2003 Action had been
  administratively dismissed.
[4] In the mediation agreement, Husband agreed to pay Wifeâ€™s
  attorneyâ€™s fees of $3,000.
[5] See fn. 2, supra. 
[6] See S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 20-3-130(B) (Supp. 2008)
  (which provides that alimony terminates upon â€œthe remarriage or continued
  cohabitation of the supported spouseâ€).Â  This section also provides as follows:

	For
  purposes of this subsection and unless otherwise agreed to in writing by the
  parties, â€œcontinued cohabitationâ€ means the supported spouse resides with
  another person in a romantic relationship for a period of ninety or more
  consecutive days. Â The court may determine that a continued cohabitation exists
  if there is evidence that the supported spouse resides with another person in a
  romantic relationship for periods of less than ninety days and the two
  periodically separate in order to circumvent the ninety-day requirement.
